stories.lead_paragraph: The most dramatic space flight in history ended yesterday with the safe return of Apollo 13's crew. For three-and-a-half days all three astronauts had lived at the brink of death in a crippled vehicle whose reserves were so near exhaustion that it had margin neither for human error nor for further malfunctioning of its equipment.

stories.lead_paragraph: Gusts of nearly 25 miles per hour here forced the space shuttle Atlantis and its astronauts to postpone their return to Earth today for a second day. The weather was no better at the backup landing site in California, so NASA ordered the crew to plan for a Tuesday landing. The shuttle and its crew of five undocked from the International Space Station on Friday, after delivering and installing the $1.4 billion Destiny laboratory, and should have returned to Earth on Sunday.

stories.abstract: Investigators say most of recovered U-shaped panels from leading edge of space shuttle Columbia's left wing were split along middle; believe left wing was opened up to superheated gases as shuttle tried to return to Earth, but they are still uncertain about chain of events leading up to disaster; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Findings Deemed Significant, but Inconclusive

stories.snippet: Investigators said today that most of the recovered U-shaped panels from the leading edge of the Columbia's left wing had been split along the middle. They said the finding was significant, but they did not know what it meant.     Experts say they...

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ and MATTHEW L. WALD

stories.lead_paragraph: Investigators said today that most of the recovered U-shaped panels from the leading edge of the Columbia's left wing had been split along the middle. They said the finding was significant, but they did not know what it meant. Experts say they believe that the left wing was opened up to superheated gases, probably at the leading edge, as the shuttle tried to return to earth on Feb. 1. Their operative theory is that the cause of the breach was a strike by debris on liftoff. But nine weeks into the investigation, they say they are still uncertain about the chain of events, and new findings like the one today about the reinforced carbon-carbon wing panels merely added to the mystery.

headline.main: Hapless Crew Of Mir Station Back on Earth

stories.snippet: After six of the least glorious months in the history of manned space flight, the hapless crew of the Mir space station retreated from the cosmos this afternoon, floating to earth three hours later in a cloud of dust on the steppes of Kazakstan.    ...
stories.lead_paragraph: After six of the least glorious months in the history of manned space flight, the hapless crew of the Mir space station retreated from the cosmos this afternoon, floating to earth three hours later in a cloud of dust on the steppes of Kazakstan. ''I hope that everything that went wrong here is leaving with us,'' the forlorn commander, Vasily Tsibliyev, told the three crew members who remained, as he prepared to leave the space station. ''We are leaving now. See you on earth.''

byline.original: By ANDREW C. REVKIN and WARREN E. LEARY; John Schwartz contributed reporting for this article

stories.lead_paragraph: NASA officials acknowledged yesterday that air, water and radiation monitors, medical devices and some other systems on the International Space Station were ailing or broken. But in news conferences, the astronauts aboard the station and a number of space agency officials said they were confident that the station was safe for now. They said that the situation was being carefully monitored and that the astronauts could be evacuated quickly if problems worsened.

headline.main: Universe as Doughnut: New Data, New Debate

stories.snippet: Long ago in the dawn of the computer age, college students often whiled away the nights playing a computer game called Spacewar. It consisted of two rocket ships attempting to blast each other out of the sky with torpedoes while trying to avoid...
stories.lead_paragraph: Long ago in the dawn of the computer age, college students often whiled away the nights playing a computer game called Spacewar. It consisted of two rocket ships attempting to blast each other out of the sky with torpedoes while trying to avoid falling into a star at the center of the screen. Although cartoonish in appearance, the game was amazingly faithful to the laws of physics, complete with a gravitational field that affected both the torpedoes and the rockets. Only one feature seemed outlandish: a ship that drifted off the edge of the screen would reappear on the opposite side.

headline.main: Plotting a Mission to Retrieve Rocks From Mars

stories.snippet: WHILE scientists at several laboratories examine a dark piece of rock to see if it indeed holds evidence of early life on Mars, NASA officials are weighing a wide assortment of ideas for revamping and accelerating current plans for exploring the red...
stories.lead_paragraph: WHILE scientists at several laboratories examine a dark piece of rock to see if it indeed holds evidence of early life on Mars, NASA officials are weighing a wide assortment of ideas for revamping and accelerating current plans for exploring the red planet. The focus is on how and when to secure what scientists covet most: an indisputable sample of Martian rock and soil, preferably from a relatively warm, wet place where microbes might have arisen long ago. Mission planners and scientists are expected to offer recommendations to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration this month. They want to take advantage of public and political enthusiasms touched off by the announcement last month that a meteorite that apparently fell from Mars contained mineral and fossil traces of possible life. They also need to have mission options ready for NASA budget planning, negotiations with potential international partners and a conference on space at the White House in December.

headline.main: Lunar Debris Danger Discounted

stories.snippet: The Times's concern over biological contamination from the moon (editorials of May 18 and May 25) is entirely misdirected. Every day, the earth receives more lunar matter in the form of meteors and meteorites than the entire Apollo program is...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Times's concern over biological contamination from the moon (editorials of May 18 and May 25) is entirely misdirected. Every day, the earth receives more lunar matter in the form of meteors and meteorites than the entire Apollo program is scheduled to return. This influx has gone on for four and a half billion years, apparently without completely obliterating terrestrial life.

headline.main: 2-Man Crew, With Modified Duties, Reaches Space Station

stories.snippet: The pared-down relief crew arrived at the International Space Station today, just two men who will work to keep the massive project running in place until American space shuttles fly again and construction can resume.    Duties of this two-man crew...
stories.lead_paragraph: The pared-down relief crew arrived at the International Space Station today, just two men who will work to keep the massive project running in place until American space shuttles fly again and construction can resume. Duties of this two-man crew will differ greatly from those of its three-member predecessors: as a result of the grounding of the American shuttle fleet after the loss of the Columbia on Feb. 1, space station building has come to a halt and normal supply lines are choked. The new crew will have less time for research and will have to pay extra attention to food, water and other consumables, which are in increasingly short supply without regular shuttle visits.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Flight To An Asteroid

stories.snippet: A Japanese rocket lifted off on a four-year mission to bring asteroid samples back to Earth for the first time. The Muses-C space probe, launched from Kagoshima Space Center on the island of Kyushu, is to make the two-way trip to the tiny asteroid...
stories.lead_paragraph: A Japanese rocket lifted off on a four-year mission to bring asteroid samples back to Earth for the first time. The Muses-C space probe, launched from Kagoshima Space Center on the island of Kyushu, is to make the two-way trip to the tiny asteroid 1998 SF36, 180 million miles from Earth. To collect the samples, the probe will make three brief contacts with the asteroid -- 2,300 feet long and 1,000 feet wide -- each time firing a small projectile into its crust and collecting the ejected fragments. The probe is to return to Earth in 2007, with the container of samples designed to parachute into the Australian desert.

stories.snippet: Stuffing to the Gills      It's pretty difficult (not to mention impolite) to talk with your mouth full. But the cardinalfish has a different problem. It finds it hard to breathe, as a full mouth impedes the flow of oxygen-bearing water past the...
stories.lead_paragraph: Stuffing to the Gills It's pretty difficult (not to mention impolite) to talk with your mouth full. But the cardinalfish has a different problem. It finds it hard to breathe, as a full mouth impedes the flow of oxygen-bearing water past the gills. Now, you may wonder just how often cardinalfish, found around coral reefs, actually become stuffed to the gills. The answer is quite often, though food has nothing to do with it. Like a few other types of fish, cardinalfish are mouthbrooders. Males keep fertilized eggs in their mouths for a week or two, until they hatch. Broods can be large, up to a quarter of the fish's body weight.

stories.abstract: NASA records show that emergency plan to use International Space Station as safe haven for shuttle astronauts whose craft cannot safely return to earth carries high risk of failure; says station lacks adequate support systems and supplies for its occupants and shuttle crew to survive for more than few months at best and few weeks at worst, not enough time to perform rescue; information underscores risk inherent in space travel; some NASA employees say safety remains afterthought (M)

headline.main: NASA Rescue Plan Is Reported to Have High Risk of Failure

stories.snippet: NASA's emergency plan to use the International Space Station as a safe haven for shuttle astronauts whose craft cannot safely return to earth would carry a high risk of failure if it were ever tried, according to internal space agency documents.    ...
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA's emergency plan to use the International Space Station as a safe haven for shuttle astronauts whose craft cannot safely return to earth would carry a high risk of failure if it were ever tried, according to internal space agency documents. The documents say the space station lacks adequate support systems and supplies to assure that its own occupants and a shuttle crew could stay alive for more than a few months at best and a few weeks at worst -- not enough time, under many possible situations outlined in the documents, to carry off a rescue plan.

stories.lead_paragraph: Russian space officials have only the highest praise and affection for Shannon Lucid, the NASA astronaut who has spent the last six months aboard their orbiting station. But they hope she will be able to go home soon. Dr. Lucid, 53, a biochemist and mother of three grown children, was supposed to return to Earth in early August. But problems with booster rockets and two hurricanes stalled a trip by the shuttle Atlantis to Mir, the Russian space station.

stories.lead_paragraph: After nearly 18 days aloft, the space shuttle Columbia and its five astronauts returned to Earth today at dawn, ending the longest shuttle flight ever. stories.snippet: The two main systems for producing oxygen on the Mir broke down today, presenting its three-man crew with a fresh setback just days after the crippled space station appeared to be on the road to recovery.    NASA described the mishap as ''serious''...
stories.lead_paragraph: The two main systems for producing oxygen on the Mir broke down today, presenting its three-man crew with a fresh setback just days after the crippled space station appeared to be on the road to recovery. NASA described the mishap as ''serious'' but said the crew still had enough oxygen to last several days, during which they would try to repair the systems. But failure to restore the flow of oxygen could force the evacuation of the space station and deal a humiliating blow to the impoverished Russian space program.

stories.lead_paragraph: Fueling civilization a half-century from now and stemming global warming is a titanic challenge. It is inspiring big ideas, but not nearly enough research to pull them off. This page illustrates just one possible portfolio of future United States energy sources and the potential share of each, as envisioned by several experts. Each fuel has its partisans and skeptics experts do disagree.

stories.abstract: Article in series The Energy Challenge examines challenge of limiting global warming at time when research into energy technologies by government industry has been falling, not rising; United States federal spending for all energy research and development is less than half of what it was quarter-century ago; Pres Bush's request for $4.2 billion increase for 2007 is considered only small fraction of what is needed by most climate and energy experts; Japan is lone economic power to increase research spending in recent decades; studies show private sector energy companies have long tradition of eschewing long-term technology quests because of lack of short-term payoffs; many scientists, economists, engineers and entrepreneurs agree that without more aggressive search for non-polluting energy sources and systems, world faces dangerous warming and international strife as nations with growing energy demands compete for increasingly inadequate resources; charts; graphs (L)

headline.main: BUDGETS FALLING IN RACE TO FIGHT GLOBAL WARMING

stories.snippet: Though experts agree the world faces a daunting challenge in finding nonpolluting energy sources, research into new technology has declined.
stories.lead_paragraph: Cheers fit for a revival meeting swept a hotel ballroom as 1,800 entrepreneurs and experts watched a PowerPoint presentation of the most promising technologies for limiting global warming: solar power, wind, ethanol and other farmed fuels, energy-efficient buildings and fuel-sipping cars. ''Houston,'' Charles F. Kutscher, chairman of the Solar 2006 conference, concluded in a twist on the line from Apollo 13, ''we have a solution.''

headline.main: Justice Dept. to Join Suit Against TRW

stories.snippet: The Justice Department said today that it would join in a whistle-blower lawsuit that accuses TRW Inc. of falsely billing the Government for expenses.     The lawsuit, filed by a former TRW financial manager, Richard D. Bagley, contends that the...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said today that it would join in a whistle-blower lawsuit that accuses TRW Inc. of falsely billing the Government for expenses. The lawsuit, filed by a former TRW financial manager, Richard D. Bagley, contends that the company ''fraudulently'' classified its work in a way that resulted in NASA and the Pentagon being billed for expenses that should have come out of the company's pocket. The overcharge was $50 million, said Eric R. Havian, a lawyer for Mr. Bagley.

headline.main: The Big Thought Is Missing in National Security

stories.snippet: Why, six years after 9/11, is there no mega-research project to address the plausible security threats to the United States in the 21st century?
stories.lead_paragraph: WHY has the pace of fundamental innovation in military technologies slowed? Why, six years after 9/11, is there no mega-research project -- along the lines of the crash Manhattan Project that 62 years ago produced the first atomic bombs -- to address the plausible security threats to the United States in the 21st century? These two questions say a lot about how innovation happens today, and why concerns about national security, which once motivated civilian scientists and engineers to make crucial contributions to military technologies, may again shape innovation priorities.

headline.main: Smile, Gamers: You're in the Picture

stories.snippet: RICHARD MARX, a 34-year-old astronautical and aeronautical engineer, has been spending a lot of time lately pretending to be Harry Potter. His wand is made from parts of a hotel clothes hanger and has a brightly colored ball on one end. But when he...
stories.lead_paragraph: RICHARD MARX, a 34-year-old astronautical and aeronautical engineer, has been spending a lot of time lately pretending to be Harry Potter. His wand is made from parts of a hotel clothes hanger and has a brightly colored ball on one end. But when he waves it, Dr. Marx says, it begins to glow and emit a distinctive hum in a TV monitor across the room. By moving the wand in a circle, he can produce a trail that turns into a ring of fire on the screen. By flicking the wand toward the TV, he can make a fireball sizzle across the monitor. Other geometric shapes conjure tornadoes or make the player invisible. ''I actually had my son draw up a list of spells he thought would be good,'' Dr. Marx said.

headline.main: POINT OF VIEW; A Government Takeover of R. and D.?

stories.snippet: Under the leadership of the old Office of Scientific Research and Development, the combined scientific and technical resources of our governmental, industrial and academic communities were rapidly and effectively mobilized to win World War II. New...
stories.lead_paragraph: Under the leadership of the old Office of Scientific Research and Development, the combined scientific and technical resources of our governmental, industrial and academic communities were rapidly and effectively mobilized to win World War II. New management mechanisms with fast reaction times were evolved. Authority and responsibility were clearly delegated for specific technical programs, usually without political constraints at the Federal or local level.

headline.main: The Final Frontier, And Earthly Needs

stories.snippet: To the Editor:     Following on the heels of your report about scientific findings of the potential relationship between global warming and the extinction of countless species within the next 50 years (news article, Jan. 8), we read about the...
stories.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Following on the heels of your report about scientific findings of the potential relationship between global warming and the extinction of countless species within the next 50 years (news article, Jan. 8), we read about the president's proposed new initiative to send humans to Mars (front page, Jan. 9). The need for a major research and development effort to address the devastating impact of climate change surely must take precedence over adventures in outer space. WENDY M. GERINGER Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. Jan. 9, 2004

headline.main: LOCKHEED WINS TWO BIG SPACE CONTRACTS

stories.snippet: The Lockheed Martin Corporation won a contract worth up to $243.5 million yesterday to support shuttle missions and programs on the International Space Station and a one-year contract extension worth up to $184 million to help NASA's research and...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Lockheed Martin Corporation won a contract worth up to $243.5 million yesterday to support shuttle missions and programs on the International Space Station and a one-year contract extension worth up to $184 million to help NASA's research and development laboratories. The shuttle and space station contract is initially for nine months and worth $64.9 million, but can be extended for up to two years, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said. Shares of Lockheed, which is based in Bethesda, Md., rose 48 cents, to $45.91.

stories.abstract: Boeing says it will enter space tourism business, announcement that could bolster Obama administration's efforts to transform National Aeronautics and Space Administration into agency that focuses less on building rockets and more on nurturing commercial space industry; flights could begin as early as 2015 and would likely be launched from Cape Canaveral to International Space Station; Pres Obama has proposed turning over to private companies business of taking NASA astronauts to orbit; Boeing and Bigelow Aerospace of Las Vegas have $18 million contract for development and testing of capsule that could carry seven passengers; current NASA plans call for four space station crew members at a time, leaving three seats for space tourists; House bill calls on NASA to build government-owned rockets for taking astronauts to space station and eventually Mars; competing vision, embodied in Obama's 2011 budget proposal for NASA, focuses instead on investing in companies like Boeing that want to develop space equivalent of airlines; thinking goes that competition will drive down costs of getting to space, leading to profitable new American industry and freeing more of NASA's budget for deep-space missions; photos (M)

headline.main: Boeing Plans To Fly Tourists Beyond Earth

stories.snippet: The move could bolster efforts by the Obama administration to direct NASA toward commercial space.
stories.lead_paragraph: Boeing said Wednesday that it was entering the space tourism business, an announcement that could bolster the Obama administration's efforts to transform the National Aeronautics and Space Administration into an agency that focuses less on building rockets and more on nurturing a commercial space industry. The flights, which could begin as early as 2015, would most likely launch from Cape Canaveral in Florida to the International Space Station. The Obama administration has proposed turning over to private companies the business of taking NASA astronauts to orbit, and Boeing and Bigelow Aerospace of Las Vegas won an $18 million contract this year for preliminary development and testing of a capsule that could carry seven passengers.

stories.abstract: 3 US astronauts on May 26 are launched from Cape Kennedy for orbital rendezvous with malfunctioning Skylab space station; fail to dislodge jammed solar power wing and, after 9 attempts, finally succeed in docking with Skylab; transmit TV pictures of malfunctioning vehicle; link-up is achieved after 3 hrs, during which crew effects changes in wiring of Skylab's docking hatch; achieves 'hard dock' by using jumper cable to bypass series of control switches and route power directly to motor that operates docking latches; Comdr Weitz fails to dislodge solar power wing using 10-ft-long shepherd's crook and pruning shears; radioes: 'I hate to say it, but we ain't going to do it with the tools we got'; Capt Conrad says wing appears to be 'hooked in there like its nailed in'; repts: 'Solar wing 2 was gone, completely off the bird. Wing 1 is partially deployed, a bulge of meteoroid shield holding it'; repts also that gold foil covering much of Skylab's hull, exposed because of missing thermal shield, has turned considerably black in sun; temperatures within space station have remained excessive as result of loss of thermal micrometeoroid shield during launching from Cape Kennedy and because of failure of solar power wing; crew will transfer from Apollo spacecraft to Skylab wearing face masks in event that laboratory contains noxous gases from deterioration of overheated plastic materials; hope to deploy mylar awning over space station through airlock in side of vehicle; launching of astronauts from Cape Kennedy described; scientists illus at Kennedy Space Center; Saturn 1B illus leaving launching pad; TV picture of Skylab as seen from Apollo spacecraft

headline.main: Atlantis Blasts Off in Swift Pursuit of Mir Space Station

stories.snippet: In a celestial chase around the Earth, the space shuttle Atlantis dashed across the skies today, pursuing the Russian Mir space station for a rendezvous and linkup.    Atlantis, with a crew of six, blasted into chilly, pre-dawn skies today on flaming...
stories.lead_paragraph: In a celestial chase around the Earth, the space shuttle Atlantis dashed across the skies today, pursuing the Russian Mir space station for a rendezvous and linkup. Atlantis, with a crew of six, blasted into chilly, pre-dawn skies today on flaming rockets that remained visible from the launching site for almost eight minutes. Looking like a bright star, the shuttle finally disappeared into the darkness after it was more than 300 miles away from the Kennedy Space Center and about 70 miles high.

stories.abstract: Space shuttle Atlantis is launched from Cape Canaveral on mission to carry science laboratory to International Space Station; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Atlantis Heads for Space Station Carrying Laboratory

stories.snippet: The space shuttle Atlantis, carrying a giant American science laboratory that will anchor further expansion of the International Space Station, created a visual spectacular today as it rocketed into the twilight.    Carrying a crew of five, the...
stories.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Atlantis, carrying a giant American science laboratory that will anchor further expansion of the International Space Station, created a visual spectacular today as it rocketed into the twilight. Carrying a crew of five, the shuttle rose from the Kennedy Space Center in a dazzling splash of color across the sky to begin a two-day chase of the space station. The mission, one of the most crucial for the station, is to give the orbiting outpost the ability to do cutting-edge science, one purpose of the $60 billion program.

stories.abstract: Tech Sergeant Joseph Bannon, firefighter at New Jersey Air National Guard's 177th Figher Wing Base at Atlantic City International Airport, answers questions on emergency preparations in event space shuttle launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla, gets into trouble; photo (On the Map column) (M)

headline.main: Firefighters Are Ready to Rescue a Space Shuttle in Distress

stories.snippet: Space shuttles  launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., commonly head south, but  for resupply missions to the International Space Station, they  head north. If such a  shuttle were to get in trouble, one of the three places on the East Coast where  it...
stories.lead_paragraph: Space shuttles launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., commonly head south, but for resupply missions to the International Space Station, they head north. If such a shuttle were to get in trouble, one of the three places on the East Coast where it can make an emergency landing is the New Jersey Air National Guard's 177th Fighter Wing Base at Atlantic City International Airport. There, firefighters attached to the 177th Wing will get the astronauts out in a hurry. Tech. Sgt. Joseph Bannon, one of those firefighters, talked about the rescue plans. Q. Why did NASA choose the base at Atlantic City National International Airport?

headline.main: Space Station's First Construction Crew Lifts Off Aboard the Shuttle

stories.snippet: The planet's most daring construction job began today as the shuttle Endeavour carried into orbit six astronauts and the first American-built part of an international space station that is expected to cost more than $100 billion.    After a...
stories.lead_paragraph: The planet's most daring construction job began today as the shuttle Endeavour carried into orbit six astronauts and the first American-built part of an international space station that is expected to cost more than $100 billion. After a last-minute alarm on the shuttle forced a postponement early Thursday, the launching went off flawlessly at 3:36 this morning, right on schedule. The night sky was clear, and the moon full. With a roar, Endeavour made its fiery ascent and briefly turned the Florida coastline from night to day. More than five minutes and 500 miles later, the spaceship's main engines could still be seen in the distance, twinkling like a new star.

stories.abstract: Lt Col J H Glenn Jr orbits earth 3 times in Friendship 7 Mercury capsule, lands safely in Atlantic and is picked up by destroyer Noa; 40-yr-old astronaut, 1st Amer to achieve orbital flight, is well after 81,000-mi, 4-hr-56-min flight except for 2 knuckles skinned while blowing capsule side hatch; he is transferred to carrier Randolph, later flown to Grand Turk Is for 2 days of 'de-briefing' and rest; was launched from Cape Canaveral by Atlas rocket at 9:47 AM, landed in ocean at 2:43 PM, taken from water at 3:01 PM; orbit ranged between 99 and 162 mi; capsule traveled at about 17,350 mph; officials feared that heat shield had become unlatched and would fall before re-entry, leaving capsule to disintegrate; had Glenn delay jettisoning retro-rocket pkg so that its straps would hold shield in place; pkg burned during re-entry, shield did not drop until it was to deploy cloth landing bag, indicating signal that caused anxiety about latch may have been false; automatic attitude control system faltered during flight, forcing Glenn to use manual controls and causing some doubt that 3 orbits could be made; some of Glenn's equipment, his med kit, other flight details noted; pre-flight, launch and recovery scenes illus

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: Sun-Particle Mission Blasts Off

stories.snippet: After nine days of delay, a NASA robotic explorer named Genesis began a three-year, 20-million-mile, round-trip mission to gather and return tiny particles of the sun. Genesis will travel to a point one million miles from Earth, then spend two and a...
stories.lead_paragraph: After nine days of delay, a NASA robotic explorer named Genesis began a three-year, 20-million-mile, round-trip mission to gather and return tiny particles of the sun. Genesis will travel to a point one million miles from Earth, then spend two and a half years gathering atoms from the solar winds on collector panels. When they come to Earth in 2004, the atoms will be the first extraterrestrial material returned by NASA since Apollo 17 astronauts brought back lunar rocks in 1972.

headline.main: Military Satellite Stranded in a Lopsided Orbit

stories.snippet: A giant rocket failed to carry a communications satellite into its intended orbit after launching from Florida today, dealing the Air Force a third straight setback in a space mission that cost well over $1 billion.    ''Obviously, this is a very...
stories.lead_paragraph: A giant rocket failed to carry a communications satellite into its intended orbit after launching from Florida today, dealing the Air Force a third straight setback in a space mission that cost well over $1 billion. ''Obviously, this is a very disappointing day,'' Brig. Gen. Randy Starbuck told an early evening news conference at Cape Canaveral, confirming that a Titan 4B rocket costing $433 million had failed to lift a satellite worth $800 million into proper orbit.

stories.snippet: Intrigued by fresh evidence of possible life on Mars, scientists launched an unmanned spacecraft today as the first step in a planned 10-year campaign to explore the arid plains, valleys and polar ice caps of the red planet.    The ultimate goal of...
stories.lead_paragraph: Intrigued by fresh evidence of possible life on Mars, scientists launched an unmanned spacecraft today as the first step in a planned 10-year campaign to explore the arid plains, valleys and polar ice caps of the red planet. The ultimate goal of this new generation of robotic explorers is to solve a mystery that has long fired the human imagination: have there ever been Martians in any form, however rudimentary, and do they still exist?

headline.main: Fear and Flying

stories.snippet: Every tragedy in space gives rise to a handful of usual questions, and a big one is, Are astronauts ever scared? The answer, of course, is that every mission is different, every program is different, every person is different. For me, there is no...
stories.lead_paragraph: Every tragedy in space gives rise to a handful of usual questions, and a big one is, Are astronauts ever scared? The answer, of course, is that every mission is different, every program is different, every person is different. For me, there is no question that space travel gave rise to an anxiety, a heightened sense of alertness. But I think most of my colleagues would agree that this has less to do with concern for your safety than with anxiety that your performance will not measure up to expectations. The big worry is that you are on the verge of messing up, and that might lead to a problem, endangering the mission and the crew. There is hardly anything productive about worry or fear when you can't do anything about the circumstances. Why be anxious until something happens? I think about taking off in a fighter plane -- you get the aircraft in the air and raise the gear, and if at that moment the engine goes out, you're in big trouble. Yet it wouldn't be much fun to be a fighter pilot if you were filled with fear every time you went out on the runway. I don't think anybody -- astronauts or otherwise -- is born with some kind of right stuff. It's something you work into. You don't learn it, but you adjust to it in your own way. Or else you wash out of flight school and get a job as a journalist.

stories.lead_paragraph: DURING the cold war, small groups of officials in Washington and Moscow held a monopoly on secret intelligence and often clashed publicly on whether the data indicated that arms treaties were being obeyed or broken. stories.abstract: Local boosters in Huntsville, Ala, are hoping to use 50th anniversary of Explorer I, first American satellite launched into orbit, to promote Huntsville as Rocket City; relocation of German rocket scientists to area in 1950 transformed city from small cotton town to birthplace of space program, now with one of country's highest concentrations of rocket scientists and propulsion experts; photos; map (M)

headline.main: When the Germans, and Their Rockets, Came to Town

stories.snippet: After World War II, Huntsville, Ala., was transformed by Wernher von Braun’s rocket program. Now it has one of the country’s highest concentrations of scientists and engineers.
stories.lead_paragraph: In 1950, this cotton market town in northern Alabama lost a bid for a military aviation project that would have revived its mothballed arsenal. The consolation prize was dubious: 118 German rocket scientists who had surrendered to the Americans during World War II, led by a man -- a crackpot, evidently -- who claimed humans could visit the moon. Ultimately those German immigrants made history, launching the first American satellite, Explorer I, into orbit in January 1958 and putting astronauts on the moon in 1969. The crackpot, Wernher von Braun, was celebrated as a visionary.

headline.main: Marveling at Wonders Out of This World

stories.snippet: An exhibition at the National Air and Space Museum features 148 extraordinary photographs of moons and planets.
stories.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- When I was very young, I cherished a collection of ''space cards'' -- trading cards that accompanied packs of bubble gum -- offering exotic visions that supposedly would soon be within reach: space ships gliding through Saturn's rings; explorers enduring a Venus dust storm; loopy Technicolor Martians making their first contact with visiting Earthlings. Some of those half-century-old imaginings may have been outlandish, but the cards left their mark, assisted by decades of science fiction that confidently assumed we were on the brink of an era of pioneering exploration. In a way, we were, though not quite as those cards suggested. But the appetite they whetted remained.

headline.main: Restoring a Museum Piece, A Jungle Gym That Once Flew

stories.snippet: At the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum in New York, a Grumman fighter jet is painstakingly restored.
stories.lead_paragraph: THE Grumman F9F Cougar had seen better days, some of them flying in Navy fighter squadrons in the 1950s. But then it was retired and ended up spending years in a park in New Jersey as perhaps the world's coolest jungle gym. Now it's a mess -- the once-smooth metal skin rough and spotted, holes here and there. The fuselage is in two pieces. And the wings have been taken off, which, for a high-performance jet aircraft, is a real insult.

headline.main: Enterprise Is Hoisted To Deck Of Intrepid

stories.snippet: Updated, 4:05 p.m. | First, the space shuttle Enterprise came by air. Then, on Wednesday, it arrived again - this time by sea.     Six weeks after the Enterprise made its New York City debut on the back of a 747 jet, it completed its oft-delayed...
stories.lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:05 p.m. | First, the space shuttle Enterprise came by air. Then, on Wednesday, it arrived again - this time by sea. Six weeks after the Enterprise made its New York City debut on the back of a 747 jet, it completed its oft-delayed journey to Manhattan in appropriately slow motion. The final act was a precise water ballet involving the shuttle, two barges, three tugboats, a huge floating crane and an aircraft carrier.

stories.abstract: National Air and Space Museum site opens display of Smithsonian's collection of space artifacts at James S McDonnell Space Hangar in Chantilly, Va; photo (M)

headline.main: Smithsonian Displays Space Artifacts

stories.snippet: The National Air and Space Museum's giant site at Dulles Airport, already crammed with high-profile exhibits like the Enola Gay and a Concorde, on Nov. 1 added a large display from the museums' collection of space artifacts. The more than 600 items...
stories.lead_paragraph: The National Air and Space Museum's giant site at Dulles Airport, already crammed with high-profile exhibits like the Enola Gay and a Concorde, on Nov. 1 added a large display from the museums' collection of space artifacts. The more than 600 items on display in the newly opened James S. McDonnell Space Hangar, in Chantilly, Va., include the first Space Shuttle, artifacts from the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo programs and Soviet spaceship parts. There is also a missile with a 15-foot array of metal fins that looks like the ribs of an umbrella, resembling a prop out of a George Lucas movie -- an eerie coincidence since it was part of President Ronald Reagan's ''Star Wars'' defense plan.

headline.main: A Year of 'Star Wars' Starts at Smithsonian

stories.snippet: The Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum, which chronicles the history of manned flight, is paying homage to some of the most famous fictional space travel.    A new show, ''Star Wars: The Magic of Myth,'' opened last month and is scheduled to...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum, which chronicles the history of manned flight, is paying homage to some of the most famous fictional space travel. A new show, ''Star Wars: The Magic of Myth,'' opened last month and is scheduled to run through next Nov. 1. It features original props, models, characters, costumes and artwork from the original George Lucas film trilogy, ''Star Wars: A New Hope'' (1977), ''The Empire Strikes Back'' (1980) and ''Return of the Jedi'' (1983).

headline.main: A Museum Increases Its Wingspan

stories.snippet: THE Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum is generally considered to be the most visited museum in the world, with over nine million visitors a year. But even the most dedicated of those see just a few highlights of the Smithsonian's collection,...
stories.lead_paragraph: THE Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum is generally considered to be the most visited museum in the world, with over nine million visitors a year. But even the most dedicated of those see just a few highlights of the Smithsonian's collection, because the building on the National Mall has had space to display only about 10 percent of the museum's holdings. Soon visitors will be able to see much more. On Dec. 15, two days before aviation history buffs mark the 100th anniversary of the first powered flight, the museum will open the Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center, a new 760,000-square-foot hangar on the edge of Dulles International Airport in Chantilly, Va. It will eventually house most of the rest of the collection, displaying many of the museum's treasures for easy public viewing for the first time. The Wright Brothers' 1903 Flyer will stay in the downtown building, but those who make the 28-mile trip out to Dulles will be able to see all of that aircraft's giant progeny, including Air France's first Concorde, the prototype for the Boeing 707, NASA's prototype Space Shuttle and the Superfortress that dropped the first atomic bomb on Japan in 1945

stories.lead_paragraph: THE first thing visitors encounter in the main display area of the Udvar-Hazy Center, the National Air and Space Museum annex near Dulles airport in the Virginia countryside, is a huge black spy plane. It's an SR-71A Blackbird, the ultimate hot-rod aircraft, one of about 30 built at the Lockheed Skunk Works in California in the 1960s. This one last flew in 1990, traveling the 2,300 miles between Los Angeles and Washington in 1 hour 4 minutes 20 seconds -- a transcontinental blur.

headline.main: FOOTLIGHTS

stories.snippet: NEWS    Earthly Visions      Thirty years after man first walked on the moon, ''Artistry of Space,'' an exhibition of 78 paintings, drawings and multimedia works, is traveling the rails. The show, aboard Artrain USA, billed as the nation's only...
stories.lead_paragraph: NEWS Earthly Visions Thirty years after man first walked on the moon, ''Artistry of Space,'' an exhibition of 78 paintings, drawings and multimedia works, is traveling the rails. The show, aboard Artrain USA, billed as the nation's only traveling art museum on a train, is an exhibition of works from the National Air and Space Museum and NASA. Since 1962 NASA has invited more than 250 American artists to witness United States space missions and to interpret space flight through their art. As a result Peter Max, Robert Rauschenberg, Norman Rockwell, Andy Warhol and James Wyeth have documented the work of engineers, astronauts and scientists in space exploration. Artrain, with its classic railroad cars, is at Union Station in Washington through Sunday and in coming months will be visiting Atlantic City, N.J., Seymour, Conn., and Chatham, N.Y.

headline.main: Just a Couple Of Astronauts Sitting Around Talking Mars

stories.snippet: It's not every day that students from around the world have a chance to interact with people who have been in space. But students will be able to do just that on May 2, when the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum presents a live...
stories.lead_paragraph: It's not every day that students from around the world have a chance to interact with people who have been in space. But students will be able to do just that on May 2, when the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum presents a live two-hour interactive Webcast on the Internet and via a satellite broadcast. The Webcast, ''Cyber Space Day,'' from noon to 2 p.m., will focus on this year's Space Day theme: living and working on Mars. Mars experts, scientists and astronauts will take part, and the forums will include e-mail question-and-answer sessions with Sally K. Ride, the first American woman in space, and former Senator John Glenn, the first American to orbit the Earth. (He returned to space at age 77 in 1998.)

stories.lead_paragraph: SUITLAND, Md. -- Stashed in a Smithsonian storage building in this Washington suburb are some of the engineering wonders of the space race. These marvels are far smaller than the towering rockets and streamlined spacecraft that took men into orbit and to the Moon. Far softer, too. They are the spacesuits that kept the astronauts alive beyond Earth.

headline.main: Mighty Moon Suits Are Falling Apart

stories.snippet: For people awake and aware during the Apollo Moon landings, the most unforgettable images sent to Earth were of astronauts in their ghostly white spacesuits framed by the gray landscape of another world.    Shielded in the suits from the Moon's harsh...
stories.lead_paragraph: For people awake and aware during the Apollo Moon landings, the most unforgettable images sent to Earth were of astronauts in their ghostly white spacesuits framed by the gray landscape of another world. Shielded in the suits from the Moon's harsh environment, the men skipped across the dusty terrain, scooted about in wire-wheeled buggies, picked up piles of rocks and even swatted golf balls over the horizon.

headline.main: Media Talk; Dwindling Corps Of Specialists On Aviation

stories.snippet: In the forefront of the television coverage of John F. Kennedy Jr.'s plane crash were examples of an increasingly rare breed of specialist reporters. NBC's aviation reporter, Robert Hager, was the first to report that the plane was missing on the...
stories.lead_paragraph: In the forefront of the television coverage of John F. Kennedy Jr.'s plane crash were examples of an increasingly rare breed of specialist reporters. NBC's aviation reporter, Robert Hager, was the first to report that the plane was missing on the morning of July 17. And his counterpart at CBS, Bob Orr, was the first to report the details of the radar track that indicated Mr. Kennedy had turned out to sea, possibly because Mr. Kennedy was disoriented, before he lost control of his plane. These aviation reporters are among the few remaining members of what was once a much larger corps of journalists specializing in coverage of air and space travel.

stories.snippet: TOULOUSE, the city of ancient pink-brick churches and stately homes on the Garonne River in southwestern France, may be noted for foie gras, but it is just as proud to be the aerospace capital of Europe.     The first regularly scheduled airline...
stories.lead_paragraph: TOULOUSE, the city of ancient pink-brick churches and stately homes on the Garonne River in southwestern France, may be noted for foie gras, but it is just as proud to be the aerospace capital of Europe. The first regularly scheduled airline flights in France took off from the Toulouse airport in the 1920's, and now long-range passenger planes of the Airbus consortium, Boeing's most important rivals in world markets, are assembled in a vast hangar in the suburb of Colomiers; the National Center for Space Research has been centered in Toulouse for 30 years.

stories.lead_paragraph: For the first time, a space shuttle landed in New York City. Not under its own power, though, because it never had any power of its own. The shuttle that arrived at Kennedy International Airport on Friday after swanning over the metropolitan area for about an hour was the Enterprise, which was the prototype for the shuttles that rocketed into space.

Dailey, a top official at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, has been named the new director of the National Air and Space Museum, the Smithsonian Institution said today. headline.main: Panel Upset by New Delay In Russian Space Module

stories.snippet: After years of delay and cost overruns on the proposed international space station, the Clinton Administration came into office four years ago vowing to put the project on a strict schedule and keep it there, no matter what.    Eager to help the...
stories.lead_paragraph: After years of delay and cost overruns on the proposed international space station, the Clinton Administration came into office four years ago vowing to put the project on a strict schedule and keep it there, no matter what. Eager to help the Russians after the cold war, the Administration brokered a deal in 1993 to have them join the international station team. And it set a firm date -- November 1997 -- to get the effort off the ground and start assembling the station in space.

The shuttle and its crew of seven astronauts, including three who will be dropped off for a five-month stay on the orbiting station, are to blast off from the Kennedy Space Center on Thursday at 7:41 p.m.

headline.kicker: GLENN RETURNS TO SPACE: THE PRESIDENT
headline.main: Clinton Praises Launching And Gains of Space Program

stories.snippet: Hitching a rhetorical ride on John Glenn's inspiring voyage into space, President Clinton today bid the 77-year-old Senator a safe journey and extolled the earthbound benefits of America's space program.    The President declared today's launching of...
stories.lead_paragraph: Hitching a rhetorical ride on John Glenn's inspiring voyage into space, President Clinton today bid the 77-year-old Senator a safe journey and extolled the earthbound benefits of America's space program. The President declared today's launching of the space shuttle Discovery ''a great day for America, a great day for our senior citizens.'' He said he was ''absolutely thrilled'' by the spectacle of the liftoff -- the first attended by an American President since 1969 -- and described himself as ''like a kid at his first Christmas.''

stories.lead_paragraph: NASA officials decided today to delay launching the space shuttle Endeavour until next week to allow astronauts aboard the International Space Station to tackle docking problems with a Russian cargo ship before the shuttle arrives. Endeavour and its crew of seven are now set to blast off for the station at 5:45 p.m. Tuesday, a day after a pair of Russian astronauts aboard the station take a space walk to the Progress cargo craft to remove debris that has prevented a firm docking.

stories.abstract: NASA officials again postpone launching of space shuttle Atlantis as they continue to discuss how to deal with fuel sensor problem (M)

headline.main: NASA Delays Shuttle Launching Again

stories.snippet: NASA officials on Friday again postponed the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis as they continued to discuss how to deal with a fuel sensor problem.
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA officials on Friday again postponed the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis as they continued to discuss how to deal with a fuel sensor problem. The flight, scheduled for Thursday and later pushed to Saturday, is now set for a Sunday liftoff at 3:21 p.m., officials said. But a Sunday launching is not guaranteed, as mission officials plan to meet again Saturday to discuss options that may mean further delays, N. Wayne Hale, the shuttle program director, said Friday night. Mr. Hale called the fuel sensor system ''suspect'' and said thinking is still ''evolving.''

stories.abstract: NASA officials say that launching of space shuttle Atlantis is being delayed again until June in order to repair hail damage on craft's fuel tank; delicate foam at top of tank suffered thousands of dents when shuttle was on launching pad during February hailstorm; decision to delay launch again casts doubt on NASA's plans for four shuttle missions in 2007, down from five missions first announced (M)

headline.main: NASA Delays Shuttle Launching Until June to Fix Hail Damage

stories.snippet: The delicate foam at the top of a 15-story-tall external fuel tank suffered thousands of dings in a hailstorm in February.
stories.lead_paragraph: The much-delayed launching of the space shuttle Atlantis is being pushed back again into June as NASA struggles to repair thousands of gouges on the craft's hail-pocked fuel tank, officials said yesterday. The mission was to begin in mid-March, and the shuttle had already been rolled to the launching pad in February when the hailstorm occurred. Much of the shuttle is protected by a gantry that is moved away before launching, but the 15-story-tall external fuel tank, with its distinctive coating of orange insulating foam, pokes out well beyond the top of the structure.

stories.lead_paragraph: NASA on Sunday delayed the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis until at least Jan. 2 to give engineers time to diagnose and fix its balky fuel tank sensors. The flight, originally scheduled for Thursday and then rescheduled for Sunday, was given its latest postponement when one of four critical sensors in the liquid hydrogen section of the external tank malfunctioned during early morning fueling.

The oxygen is part of the supply the astronauts breathe during launch and landing, both inside the suits and inside the cabin, space officials said.

headline.main: A Milestone In Space Flight Is Postponed

stories.snippet: A last-minute alarm forced NASA to halt today's launching of the space shuttle Endeavour, on a mission to start assembling the international space station. Another attempt for Endeavour and its crew of six astronauts is scheduled for Friday at 3:36...
stories.lead_paragraph: A last-minute alarm forced NASA to halt today's launching of the space shuttle Endeavour, on a mission to start assembling the international space station. Another attempt for Endeavour and its crew of six astronauts is scheduled for Friday at 3:36 A.M. This was the first time in three years, and 19 flights, that a shuttle countdown had been stopped after the spaceship was fueled and the crew aboard the craft and ready to go. The uncommon delay prompted frowns and furrowed brows here, although officials stressed that it was entirely warranted.

stories.lead_paragraph: Difficulty testing a new valve prompted another delay today in the launching of the space shuttle Endeavour on a mission to the International Space Station. Originally set to take off last Thursday, the shuttle and a crew of seven astronauts are now scheduled to blast off between 4 p.m. and 8 p.m. on Wednesday. For security reasons, the time will not be announced until 24 hours before the launching.

stories.abstract: NASA postpones launching of Space Infrared Telescope Facility, or Sirtf, because of defective solid-fuel booster motor (S)

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: Washington: Space Telescope Delay

stories.snippet: Because of problems with a rocket, NASA postponed the launching of an infrared telescope that is to be the last of its so-called Great Observatories, joining the Hubble Space Telescope and the Chandra X-Ray Telescope. The flight of the Space Infrared...
stories.lead_paragraph: Because of problems with a rocket, NASA postponed the launching of an infrared telescope that is to be the last of its so-called Great Observatories, joining the Hubble Space Telescope and the Chandra X-Ray Telescope. The flight of the Space Infrared Telescope Facility, or Sirtf, will occur no earlier than mid-August, the agency announced. One of nine solid-fuel booster motors attached to the Boeing Delta II rocket must be replaced because of defects. To avoid interfering with the launching of two Mars ground rover spacecraft, scheduled for June 7 and June 25, the agency has moved the Sirtf mission to late summer. Warren E. Leary (NYT)

stories.snippet: Asian elephants as adept biochemists, desert locusts, undersea eavesdroppers and more.
stories.lead_paragraph: No Flies on These Locusts The desert locust, Schistocerca gregaria, is infamous for its ability to swarm in huge numbers, travel long distances and wipe out crops along the way. But S. gregaria's destruction is limited to the Middle East, Africa and western Asia; it is the only locust found in the Old World. The other 50-odd species in the genus are found in the Americas. Biologists have long wondered how this separation happened. Because the desert locust, in particular, is such a long-distance traveler, some scientists think the New World locusts must be descended from desert locusts that crossed the Atlantic ages ago. But others say S. gregaria is so closely related to a group of American locusts that it probably originated in the New World, a single lineage having crossed the ocean fairly recently.

stories.lead_paragraph: Studies conducted by NASA over the last four years concluded that damage to the brittle, heat-shedding material on the leading edge of the space shuttle Columbia's wings posed one of the highest risks of a catastrophic accident. The studies focused largely on the tremendous damage that could be caused in the unlikely event that a tiny meteoroid or other bit of orbital debris hit the leading edge of a wing, which is made of a lightweight material called reinforced carbon-carbon. That is still one of the theories about what might have happened to the Columbia eight days ago.

headline.main: Our Best Spies Are In Space

stories.snippet: Though the two events seem unconnected, the tragic bombing of the American embassies in East Africa last week was in some ways related to the explosion a few days later of a Titan 4A rocket shortly after launching from Cape Canaveral, Fla. One was...
stories.lead_paragraph: Though the two events seem unconnected, the tragic bombing of the American embassies in East Africa last week was in some ways related to the explosion a few days later of a Titan 4A rocket shortly after launching from Cape Canaveral, Fla. One was caused by terrorists, and the other was a blow to a system intended to help ferret them out. The payload lost in the rocket explosion was a Mercury-class signals intelligence satellite, one of a series of spacecraft used by the supersecret National Security Agency to eavesdrop on everything from cellular telephone calls to global data transmissions (like faxes and computer transfers) to nuclear missile tests. The satellite was scheduled to have been placed in orbit above Africa, where it would also have eavesdropped on the Mideast. The loss may eventually hamper the Government's ability to track down those responsible for the embassy bombing as well as prevent similar acts in the future.

stories.snippet: How ungulates affect an ecosystem, how larval fish find their way home, a new telescope and more.
stories.lead_paragraph: Smells Like Home You can go home again, but if you're a just-hatched reef fish, it's not that easy. Larval fish often lead a peripatetic existence, drifting with ocean currents until they are widely dispersed, far from the reef of their birth. If all larvae of one species were scattered over a wide area -- creating, in effect, a giant mixing bowl -- genetic sameness would be the expected result. But there are enough differences between fish on different reefs to indicate that populations do stay separate, and many larvae do make it home again.

stories.lead_paragraph: Urban Ants Take the Heat There may be some remaining pockets of resistance to the idea that the planet is heating up, but no one can deny that cities have been growing warmer. Urban areas can be as much as 20 degrees hotter than nearby rural ones, a result, among other factors, of all that concrete and asphalt pumping out heat as sunlight hits it. Sweltering temperatures affect humans, of course, but are there other biological consequences of what are known as urban heat islands? A study by Michael J. Angilletta Jr. of Indiana State University and colleagues shows that there is. Urban ants, they report in PLoS Biology, can stand the heat better than those from out of town.

stories.lead_paragraph: Donna L. Shirley used to run NASA's Mars exploration program. Now she is doing something even more far out. Ms. Shirley, who retired from NASA in 1998, is director of the new Science Fiction Museum and Hall of Fame here, set to open on June 18. Instead of pointing space probes at the next rock out from the Sun, she now oversees exhibits exploring the universe of ''What if?,'' from genetic engineering to aliens to parallel worlds.

stories.lead_paragraph: Better End of Life for Polystyrene From an environmental standpoint, polystyrene is far from a dream product. Close to 80 percent of the three million tons of the petrochemical plastic in the United States each year (much of it as foam coffee cups and takeout food containers) ends up in landfills, where it doesn't break down over time. Recycling is not an economical option. Scientists have long sought ways to make polystyrene more environmentally friendly. Researchers at the National University of Ireland and Hamburg University in Germany have come up with a new approach. If polystyrene itself is not biodegradable, they ask, can it be converted into something that is?

stories.lead_paragraph: Nocturnal, Without the Night Light is one of the great forces of nature, the cycle of daytime and nighttime affecting the activities of countless plants and animals. Take the oriental army worm caterpillar, Mythimna separata, which infests corn plants. During the day, the bugs hide underground or tucked behind a leaf where it joins the stalk. At night, they emerge and munch away on the plant. So the army worm is nocturnal, and it's a good thing, too: that helps it avoid being infested by a parasitic wasp, Cotesia kariyai, that is attracted to corn plants during the day. There's only one problem. Researchers in Japan have discovered what makes the army worm nocturnal, and it's not light -- at least not directly.

headline.main: A 'Little' Museum With Big Clout

stories.snippet: We were quite amused and perplexed to see the Science Museum of Long Island referred to as a ''pocket museum'' in the June 20 article, ''Inventing a Science and Technology Museum.'' Over the years, the museum has attracted luminaries such as the...
stories.section_name: Technology; Science; New York and Region; Opinion
stories.lead_paragraph: We were quite amused and perplexed to see the Science Museum of Long Island referred to as a ''pocket museum'' in the June 20 article, ''Inventing a Science and Technology Museum.'' Over the years, the museum has attracted luminaries such as the Nobel Prize winner Frank Oppenheimer, the astronaut Scott Carpenter, the Russian cosmonaut Viktor Savinhykh, the oceanographer Sylvia Earle, the environmentalist Jim Fowler and the Antarctic specialist Rita Mathews. These and other top scientists have visited the museum and contributed to our courses, workshops and lectures because they felt our hands-on science programs for children were substantive and dynamic. Our director, Dr. John Loret, is a marine biologist who has participated in expeditions with Thor Heyerdahl. Dr. Loret, a former Explorer's Club president, has led more than 35 global science expeditions himself. You don't draw a stellar caliber of people like the ones mentioned to collaborate with or direct an organization when you're merely a ''pocket museum.'' Last year alone, more than 92,000 schoolchildren and adults participated in the museums programs and activities. Our courses run the gamut in variety. In our paleontology program, students actually unearth bones, map them out, then create protective jackets around them just as paleontologists do, or they may build an advanced rocket and launch it in our rocketry program. Others might collect and maintain live specimens from the sea and perform salinity experiments on a boat that goes out in the Long Island Sound. As for our widely popular travel expeditions for adults, CNN filmed our 1998 trip to Easter Island because of the El Nino implications in the Pacific Ocean that we investigated. The program, ''Forging Ahead: Easter Island Expedition,'' aired several times nationally and itnernationally last fall. The History Channel also aired the program this June.

stories.lead_paragraph: Oil's Lasting Presence The 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill, which poured 11 million gallons of crude oil into the waters of southern Alaska, was one of the worst environmental catastrophes ever. Billions of dollars were spent cleaning up Prince William Sound and other parts of the Gulf of Alaska. Yet in some ways the spill has never gone away. Some of the oil that coated the shoreline in the first weeks after the disaster percolated a foot or so down into sediments and remains there.

headline.main: Mapping Where Lightning Is Likely to Strike

stories.lead_paragraph: Drawing on accumulated data from satellite sensors, scientists have produced a new map of the world showing where and when lightning is most likely or least likely to strike. NASA scientists at the National Space Science and Technology Center in Huntsville, Ala., said this was the first comprehensive picture yet of pla netwide lightning activity by latitude, longitude and time of year. Before the monitoring by satellite detectors, the incidence and timing of lightning had been poorly sampled over oceans and in most low-population areas.

stories.snippet: For the future of human space exploration, NASA may turn to retro spacecraft designs.    The spacecraft that is to take astronauts back to the Moon, called the crew exploration vehicle, may turn out to be more than passingly reminiscent of the old...
stories.lead_paragraph: For the future of human space exploration, NASA may turn to retro spacecraft designs. The spacecraft that is to take astronauts back to the Moon, called the crew exploration vehicle, may turn out to be more than passingly reminiscent of the old Apollo spacecraft. NASA is not about to start rummaging about museums for leftover equipment to fulfill President Bush's mandate, but many outside experts expect the space agency to turn away from sleek, winged, reusable designs like the shuttle and return to the simple capsules that parachute back to Earth. Such designs, updated with modern electronics, would also help the agency stay within the modest budgets that Mr. Bush has set out for the Moon shot.

The full report is expected later this month.

stories.lead_paragraph: Ancient Amber A piece of amber that is, say, 25 million years old and contains a midge or a spider is one thing, but the amber being reported in the current issue of Nature is something else entirely. Described by Alexander R. Schmidt of the Natural History Museum at Humboldt University-Berlin and colleagues, the droplets of amber are 220 million years old. Rather than containing an insect or two, they contain bacteria, fungi, algae and protozoans -- a who's who of micro-organisms from the Triassic.

stories.snippet: THE robot known as Rhode Warrior was due back on the playing field in less than 20 minutes, and the cramped pit area in which it was parked was a hive of urgent activity.    Students from Middletown High School in Middletown, R.I., clustered to...
stories.lead_paragraph: THE robot known as Rhode Warrior was due back on the playing field in less than 20 minutes, and the cramped pit area in which it was parked was a hive of urgent activity. Students from Middletown High School in Middletown, R.I., clustered to discuss refinements in their strategy for the next match. In one corner, a student's mother worked on a sewing machine, mending one of the two conveyor belts that allow the Rhode Warrior, which looks like a rolling phone booth, to vacuum up soccer balls from the field. David Ferreira, a Middletown High alumnus who returns each year to assist the team, knelt to reattach a small aluminum plate that helps guide balls between the conveyor belts and into the robot.

stories.lead_paragraph: Shaken and Sorted On the Surface Of an Asteroid While it has been rolling its way through the solar system, the near-Earth asteroid Itokawa has been shaking, too. That's the conclusion of Hideaki Miyamoto of the University of Tokyo and colleagues, who see evidence of vibrations at work in images of the asteroid's gravel-strewn surface. The close-up images were taken in 2005 by the Japanese spacecraft Hayabusa as it hovered over and touched down briefly on the 1,000-foot asteroid in a sample-return mission. The images show the kinds of gravel migration, alignment and sorting that can be caused by shaking, and are often seen on Earth along riverbeds or after landslides.

stories.lead_paragraph: The Moon Sighs The moon, planetary scientists will tell you, is deader than a door nail. Sure, there is a constant stream of small moonquakes, but volcanically speaking the moon stopped being active more than 3 billion years ago. Since then it's been pretty much dead on the inside. Maybe not totally, according to research by Peter H. Schultz of Brown University and colleagues. In the current issue of Nature, they describe a lunar feature that they say shows signs of a relatively recent release of gas from deep beneath the surface.

stories.lead_paragraph: Ring Around the Planets For roughly 300 years, Saturn was the only planet known to have rings. But since the 1970's, rings have been discovered around Jupiter, Uranus and Neptune. The most recent discovery, of two faint bands of dust outside the main ring system of Uranus, was made using the Hubble Space Telescope in 2003. Imke de Pater of the University of California, Berkeley, and colleagues have studied these newest rings and found that the outermost one holds a surprise. It's one of only two blue rings in the solar system.

stories.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Thomas L. Friedman displays an uncharacteristically narrow view of innovation when he denigrates the Mars component of the president's vision for space exploration (column, April 22). Given the vulnerability of Earth to extraterrestrial hazards and the potential of space-based resources to improve our quality of life, failing to invest in this area particularly when others like the Chinese are doing so seems terribly myopic.
