headline.main: Oldest Bacteria Fossils? Or Are They Merely Tiny Rock Flaws?

stories.snippet: If a bacterium dies in the mud and fossilizes into rock, how would anyone know? How would it differ from a rock that had never been alive? Unlike a dinosaur or a plant, a fossil of a bacterium can resemble a simple bubble or a mineral crystal -- or...
stories.lead_paragraph: If a bacterium dies in the mud and fossilizes into rock, how would anyone know? How would it differ from a rock that had never been alive? Unlike a dinosaur or a plant, a fossil of a bacterium can resemble a simple bubble or a mineral crystal -- or vice versa. That is a debate that followed the extraordinary claim in 1996 that a meteorite found in Antarctica contained the fossilized remains of Martian microbes. Other researchers have concluded the supposed fossils are merely mineral deposits with a passing resemblance to bacteria.

stories.abstract: Two groups of astronomers release images that are believed to be first pictures of planets orbiting stars other than sun; team led by Dr Christian Marois of Herzberg Institute of Astrophysics has recorded three planets circling star known as HR 8799 that is 130 light-years from Earth in constellation Pegasus; team led by Dr Paul Kalas of University of California, Berkeley, found planet orbiting star Fomalhaut that is 25 light-years away in constellation Piscis Austrinus; experts say achievement will open door to new investigations and discoveries of what planets are and how they came to be formed; findings are published in online version of journal Science; photos; chart (M)

headline.main: Now in Sight: Far-Off Planets

stories.snippet: Images released on Thursday are believed to be the first pictures of planets orbiting stars other than the sun.
stories.lead_paragraph: A little more of the universe has been pried out of the shadows. Two groups of astronomers have taken the first pictures of what they say -- and other astronomers agree -- are most likely planets going around other stars. The achievement, the result of years of effort on improved observational techniques and better data analysis, presages more such discoveries, the experts said, and will open the door to new investigations and discoveries of what planets are and how they came to be formed.

stories.abstract: Generations of physicists since Albert Einstein have been hoping to discover so called Theory of Everything, which would tie together seemingly unrelated details of universe; during past 20 years hope of universal answer has been explored through string theory, which professes to unite various forces of nature in single mathematical framework; concept is akin to vibration created when applying tension to guitar string; group of Stanford University scientists, led by Dr Leonard Sussking, has generated cosmic landscape, in which energy mapped in 4-dimensional space time allows for mountain peaks of dark energy and valleys containing universes, some of which could be suitable for life; concept of cosmological constant and its predicted and eventual decay is outlined; drawing; photos; (L)

headline.main: One Cosmic Question, Too Many Answers

stories.snippet: Call it the theory of anything.    Einstein once wondered aloud whether ''God had any choice'' in creating the universe. It was his fondest hope that the answer was no.
stories.lead_paragraph: Call it the theory of anything. Einstein once wondered aloud whether ''God had any choice'' in creating the universe. It was his fondest hope that the answer was no.

stories.abstract: Team of astronomers, led by Dr S George Djorgovski from California Institute of Technology, announces discovery of 'cosmic renaissance,' epoch in which starlight first began streaming freely through universe; new finding appears to strengthen scientific case that after decades of searching, telescopes on Earth have finally looked back far enough into time to glimpse epoch in which stars and galaxies first formed; latest observations amount to snapshot of universe just over hundred million years later (M)

headline.main: Astronomers See Evidence Of First Light In Universe

stories.snippet: A team of astronomers announced yesterday that it had found what it called the cosmic renaissance, the epoch in which starlight first began streaming freely through the universe.    The announcement was made a few days after another team reported...
stories.lead_paragraph: A team of astronomers announced yesterday that it had found what it called the cosmic renaissance, the epoch in which starlight first began streaming freely through the universe. The announcement was made a few days after another team reported that it had discovered the cosmic dark ages, a time before stars and galaxies began shining.

stories.abstract: Research team led by Dr Peter Doran of University of Illinois at Chicago, reporting in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, finds that water 60 feet below surface of Antarctica's Lake Vida, seven times as salty as seawater, does not freeze, even at 14 degrees; finds and revives bacteria in lake's frozen ice cover; research may yield clues to what life was like on Mars several billion years ago and how life on Earth survived during glacial periods; photos; map (M)

headline.main: From Lake's Depths, Frozen Bacteria Are Brought Back to Life

stories.snippet: Each summer, the top layer of ice on Lake Vida in Antarctica melts, releasing bacteria that revive, thrive and multiply for a few weeks before temperatures dip and they freeze back into suspended animation.    Farther down, deep in Lake Vida's...
stories.lead_paragraph: Each summer, the top layer of ice on Lake Vida in Antarctica melts, releasing bacteria that revive, thrive and multiply for a few weeks before temperatures dip and they freeze back into suspended animation. Farther down, deep in Lake Vida's 60-foot-thick ice cover, scientists have found bacteria that froze about the time that Rome was founded, 2,800 years ago -- and successfully brought them back to life.

stories.abstract: Scientists release clearest pictures yet taken of infant universe, before stars and galaxies formed and when space was filled with hot turbulent gases; images are from balloon-borne telescope named Boomerang, collected by multinational collaboration led by Dr Andrew Lange and Dr Paolo de Bernardis; results are published in journal Nature; scientists seeking to confirm so-called Big Bang theory on birth of universe have focused on ripples, or variations, in temperature of primordial gas; size of ripples obverved by Boomerang experiment indicates universe contains right amount of matter and energy to make space 'flat,' meaning parallel rays of light never cross or diverge, just as predicted by reigning 'infation' theory of how Big Bang started; some cosmologist are surprised that new images do not reveal fainter ripples of smaller size in sky; photo (M)

headline.main: Clearest Picture of Infant Universe Sees It All and Questions It, Too

stories.snippet: Scientists yesterday released the clearest pictures yet taken of the infant universe, before stars and galaxies had formed and when space was filled with hot turbulent gases. The images confirm one major prediction of the leading theory of the...
stories.lead_paragraph: Scientists yesterday released the clearest pictures yet taken of the infant universe, before stars and galaxies had formed and when space was filled with hot turbulent gases. The images confirm one major prediction of the leading theory of the explosive birth of the universe, but they failed to reveal another crucial feature that scientists had hoped would buttress that theory. It is uncertain how sharp a revision, if any, will be needed to account for the new evidence.

stories.abstract: Team led by Dr Luann Becker of University of California says that geological formation deep in ocean off northwest coast of Australia is 125-mile-wide crater that was formed by devastating meteor that struck Earth 251 million years ago, causing largest mass extinction in planet's history; map; Becker says Bedout depression has jumbled and melted minerals in rocks that could only have formed in violent upheaval, not as result of volcano, as long believed; 90-95 percent of ocean species and at least half of backboned species on land died out quickly at end of Permian geological period and start of Triassic (M)

headline.main: Scientists Say Crater Is Result of a Killer Meteor

stories.snippet: A buried geological formation off the northwest coast of Australia, long thought to be remnants of an old volcano, is actually a 125-mile-wide crater formed by a devastating meteor strike 251 million years ago, scientists asserted yesterday. It was...
stories.lead_paragraph: A buried geological formation off the northwest coast of Australia, long thought to be remnants of an old volcano, is actually a 125-mile-wide crater formed by a devastating meteor strike 251 million years ago, scientists asserted yesterday. It was that meteor, they went on, that caused the largest mass extinction in the Earth's history. Researchers led by Dr. Luann Becker, a geologist at the University of California, Santa Barbara, said seismic and gravitational measurements showed that the depression, called Bedout (be-DOO), had the general shape of a crater. More significant, they said, jumbled and melted minerals in the rocks could have formed only in the violent upheaval of a meteor's hitting the Earth, not from cooling lava.

stories.abstract: scientists from more than 12 nations continue preparations for viewing of eclipse in Oaxaca, Mex, area; illus; they say they selected region because of favorable weather outlook; Harvard Univ scientists, led by Dr D H Menzel, establish hq in Miahuatlan; scientists from Kitt Peak Natl, High Altitude and USAF Sacramento Peak Observatories are encamped near Quiechapa; Kitt Peak scientists plan to photograph sun's corona and chromosphere; hope to discover why corona is so much hotter than chromosphere; observation can be made only during few seconds at start and end of totality, when sun's blinding light is cut off and chromosphere is still visible; Harvard team will point spectrograph, designed by Dr J G Baker, and TV cameras at corona to record variation in polarization from inner to outer parts; many astronomers feel polarization measurements may be key to discriminating between various glows; 3 other US teams will seek to assess role of magnetic fields in forming streamers that sometimes reach out millions of mi from sun; USSR and Penna State Univ radio astronomers say they are pleased sun is near peak of 11-yr activity cycle; hope to identify what emissions are coming from specific sunspots; NASA, Lockheed Electronics and Goodyear scientists will try to record effects of solar eruption if one occurs during eclipse; Dowling Coll and MIT students will try to detect comets near sun that are too small to be observed at any other time; local residents are very curious about experiments; hold fiestas to celebrate event; schematic diagrams show how moon will move between earth and sun, causing total eclipse along E Coast, US, and partial eclipse over rest of continental US; map shows path of totality (Sullivan rept)

headline.main: In Ancient Mexican Setting, Scientists Gird for Eclipse; In Ancient Mexican Setting, Scientists Await Eclipse

stories.snippet: OAXACA, Mexico, March 5 From the Pacific shore of Mexico deep into the mountains, valleys that until now knew no sound other than the braying of burros, the bark of sheepdogs and other natural noises, are echoing to the harsh roar of portable...

byline.original: By WALTER SULLIVAN Special to The New York Times

stories.lead_paragraph: OAXACA, Mexico, March 5 From the Pacific shore of Mexico deep into the mountains, valleys that until now knew no sound other than the braying of burros, the bark of sheepdogs and other natural noises, are echoing to the harsh roar of portable electric generators.

stories.abstract: Round pebbles discovered by Mars rover Opportunity while exploring Meridiani Planum are found to be similar to spherical pebbles in southern Utah; team of researchers from University of Utah, National Institute of Aerospace Technology, Madrid, and G d'Annunzio University, Italy, holds that Utah pebbles, formed 25 million years ago, suggest that Meridiani Planum region was once wet environment suitable for life; study, led by Dr Marjorie A Chan, University of Utah geology and geophysics department chair, is published in journal Nature; other similar earth environments that may help explain Martian landscape described; photos (M)

headline.main: Mars' Round, Smooth Stones Have a Counterpart in Utah

stories.snippet: Among the most intriguing discoveries from Mars this year are the almost perfectly round pebbles, nicknamed blueberries, that the rover Opportunity found strewn about at its landing site.    Similar spherical pebbles, it turns out, are also strewn...
stories.lead_paragraph: Among the most intriguing discoveries from Mars this year are the almost perfectly round pebbles, nicknamed blueberries, that the rover Opportunity found strewn about at its landing site. Similar spherical pebbles, it turns out, are also strewn around southern Utah.

stories.abstract: Waste recycling, once urged as answer to pollution, is now winning greater support because of econ reasons; cost of virgin materials and costs of alternative waste disposal methods have soared in recent yrs; 134-million tons of trash produced yrly in US contain estimated 11.3-million tons of iron and steel, 860,000 tons of aluminum, 430,000 tons of other metals (principally copper), over 13-million tons of glass, over 60-million tons of paper and burnable organic materials containing energy equivalent of 150-million bbls of crude oil; processes for making refined metals for virgin ores often require much more energy than would recycling of scrap metal; tech for recycling is available; recycling drive, which has its own trade assn and trade journal, Resource Recovery & Energy Rev, is led by Dr Glenn Seaborg, formerly of AEC, Dr Rocco Petrone (Natl Center for Resource Recovery) and Neil Armstrong; chief obstacles to 'recycled society' are US freight rates that favor virgin iron ore over scrap, and lack of experience in field on part of pol leaders; cos developing recycling equipment noted; St Louis success with recycling discussed; Dr Jack Milgrom (Arthur D Little), Herschel Cutler (Inst of Scrap Iron and Steel), and Dr Helmut W Schultz (Columbia Univ) comment; illus; chart (L)

headline.main: COINING TRASH GOLD STRIKE ON THE DISASSEMBLY LINE; A new technology for recycling wastes is coming into its own--and the ecologists have an unexpected, even invincible ally. Gold strike

stories.snippet: Waste recycling, once urged as answer to pollution, is now winning greater support because of econ reasons; cost of virgin materials and costs of alternative waste disposal methods have soared in recent yrs; 134-million tons of trash produced yrly in...

stories.abstract: Astronomers discover biggest, brightest star they have ever seen; its existence defies theories of how stars form; LBV 1806-20 is 5 million to 40 million times as bright, 150 times as massive and 200 times as wide as Sun; findings are reported at meeting of American Astronomical Sociey in Atlanta; research was led by Dr Steven Eikenberry of University of Florida; drawings (M)

headline.main: Astronomers Call LBV 1806-20 the Superstar That Outshines All

stories.snippet: Astronomers have spotted what they believe is the biggest, brightest star they have ever seen -- and indeed bigger than can be explained by the usual theories of how stars form.    The star, LBV 1806-20, is 5 million to 40 million times as bright as...
stories.lead_paragraph: Astronomers have spotted what they believe is the biggest, brightest star they have ever seen -- and indeed bigger than can be explained by the usual theories of how stars form. The star, LBV 1806-20, is 5 million to 40 million times as bright as the Sun, at least 150 times as massive and at least 200 times as wide, astronomers reported on Monday at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society here.

stories.abstract: Concern that asteroid discovered in Dec might closely approach Earth in 2028 spurred astronomers to frantically search files for old photos of asteroid; astronomers at Jet Propulsion Laboratory, led by Drs Donald K Yeomans and Paul W Chodas and at Central Bureau for Astronomical Telegrams, led by Dr Brian G Marsden, measured asteroid's movement to conclude it posed no threat to Earth; based findings on photos taken at laboratory by Dr Eleanor Francis Helin (M)

headline.main: Frantic Hunt Found Photos That Deflated Asteroid Fears

stories.snippet: It pays to save old photographs.    On Wednesday astronomers around the world began a frantic search of their files of celestial pictures, looking for a tiny smudge of light revealing the path of an object that might one day blast Earth. They had...
stories.lead_paragraph: It pays to save old photographs. On Wednesday astronomers around the world began a frantic search of their files of celestial pictures, looking for a tiny smudge of light revealing the path of an object that might one day blast Earth. They had learned that an asteroid discovered in December was spiraling toward a close approach to Earth in 2028, and there was an urgent need to predict whether it would be a hit or a miss.

stories.abstract: Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics researchers, led by Dr Andreas Zezas and working at Chandra X-ray Observatory, find remnants of cosmic collision 100 million light-years away; photos (S)

headline.main: Galaxy Crash And Fallout

stories.snippet: Astronomers announced yesterday that they had found the remains of an ancient cosmic car wreck.     Using the Chandra X-ray Observatory to probe beneath the pearly placid surface of a galaxy by the name of NGC 4261, 100 million light-years from here,...
stories.lead_paragraph: Astronomers announced yesterday that they had found the remains of an ancient cosmic car wreck. Using the Chandra X-ray Observatory to probe beneath the pearly placid surface of a galaxy by the name of NGC 4261, 100 million light-years from here, astronomers from the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics discovered a trail of intense X-ray hot spots strung 50,000 light-years across space ''like beads on a necklace,'' in the words of Dr. Andreas Zezas.

stories.abstract: Astronomers have detected faint light from small group of stars so far away that they could be 'baby galaxy,' early universe just beginning its tranformation from virtual emptiness; young galaxy is presumably one of long-sought 'building blocks' out of which mature galaxies are assembled; drawing; even more exciting to scientists is means of discovery, gravitational lensing: massive cluster of galaxies in foreground magnifies passing light from more distant objects, making them visible to powerful telescopes; research is reported by American and European astronomers led by Dr Richard Ellis at Cal Tech (M)

headline.main: Cosmic 'Building Block' Is Detected

stories.snippet: Astronomers have detected the faint light from a small congregation of stars so far away that they think it is a vision of the early universe at the beginning of its transformation from virtual emptiness to a place of arching galaxies on a majestic...
stories.lead_paragraph: Astronomers have detected the faint light from a small congregation of stars so far away that they think it is a vision of the early universe at the beginning of its transformation from virtual emptiness to a place of arching galaxies on a majestic scale. The light was observed through a technique that scientists hope will finally give them systematic access to one of the most poorly understood epochs in cosmic history, the first half-billion years or so of the universe's existence.

stories.abstract: Team of astronomers, led by Dr Ben R Oppenheimer, views star Omega Herculis using AEOS, United States Air Force telescope in Haleakala, Hawaii, and experimental coronagraphy; rain had hampered group during earlier attempts to begin research on exoplanetary objects; photo (S)

headline.main: Clear Skies, Stars in View

stories.snippet: Earlier this month, after it finally stopped raining, Dr. Ben R. Oppenheimer and his colleagues could be found back in Haleakala, Hawaii, training a high-resolution United States Air Force telescope equipped with an experimental coronagraph on the...
stories.lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, after it finally stopped raining, Dr. Ben R. Oppenheimer and his colleagues could be found back in Haleakala, Hawaii, training a high-resolution United States Air Force telescope equipped with an experimental coronagraph on the star Omega Herculis, also known as Cujam. They recorded an image of the star and a dim companion star only a thousandth as bright.

stories.abstract: Article on research being conducted at Svartisen Glacier in Norway, where team of glaciologists led by Dr Neal Iverson are studying glacial movement; mile-long laboratory and research tunnel, built and maintained by Norwegian Water Resources and Energy Directorate, described; data suggest that simple friction, working like ice cube on sand paper, plays major role in how glaciers move; photos; diagrams; map (M)

headline.main: What Makes a Glacier Go? Scientists Look Inside

stories.snippet: To find the Aladdin's Cave of modern glaciology, follow these simple directions:    Fly to Bodo, in the Arctic Circle. Drive three hours south to an empty jetty and wait for the boatman. Cross the fjord, walk a mile on a gravel road toward the...
stories.lead_paragraph: To find the Aladdin's Cave of modern glaciology, follow these simple directions: Fly to Bodo, in the Arctic Circle. Drive three hours south to an empty jetty and wait for the boatman. Cross the fjord, walk a mile on a gravel road toward the glacier, which looks like a huge cracked dragon's tongue of cornflower-blue ice.

stories.abstract: Team of American astronomers led by Dr Jane Luu report discovering icy, 300-mile-wide mini-planet beyond Neptune, article in journal Nature; believe planet, 1966 TL66, may be part of hidden belt of rubble left over from creation of solar system, pieces of which occasionally crash into Jupiter; estimate 6,400 similar objects might be orbiting in dark fringes of solar system (M)

headline.main: Mini-Planet at Solar System's Edge Might Be Part of Rubble Belt

stories.snippet: An icy, 300-mile-wide mini-planet has been found beyond Neptune on the dark fringes of the solar system, and scientists believe it may be part of a hidden belt of millions of bits of speeding rubble left over from the creation of the solar system,...
stories.lead_paragraph: An icy, 300-mile-wide mini-planet has been found beyond Neptune on the dark fringes of the solar system, and scientists believe it may be part of a hidden belt of millions of bits of speeding rubble left over from the creation of the solar system, pieces of which occasionally crash into Jupiter. In 1994, a celestial enigma known as comet Shoemaker-Levy 9, which might be from the hidden belt, plunged into Jupiter in a fiery death marked by bright flashes and fireballs the size of Earth.

stories.abstract: International team of astrophysicists discovers that basic laws of nature as understood today may be changing slightly as universe ages, surprising finding that could challenge fundamental assumptions about workings of cosmos; research team led by Dr John K Webb used Keck telescope in Hawaii, world's largest single telescope, to study behavior of metallic atoms in gas clouds as far away from Earth as 12 billion light years; observations revealed patters of light absorption that team could not explain without assuming change in a basic constant of nature, called fine structure constant, involving strength of attraction between electically charged particles; if confirmed, finding could mean that other constants, like speed of light, might also have changed over history of universe; could also add credence to unproven theory of physics called string theory, which predicts that extra dimensions exist in fabric of space; implications are so far-reaching that many scientists are expressing skepticism that results will stand test of time, and even researchers on project are being deliberately cautious in presenting findings; research will be published in Physical Review Letters, field's most prestigious journal; chart explains fine structure content (M)

headline.main: Anything Can Change, It Seems, Even an Immutable Law of Nature

stories.snippet: An international team of astrophysicists has discovered that the basic laws of nature as understood today may be changing slightly as the universe ages, a surprising finding that could rewrite physics textbooks and challenge fundamental assumptions...

byline.original: By JAMES GLANZ and DENNIS OVERBYE

stories.lead_paragraph: An international team of astrophysicists has discovered that the basic laws of nature as understood today may be changing slightly as the universe ages, a surprising finding that could rewrite physics textbooks and challenge fundamental assumptions about the workings of the cosmos. The researchers used the world's largest single telescope to study the behavior of metallic atoms in gas clouds as far away from Earth as 12 billion light years. The observations revealed patterns of light absorption that the team could not explain without assuming a change in a basic constant of nature involving the strength of the attraction between electrically charged particles.

stories.abstract: Two teams of astronomers are studying supernovas in spirited contest to determine whether the universe will continue to expand forever, reach a state of equilibrium or collapse into Big Crunch; teams, one led by Dr Saul Perlmutter that grew out of work at Lawrence Berkeley laboratory and another under Dr Brian Schmidt that is more loosely organized, share data and equipment, but competition has its share of ego and tensions, which stem from differences in their organization, background and temperament; both teams express confidence in their findings, but are looking for more evidence that what they are seeing--an accelerating expansion of the universe and something like the cosmological constant--is really there; photos; drawings (L)

headline.main: In the Light of Dying Stars, Astronomers See Intimations Of Cosmic Immortality

stories.snippet: HIGH on the mountain, above the clouds and under a crescent moon, one of the world's two most powerful telescopes was aimed at stars exploding halfway across the universe. The night was not going well. At one point fog had shut down operations, and...
stories.lead_paragraph: HIGH on the mountain, above the clouds and under a crescent moon, one of the world's two most powerful telescopes was aimed at stars exploding halfway across the universe. The night was not going well. At one point fog had shut down operations, and roiling winds sometimes blurred vision. An electronics glitch erased some precious data and cost time. Scientists were hunched before computer screens in a control room at the base of the mountain, anxiously waiting for an encouraging word from telescope operators up in the dome at Keck Observatory here. ''This is ulcer time,'' said Dr. Robert A. Knop, one of the astronomers, as he reached for another handful of corn chips. ''You get the feeling the universe is trying to prevent us from discovering the truth.''

stories.abstract: Group of international astronomers, who are led by Dr David Charbonneau of Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Dr Timothy Brown of National Center for Atmospheric Research and Dr Edward Dunham of Lowell Observatory and who established network of three small telescopes to look for new planets, have discovered Jupiter-size planet orbiting star in constellation Lyra; report on planet has been submitted to Astrophysical Journal Letters; group has small telescopes, which use wider field of observation and search for transitory blips in starlight to recognize planetary movement and help identify mass; photo (M)

headline.main: Spotted by a Very Small Telescope: A Very Large Planet

stories.snippet: It turns out you don't need a giant telescope to make a cosmic discovery.    Astronomers announced last week that they had found a Jupiter-size planet orbiting a star about 500 light-years from Earth in the constellation Lyra. In an age when cosmic...
stories.lead_paragraph: It turns out you don't need a giant telescope to make a cosmic discovery. Astronomers announced last week that they had found a Jupiter-size planet orbiting a star about 500 light-years from Earth in the constellation Lyra. In an age when cosmic investigations use telescopes hundreds of inches across, the planet was spotted with a telescope, in the Canary Islands, just four inches in diameter -- only slightly larger than the one Galileo first pointed at the heavens 400 years ago, and smaller than the backyard instruments used by many amateur astronomers.

stories.abstract: Two research teams carry out chemical and magnetic studies that may turn back challenge to finding that meteorite from Mars contains hints of past life there; separate teams led by Dr Joseph L Kirschvink of Caltech and Dr John W Valley of Wisconsin say Martian rock in question was never subjected to excessive heat that would have killed off residues of living organisms (S)

headline.main: Study Backs Idea That Meteorite Hints of Life on Mars

stories.snippet: New chemical and magnetic studies may have turned back a serious challenge to the idea that a meteorite from Mars contains hints of past life on that planet.    In August, scientists caused a sensation with the announcement of traces of possible...
stories.lead_paragraph: New chemical and magnetic studies may have turned back a serious challenge to the idea that a meteorite from Mars contains hints of past life on that planet. In August, scientists caused a sensation with the announcement of traces of possible early Martian life found in the potato-size rock. But others raised doubts, citing evidence that the rock in question had probably been exposed to temperatures as high as 660 to 1,200 degrees Fahrenheit, too high for it to have harbored living organisms.

stories.abstract: Astronomers led by Dr Wendy L Freedman calculate the expansion rate of universe is 70, plus or minus 7, meaning that a galaxy appears to be flying away at rate of 70 kilometers per second per megaparsec, or 160,000 miles per hour faster for every 3.26 million light-years away from Earth; figure, also known as Hubble constant, is based on eight years of measurements taken with Hubble Space Telescope and is indispensable for determining the age, size and fate of universe; would indicate that universe has been expanding for at least 12 billion years since theorized Big Bang and that depending on density of cosmic matter and possible existence of a mysterious form of vacuum energy, the age of universe could be closer to 13.5 billion or even 15 billion years (M)

headline.main: Hubble Telescope Yields Data for Recalculating Age of Universe

stories.snippet: After eight years of measurements by the Hubble Space Telescope, astronomers think they have finally established a reliable value to the expansion rate of the universe, the indispensable number required for determining the age, size and fate of the...
stories.lead_paragraph: After eight years of measurements by the Hubble Space Telescope, astronomers think they have finally established a reliable value to the expansion rate of the universe, the indispensable number required for determining the age, size and fate of the universe. It is a number that scientists have sought ever since 1929, when Edwin P. Hubble discovered that the galaxies are flying outward at velocities that increase with distance. Estimates of the expansion rate, also known as the Hubble constant, are fundamental to all theories of cosmic evolution. But they have fluctuated wildly between numbers that would put the age of the universe anywhere from 10 billion to 20 billion years.

stories.abstract: Researchers say age of dinosaurs, which ended with cataclysmic bang of meteor impact 65 million years ago, may also have begun with one; report first direct, though tentative, geological evidence of meteor impact 200 million years ago, coinciding with mass extinction that eliminated half of major groups of life and opened evolutionary door for relatively small group of dinosaurs to thrive and grow large; study, led by Dr Paul E Olsen, is reported in journal Science (M)

headline.main: Meteor May Have Started Dinosaur Era

stories.snippet: The age of dinosaurs, which ended with the cataclysmic bang of a meteor impact 65 million years ago, may also have begun with one.    Researchers report today in the journal Science the first direct, though tentative, geological evidence of a meteor...
stories.lead_paragraph: The age of dinosaurs, which ended with the cataclysmic bang of a meteor impact 65 million years ago, may also have begun with one. Researchers report today in the journal Science the first direct, though tentative, geological evidence of a meteor impact 200 million years ago, coinciding with a mass extinction that eliminated half of the major groups of life and opened the evolutionary door for what was then a relatively small group of animals: dinosaurs.

stories.abstract: NASA and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration joint research venture, led by Dr James Churnside, locates pockets of ocean debris and maps potential paths of migration using ocean circulation models and satellites; scientists hope to identify and contain debris, primarily harmful discarded fishing nets, before debris reaches coral reefs and causes extensive damage to environment (M)

headline.main: Satellites and Airborne Searches Spot Harmful Ocean Debris

stories.snippet: For the first time, scientists have combined satellites, sophisticated imaging and airborne searches to locate large chunks of unsightly ocean debris that can be dangerous to marine life.    The scientists, who conducted the project over the summer,...
stories.lead_paragraph: For the first time, scientists have combined satellites, sophisticated imaging and airborne searches to locate large chunks of unsightly ocean debris that can be dangerous to marine life. The scientists, who conducted the project over the summer, used ocean circulation models and satellites to pinpoint potential areas where they could fly in and use visible and thermal imaging to find debris. Much of the floating junk comes from industrial fishing, logging and dumping.

stories.abstract: Profile of astrophysicist Neil De Grasse Tyson, director of Hayden Planetarium, site of most expensive New Year's Eve fundraiser in New York City; event marks opening of new Rose Center for Earth and Space, with rebuilt planetarium as its showcase; photo (Public Lives column) (M)

headline.main: Putting a Milestone in Cosmic Perspective

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE

stories.snippet: DR. NEIL DE GRASSE TYSON is laughing as he scampers down a spiraling ramp of time in the renovated heavens of the Hayden Planetarium, site of the most expensive New Year's Eve fund-raiser in the city. The length of a football field, the ramp...
stories.lead_paragraph: DR. NEIL DE GRASSE TYSON is laughing as he scampers down a spiraling ramp of time in the renovated heavens of the Hayden Planetarium, site of the most expensive New Year's Eve fund-raiser in the city. The length of a football field, the ramp represents the 13-billion-year evolution of the universe. A step or two from the bottom, Dr. Tyson, the planetarium's director and an astrophysicist by training and dreaming, plucks a hair from his visitor's head. On the scale of the ramp, he says, ''All human history, from cave drawings on, fits on this strand.''

stories.abstract: Neighbors are adjusting to increased noise and traffic congestion around new Rose Center for Earth and Space in Manhattan eight months after its opening; Flushing Remonstrance, 342-year-old document that is believed to be first recorded defense of religious freedom in new world that has been on display at Flushing Public Library, is returned to New York State officials despite community opposition; document is in laboratory in Philadelphia, where it was delivered six weeks ago to repair damage from moisture and fire in 1911; photos (M)

headline.main: FOLLOWING UP

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE

stories.snippet: Welcome Not Universal, But Neighbors Adjust       There was not only jubilation but concern eight months ago, when the sleek, glass-and-aluminum, $210 million Rose Center for Earth and Space opened its doors at 81st Street and Central Park West.    ...
stories.lead_paragraph: Welcome Not Universal, But Neighbors Adjust There was not only jubilation but concern eight months ago, when the sleek, glass-and-aluminum, $210 million Rose Center for Earth and Space opened its doors at 81st Street and Central Park West. The American Museum of Natural History saw its new planetarium, which had its debut on Feb. 19, as a symbol of the institution's rebirth and a magnet for a projected one million extra visitors a year.

stories.abstract: Henry Alford comments on trip to Rose Center for Earth and Space at American Museum of Natural History ro learn about Pluto, which has just been demoted from planet to dwarf planet (M)

headline.main: Last Call for Summer: Three Days Before Real Life Returns; Beholding a Former Planet

stories.snippet: It's been a bad summer for Pluto. And so, before the season ended, I headed to the Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History to pay a condolence call, phoning ahead first, as one should. ''I feel bad about Pluto being...
stories.lead_paragraph: It's been a bad summer for Pluto. And so, before the season ended, I headed to the Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History to pay a condolence call, phoning ahead first, as one should. ''I feel bad about Pluto being demoted to a dwarf planet,'' I told a woman from the museum's Visitors Center. She reminded me that the debate has been going on for years. I elaborated that I would be visiting out of sympathy, and was thinking of bringing a covered casserole. She did not encourage this. The museum was dappled with families and foreigners. I told the young woman who sold me my ticket that I feel bad about Pluto, adding ''It's so much more than an ice ball.'' She smiled indulgently and said, ''But I'm not sure you want to live there.''

stories.snippet: RAPID-REWIND with us now to the days of yesteryear when, at the age of 8, Ellen V. Futter began mastering the dialectic of the tennis courts of Port Washington, N.Y. ''I learned to value baseline play, because steady players go a long way,'' recalled...
stories.lead_paragraph: RAPID-REWIND with us now to the days of yesteryear when, at the age of 8, Ellen V. Futter began mastering the dialectic of the tennis courts of Port Washington, N.Y. ''I learned to value baseline play, because steady players go a long way,'' recalled Ms. Futter, who is now president of the American Museum of Natural History. ''But what I really liked best was coming to the net.'' Fast-forward to a recent afternoon in her office, behind an unmarked door off a bustling museum corridor. These days Ms. Futter, 50, is challenging the net again. She is offering New Yorkers the most expensive and technically advanced planetarium in the world, the $210 million Rose Center for Earth and Space, which is to open on Feb. 19.

stories.lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, as the American Museum of Natural History put up its sleek new planetarium on the Upper West Side, its enormous sphere and glass walls were erected around one of the museum's oldest treasures, a great 15-ton meteorite that fell to Earth 10,000 years ago. For almost a century, the Willamette Meteorite -- a behemoth believed to have come from the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter and brought to the museum from the Pacific Northwest in 1906 -- has been seen and touched by generations of awed schoolchildren and other aficionados of the cosmic mysteries.

headline.main: Cut Loose in the Cosmos, Mites of Dust Without a Home

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE

stories.snippet: There was a time, not long ago, when the Hayden Planetarium quaintly combined exoticism with worn comfort. Inlaid in the floor, in colored terrazzo, was a representation of an Aztec calendar stone. The massive Willamette Meteorite squatted by the...
stories.lead_paragraph: There was a time, not long ago, when the Hayden Planetarium quaintly combined exoticism with worn comfort. Inlaid in the floor, in colored terrazzo, was a representation of an Aztec calendar stone. The massive Willamette Meteorite squatted by the museum entrance, a pitted sculpture created according to some unreadable design. In the lobby a mural depicted the cosmology of the Blackfeet Indians. In the domed hall itself, in the days before prepackaged programming became the rule, a man would stand pointing out the stars and constellations with an arrow-shaped beam of light. And the great Zeiss projection machinery would seem, silhouetted against the heavens, to be a creature out of ''War of the Worlds.'' As the show began, twilight would gradually fall, a mock skyline of houses ringing the dome beneath the blackening sky. There was no question about where one was or who one was in that artificial cosmos. One was a child of Earth, whose surface was pocked by meteorites, whose peoples devised myths to make sense of the heavens, whose contemporary citizens could sit in a city park and learn about the constellations their ancestors had carved into the sky and whose scientists were busy revealing that sky's true shape. The Zeiss machine, a descendant of one invented in 1923 for the first modern planetarium, in Germany, was literally a projector, casting on the ceiling images in which humanity could see a reflection of itself.

headline.main: Scientific Group Criticizes NASA Budget Cuts

stories.snippet: The American Geophysical Union said programs that are finally giving people an understanding of the complex world on which they live will be decimated.
stories.lead_paragraph: The proposed NASA budget cuts for Earth and space science will decimate programs that are finally giving people an understanding of the complex world on which they live, a scientific group said Tuesday. In releasing a position statement, the group, the American Geophysical Union, said the United States' leadership in Earth and space science was at risk because of financial demands on the National Aeronautics and Space Administration that had caused the agency to cut science programs to finance human spaceflight.

This week the American Museum of Natural History will present a view of the earth as it would look from the bay window of a space shuttle in orbit. Opening Saturday, the David S. and Ruth L. Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth is the first in a series of halls scheduled to open as part of the Frederick Phineas and Sandra Priest Rose Center for Earth and Space. Others, including the new Hayden Planetarium and the Cullman Hall of the Universe, will open in early 2000.

stories.snippet: In a compromise that seeks to balance scientific inquiry with cultural tradition, the American Museum of Natural History and an Indian group from Oregon have agreed that the 15.5-ton Willamette Meteorite will remain  a centerpiece of the museum's new...
stories.lead_paragraph: In a compromise that seeks to balance scientific inquiry with cultural tradition, the American Museum of Natural History and an Indian group from Oregon have agreed that the 15.5-ton Willamette Meteorite will remain a centerpiece of the museum's new center for Earth and space. The brownish iron meteorite, the largest ever discovered in the continental United States, will continue to rest on its steel pedestal in the Cullman Hall of the Universe. But in addition to a plaque describing the scientific background of the giant rock, which scientists believe plummeted to earth 10,000 years ago from the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter, there will be a second display describing its history and importance as a Native American religious object.

headline.main: Where the Sky Is Not the Limit

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE

stories.snippet: Five years in the making, the Rose Center for Earth and Space -- a $210 million successor to the old Hayden Planetarium -- will open tomorrow, offering visitors a virtual journey through time, space and the mysteries of the cosmos. It promises to be...
stories.lead_paragraph: Five years in the making, the Rose Center for Earth and Space -- a $210 million successor to the old Hayden Planetarium -- will open tomorrow, offering visitors a virtual journey through time, space and the mysteries of the cosmos. It promises to be a fantastic voyage, but as with any trip, expect a few rough spots. The domed Space Theater, which is the centerpiece of the Rose Center, the latest branch of the American Museum of Natural History, offers synthetic views of the cosmos far more detailed than the most elaborate Hollywood productions. With the help of a supercomputer, a state-of-the-art Zeiss star projector, an advanced laser system, a gigantic data base (in which the motions and distances of thousands of stars are catalogued) and, of course, the hemispheric Space Theater itself, the builders have created a marvelous celestial playhouse.

headline.main: To Walk the Moon

stories.snippet: Man has exposed himself to a variety of hostile environments. He has scaled the loftiest peaks, where the air is so thin it can barely sustain life. He has descended to the ocean floor where, under great pressure, he must breathe a special mixture of...
stories.lead_paragraph: Man has exposed himself to a variety of hostile environments. He has scaled the loftiest peaks, where the air is so thin it can barely sustain life. He has descended to the ocean floor where, under great pressure, he must breathe a special mixture of gases. Never, however, has anyone set foot on such alien terrain as that which Astronauts Armstrong and Aldrin will experience early tomorrow.

stories.snippet: Even before the independent panel issues its report on the disaster that claimed the space shuttle Columbia and its crew of seven, NASA has apparently concluded that no enormously time-consuming changes will be required before the shuttle fleet...

byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD with JOHN SCHWARTZ

stories.lead_paragraph: Even before the independent panel issues its report on the disaster that claimed the space shuttle Columbia and its crew of seven, NASA has apparently concluded that no enormously time-consuming changes will be required before the shuttle fleet returns to space, perhaps as early as December. The report by the Columbia Accident Investigation Board is tentatively scheduled for release in a month, and NASA officials say it might include problems they are not yet aware of. But they say that with fixes to the shuttle hardware, they should be able to resume missions to the International Space Station. They are also shuffling the management of the manned spaceflight program.

headline.main: We Do Not Have Liftoff: the Outta Space Crew

stories.snippet: AMONG the many politicians who sought a seat on the space shuttle, John Glenn was the obvious, perfect choice. He was the only politician with experience, unless you count Jerry Brown. At 76, Senator Glenn may be old, but he's fit, and he won't be...
stories.lead_paragraph: AMONG the many politicians who sought a seat on the space shuttle, John Glenn was the obvious, perfect choice. He was the only politician with experience, unless you count Jerry Brown. At 76, Senator Glenn may be old, but he's fit, and he won't be driving. While scientists applaud his homework assignment -- studying the impact of weightlessness on aging -- skeptics wonder if the future will really find Century Village retirees playing shuffleboard on the Mir space station. As delusional space cadets know, the Pol-in-Orbit program was adapted from the secret Enemy-to-the-Moon plan drafted in 1973 by the Nixon Administration. On a newly released White House tape, President Nixon angrily tells the then-F.B.I. Director, L. Patrick Gray, that he hoped to send Archibald Cox, Elliot Richardson and Woodstock's Wavy Gravy on an Apollo flight, ''or any damn spacecraft we've got, manned or monkeyed!''

stories.lead_paragraph: In the commander's chair of a space shuttle, Robert Deupree safely brings his craft home after launching a satellite into orbit. Mission completed, Mr. Deupree and his crew emerge from the shuttle Falcon to the applause and cheers of well-wishers. Yes, it was a fictitious mission in a simulated shuttle, and it lasted only an hour instead of days. But the crew, average age 68, was pleased. After a week of abbreviated astronaut training, culminating in the intricate shuttle mission, they understood a little better what John Glenn must be feeling.

headline.main: After the Fuss, the Launching Does Look Magical

stories.snippet: During the weeklong media drumbeat leading to John Glenn's voyage into space, the former astronaut Scott Carpenter described one benefit of the flight. As he told MSNBC, ''The nation gets to revisit a time of imagination and hope and magic.'' That...
stories.lead_paragraph: During the weeklong media drumbeat leading to John Glenn's voyage into space, the former astronaut Scott Carpenter described one benefit of the flight. As he told MSNBC, ''The nation gets to revisit a time of imagination and hope and magic.'' That sounds more like a description of a Disney film than rocket science, yet it succinctly captures the gilded tone of the television coverage up to and including yesterday's high-profile launching. The networks and all-news channels quickly found their common theme: the return of an American hero. And after 10 months of wallowing in the Lewinsky sex scandal, you could almost feel their relief as they leaped on this wholesome story. In the last decade television news has virtually ignored space unless a satellite seemed about to tumble from the sky. But all week the network newscasts have been sounding the puffy theme of heroism, interviewing Mr. Glenn and doing features on his historic flight in 1962.

headline.main: Space Aging

stories.snippet: It is hard to recapture, so long after the event, what a galvanizing effect John Glenn's first ride into orbit had on an apprehensive nation. In the years before that triumph, Americans had been plunged into self-doubt by the Soviet Union's success...
stories.lead_paragraph: It is hard to recapture, so long after the event, what a galvanizing effect John Glenn's first ride into orbit had on an apprehensive nation. In the years before that triumph, Americans had been plunged into self-doubt by the Soviet Union's success in orbiting an unmanned Sputnik satellite and then two Russian cosmonauts while a succession of American rockets exploded or misfired. Then, on Feb. 20, 1962, the freckle-faced, square-jawed Marine flier got America back in the space race with the nation's first manned orbital flight. A delirious public honored him with a tumultuous ticker-tape parade and canonized him as a genuine American hero whose exploits owed much to his unswerving patriotism, his enduring marriage, his deep roots in Presbyterianism and small-town America. Now Mr. Glenn, retiring from the Senate at the age of 77, is poised to mount again into the heavens, this time as a lowly payload specialist on today's scheduled flight of the space shuttle Discovery. Instead of piloting the spaceship, he will serve as a guinea pig for medical tests to determine the effects of weightlessness on an aging body. But neither his duties nor his low crew ranking will have much to do with how anyone views a flight that long ago became known as The John Glenn Flight, a testament more to past eminence than present value.

headline.main: A Nostalgic Celebration in Glenn's Town

stories.snippet: At this place, John Glenn was first airborne, on a crazy, wooden bridge over the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad tracks. It is a blind, one-lane bridge, so steeply arched that a driver cannot see whether a car is coming from the other direction. The...
stories.lead_paragraph: At this place, John Glenn was first airborne, on a crazy, wooden bridge over the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad tracks. It is a blind, one-lane bridge, so steeply arched that a driver cannot see whether a car is coming from the other direction. The Lindbergh-obsessed young man known as Bud Glenn loved to drive fast over the bridge in the 1930's, whistling as he drove. The old bridge is still here, as is most everything else in the hometown of whistling John Herschel Glenn Jr. The oil fields and strip mines are mostly gone from the surrounding hills of east-central Ohio, but this town of 2,200 has not changed much in the 36 years since his last flight. A cup of coffee with breakfast at Johnson's restaurant, across from his father's old plumbing shop, is just 35 cents.

headline.main: Glenn Draws Huge Crowd To View His Latest Flight

stories.snippet: The machines, the weather and John Glenn himself were ''go'' today for launching as countdown preparations progressed smoothly toward the liftoff of the space shuttle Discovery, scheduled for 2 P.M. on Thursday, on the most eagerly awaited space...
stories.lead_paragraph: The machines, the weather and John Glenn himself were ''go'' today for launching as countdown preparations progressed smoothly toward the liftoff of the space shuttle Discovery, scheduled for 2 P.M. on Thursday, on the most eagerly awaited space mission in years. All because of Mr. Glenn, returning to space after 36 years, crowds of well-wishers were already descending on the Kennedy Space Center here and were expected to swell into the hundreds of thousands. The turnout of 3,700 news people is thought to be the largest since the Apollo lunar flights. All the major television networks will be showing the liftoff live, something else that has not happened in a long time, not since 1988 with the first launching of a space shuttle after the Challenger explosion in 1986.

stories.snippet: Senator John Glenn, the merriest commuter on Capitol Hill, was talking of the spaceship he will soon be riding and the joy of weightlessness, which for him is rivaled by the delight of never again having to engage in political fund-raising, the bane...
stories.lead_paragraph: Senator John Glenn, the merriest commuter on Capitol Hill, was talking of the spaceship he will soon be riding and the joy of weightlessness, which for him is rivaled by the delight of never again having to engage in political fund-raising, the bane of his earthly existence these past 24 years. ''I'd rather wrestle a gorilla than ask anybody for another 50 cents,'' the Senator growled rather happily amid busy days of commuting between space-travel training in Houston and the astronaut's requisite renunciation of the earthly baggage called politics.

headline.main: A Failed Mission

stories.snippet: Some commentators have suggested that the Columbia disaster is more than a setback -- that it marks the end of the whole space shuttle program. Let's hope they're right.    I say this with regret. Like millions of other Americans, I dream of a day...
stories.lead_paragraph: Some commentators have suggested that the Columbia disaster is more than a setback -- that it marks the end of the whole space shuttle program. Let's hope they're right. I say this with regret. Like millions of other Americans, I dream of a day when humanity expands beyond Earth, and I'm still a sucker for well-told space travel stories -- I was furious when Fox canceled ''Firefly.'' I also understand that many people feel we shouldn't retreat in the face of adversity. But the shuttle program didn't suddenly go wrong last weekend; in terms of its original mission, it was a failure from the get-go. Indeed, manned space flight in general has turned out to be a bust.

headline.main: Voices of Experience; What Old Age Is Really Like

stories.snippet: The extraordinary attention paid to John Glenn's return to space is attributable to his status as an aging legend while his six fellow crew members are much younger ''heroes.'' This gallant act of his, despite what must be to him the distressing...
stories.lead_paragraph: The extraordinary attention paid to John Glenn's return to space is attributable to his status as an aging legend while his six fellow crew members are much younger ''heroes.'' This gallant act of his, despite what must be to him the distressing signs of an old body, has provoked celebratory writing about the glories of old age. Cameo biographies of elderly achievers have appeared, as if old age in itself was a preferable period of life. In the books I have written since I turned 70, I have displayed a contrary, even dour view. Mine was a dubious, uncelebratory account of that decade. Each time, I received protesting letters telling me how wrong I was. My correspondents told me that for them, old age is the best time of their lives, their golden years. They have never been happier, more fulfilled, more satisfied. They are of a mind with Browning's Rabbi Ben Ezra: ''Grow old along with me. The best is yet to be.''

headline.main: Space Aged

stories.snippet: ''One of the neat things about being a commander,'' says Lieut. Col. Curtis L. Brown Jr., ''is when you take rookies into space and you see their face after the main engine shutdown and you're in orbit. You never forget that.'' In October, if all...
stories.lead_paragraph: ''One of the neat things about being a commander,'' says Lieut. Col. Curtis L. Brown Jr., ''is when you take rookies into space and you see their face after the main engine shutdown and you're in orbit. You never forget that.'' In October, if all goes as planned, Colonel Brown will fly his fifth shuttle mission with one crew member who may have that same look, not from the novelty of the experience but from distant memory. If Charles Lindbergh had climbed into a cockpit two years before Ronald Reagan became President, he would have been 77, the age John Glenn will be when he makes his second spaceflight. Indeed, to understand the peculiarity of this flight, it helps to do one more piece of math: we are now further away in time from Glenn's first mission than that mission was from Lindbergh's solo flight across the Atlantic.

Mr. Glenn, who is 77, will still fly aboard the shuttle Discovery on Oct. 29. But in August he was dropped without announcement from a widely publicized experiment designed to test the hypnotic effects of very small amounts of the natural hormone, melatonin, on sleep and daytime activities in space.

stories.lead_paragraph: NASA will return the shuttle Discovery to space in two weeks, after almost two and a half years on the ground since the loss of the shuttle Columbia, officials said Thursday. ''Based on a very thorough and very successful flight readiness review, we are currently 'go for launch' of Discovery on July 13,'' said Michael D. Griffin, the administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

stories.abstract: NASA announces Shepard and Mitchell will attempt lunar landing despite earlier docking problems; Manned Spacecraft Center engineers rept they can find no evidence that docking system has been damaged; speculate some foreign particles may have contaminated docking apparatus sufficiently to prevent capture latches from springing shut during 1st 5 docking attempts; mission dir Lee says astronauts have examined and tested equipment and shown close-up TV pictures of it to engineers during long TV transmission, news conf; repts flight is proceeding smoothly; 10-second firing of spacecraft's main rocket sends spacecraft on more exact course toward moon; astronauts rept many key maneuvers are running 40 mins behind schedule; postpone navigation practice and debriefing session; Mitchell's 2 daughters illus

stories.abstract: lunar module blasts off from moon after 33 1/2 hrs on lunar surface and achieves smooth docking with command ship; Shepard and Mitchell rejoin Roosa in command ship; astronauts jettison lunar module ascent stage, which crash-lands on moon; impact is recorded by Apollo 14 seismometer; 2-min and 30-second firing of spacecraft's main engine boosts craft out of lunar orbit and back toward earth; docking and rendezvous maneuvers described; illus; flight diagram shows module's ascent from moon and orbit insertion; schematic diagram shows its rendezvous and docking with command ship; 2d lunar walk described; Shepard and Mitchell gather samples of cracked and eroding rocks that may be remnants of original lunar material; measure lunar magnetism; drive core tube about 2 ft into soil to collect subsurface material; find some white rocks; photograph old crater with new one in its center; slope of Cone Crater estimated at 18 degrees; Manned Spacecraft Center chief scientist G Simmons holds walk is great scientific achievement despite astronauts' failure to reach top of Cone Crater, news conf; astronauts gather 108 lbs of lunar samples during 2 excursions; illus of them loading samples into lunar module

stories.abstract: Shepard and Mitchell spend more than 4 1/2 hrs on lunar surface during 1 st moon walk; set up scientific observatory about 300 ft from lunar module; describe Fra Mauro region as 'stark place'; collect soil and rock samples; rept surface near module is 'extremely soft'; say module is tilted slightly on side of bowl-like depression; set up color TV camera and special antenna; plant US flag; illus; they receive congratulatory message from Nixon, who invites them to dinner at White House after they return to earth; module is only 65 ft from target point; Shepard says he is surprised by lack of large rocks in area; Mitchell sets up 3 geophones near observatory; astronauts fire 21 small explosives to 'thump' surface at 15-ft intervals; scientists rept receiving 13 usable signals from seismometer; astronauts also deploy 3 grenade-launchers, which are primed to respond to remote-control command wks after they leave moon; explosives should set off vibrations penetrating deep into lunar interior; astronauts use modular equipment transporter, 2-wheel pushcart, to help carry instruments and lunar samples; fall behind schedule; forced to cancel planned excursion to Doublet Crater; walk is delayed 50 mins because of communications problem; illus of Shepard descending to lunar surface; maps show highlights of 1st walk and scheduled itinerary for 2d one; drawing of astronaut on moon using pushcart

stories.abstract: Shepard and Mitchell in lunar module make pinpoint landing on slope in Fra Mauro highlands; landing site is in narrow valley between Doublet and Triplet Craters; landing is 2 mins behind schedule; during 12th orbit, module separates from command ship; docking mechanism works flawlessly; command ship moves into circular orbit 70 mi above moon and module goes into orbit with 69-mi apogee and 10-mi perigee; 11-min firing of module's descent stage rocket sends module into long, curving trajectory; descent is carefully plotted by astronauts, radar and on-bd computer; mysterious abort signals in module's guidance computer threaten to unintentionally abort lunar landing; 2 astronauts feed new data into computer, instructing it to ignore signals, lighting conditions are ideal during landing; touchdown is smooth; earlier, 2 short firings of spacecraft's main rocket dropped craft into lower orbit with 67-mi apogee and 12-mi perigee; maneuver was aimed at conserving fuel in module to give Shepard and Mitchell 15 additional seconds to maneuver just before touchdown; astronauts' pors; maps show geology and topography of landing site

stories.abstract: Shepard and Mitchell forced to end 2d lunar walk early after making unsuccessful attempt to climb to top of Cone Crater, 1 of mission's prime objectives; NASA drs advise against continuing because of sharp rise in astronauts' pulses and respiration rates; Shepard makes final decision; astronauts are nearly exhausted after completion of walk, which lasts 4 hrs and 39 mins; find climb much more difficult than expected; have trouble locating crater's rim; NASA geologist R Brett says samples taken from area near crater may be just as old as those at top; Berry holds Shepard and Mitchell performed more work on moon than previous lunar explorers

stories.abstract: 3-yr study made by team of physicists for Natl Acad of Sciences finds that since '67, financial support of Amer physics has been reduced by about 1/4, with potentially adverse effects on US econ, natl defense and world status; says Fed support during 5-yr period dropped by some 8% in terms of real purchasing power while increased sophistication of physics experiments also added to costs, estimated at 3-5% yrly; lists some 15 'leverage' areas in which adequate support is likely to produce dramatic results; rept is 1st of 2 vols to be published by com headed by Dr D A Bromley of Yale Univ; major proposals among 57 recommendations detailed; graphs showing drop in high school enrollments in physics from '50 to '70 and decline in Fed funding of physics, from '59 to '71, in contrast to projections made in '66

stories.abstract: Natl Acad of Sciences establishes special scientific com to assess 'on an urgent basis' possible course of action to deal with reptd threat to ozone layer of atmosphere, posed by constant discharge of Freon, propellant used in aerosol cans; cause of concern has been evidence that such gas, although otherwise stable, breaks down when exposed to ultraviolet light such as that found in stratosphere, and that resulting chlorine is believed to act as highly efficient agent in breakdown of ozone; scientists have discovered, following recent rapid growth in use of aerosol dispensers, that atmospheric levels of fluorocarbons have risen sharply; believe that fluorocarbons probably represent more serious threat to ozone layer than high-flying supersonic jetliners; some note, however, that little is known about ozone region of stratosphere, whose upper layers are too thin to permit aircraft flight but contain too much air to accommodate artificial satellites; use of aerosol has grown at estimated rate of 21% annually, with 500 different products sold in such containers; some scientists bemoan fact that production of fluorocarbons has grown into major indus, producing 2-million tons or more each yr, before suspected hazard was identified; Mfg Chemists Assn repts its research efforts have detected no indications 'at lower altitudes' of any changes in commonly used fluorocarbons; acad com is headed by Dr Donald M Hunten, expert in atmospheric chem at Kitt Peak Natl Observatory, Tuscon, Ariz (L)

headline.main: Computer Hypochondria

stories.snippet: The Apollo 17 astronauts are now tens of thousands of miles away on their historic trek to the moon. But for more than two-and-a-half hours late Wednesday night and early yesterday morning it looked as if they might not take off. The automatic cutoff...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Apollo 17 astronauts are now tens of thousands of miles away on their historic trek to the moon. But for more than two-and-a-half hours late Wednesday night and early yesterday morning it looked as if they might not take off. The automatic cutoff of launch preparations just thirty seconds before scheduled liftoff created an unprecedented situation; but the problems then posed were successfully overcome by the large and ingenious Apollo ground support team.

headline.main: Holding With Apollo 17

stories.snippet: The following essay was written by the Book Review's observer at the Apollo 17 launch on Dec. 7, 1972. I went to a moon launch for many of the reasons other people go. But I didn't go as a novelist whose next book would capture and crystallize, let...
stories.lead_paragraph: The following essay was written by the Book Review's observer at the Apollo 17 launch on Dec. 7, 1972. I went to a moon launch for many of the reasons other people go. But I didn't go as a novelist whose next book would capture and crystallize, let us say, the human side of space or the American dream in what's been happening at Cape Kennedy. Still, I was more than curious.
