stories.abstract: International team of astrophysicists discovers that basic laws of nature as understood today may be changing slightly as universe ages, surprising finding that could challenge fundamental assumptions about workings of cosmos; research team led by Dr John K Webb used Keck telescope in Hawaii, world's largest single telescope, to study behavior of metallic atoms in gas clouds as far away from Earth as 12 billion light years; observations revealed patters of light absorption that team could not explain without assuming change in a basic constant of nature, called fine structure constant, involving strength of attraction between electically charged particles; if confirmed, finding could mean that other constants, like speed of light, might also have changed over history of universe; could also add credence to unproven theory of physics called string theory, which predicts that extra dimensions exist in fabric of space; implications are so far-reaching that many scientists are expressing skepticism that results will stand test of time, and even researchers on project are being deliberately cautious in presenting findings; research will be published in Physical Review Letters, field's most prestigious journal; chart explains fine structure content (M)

headline.main: Anything Can Change, It Seems, Even an Immutable Law of Nature

stories.snippet: An international team of astrophysicists has discovered that the basic laws of nature as understood today may be changing slightly as the universe ages, a surprising finding that could rewrite physics textbooks and challenge fundamental assumptions...

byline.original: By JAMES GLANZ and DENNIS OVERBYE

stories.lead_paragraph: An international team of astrophysicists has discovered that the basic laws of nature as understood today may be changing slightly as the universe ages, a surprising finding that could rewrite physics textbooks and challenge fundamental assumptions about the workings of the cosmos. The researchers used the world's largest single telescope to study the behavior of metallic atoms in gas clouds as far away from Earth as 12 billion light years. The observations revealed patterns of light absorption that the team could not explain without assuming a change in a basic constant of nature involving the strength of the attraction between electrically charged particles.

stories.abstract: Scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory use Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider, particle accelerator, to smash nuclei of gold atoms together to make highest density of matter ever created in experiment; say accelerator smashed gold nuclei together at nearly speed of light; beyond offering clues to birth of universe, results may also shed light on compressed matter at cores of exploding stars called supernovas, stellar cinders called neutron stars and situations when energy-laden, fast-moving particles in space, cosmic rays, happen to collide (M)

headline.main: Experiments on Dense Matter Evoke Big Bang

stories.snippet: Scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory have used a particle accelerator to smash the nuclei of gold atoms together to make the highest density of matter ever created in an experiment, they announced at a conference here today.    The...
stories.lead_paragraph: Scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory have used a particle accelerator to smash the nuclei of gold atoms together to make the highest density of matter ever created in an experiment, they announced at a conference here today. The accelerator, the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider, smashed the gold nuclei together at nearly the speed of light. Physicists studied the debris speeding away from the collisions and concluded that they had produced densities more than 20 times higher than those that exist within the nuclei of ordinary matter.

headline.main: Einstein Was Right on Gravity's Velocity

stories.snippet: In a test critical to theories of cosmology, scientists have for the first time measured the speed at which the force of gravity moves. And, once again, it appears that Einstein has been proved right, scientists announced today at a meeting here of...
stories.lead_paragraph: In a test critical to theories of cosmology, scientists have for the first time measured the speed at which the force of gravity moves. And, once again, it appears that Einstein has been proved right, scientists announced today at a meeting here of the American Astronomical Society. ''Newton thought that gravity's force was instantaneous,'' said Dr. Sergei Kopeikin, a physicist at the University of Missouri. ''Einstein assumed that it moved at the speed of light, but until now, no one had measured it.''

headline.main: Fly Me to L 1

stories.snippet: For the last 24 hours, news reports have been soaring into orbit that President Bush and NASA are busy preparing their vision for the future of America's space program -- and that this vision may involve sending astronauts back to the moon, and...
stories.lead_paragraph: For the last 24 hours, news reports have been soaring into orbit that President Bush and NASA are busy preparing their vision for the future of America's space program -- and that this vision may involve sending astronauts back to the moon, and perhaps establishing some sort of permanent base there. I applaud the instinct, but I think that a moon shot alone seems more like reaching for past glory than striving for new triumphs. Instead, I think the next step in our space program should be to create a floating launching pad for manned and unmanned missions to the Moon, Mars and beyond. This is not a task for the unfinished International Space Station, which is intended to be a floating laboratory rather than a bridge to the heavens.

stories.abstract: Physicists, astronauts and space flight technologists meeting at Princeton Univ discuss likelihood that it is presently possible, and desirable, to establish self-sufficient human colonies in space; initial goal of such effort would be to construct 'small' colony of approximately 2,000 people at site along orbit of moon known as L5 liberation point, 1 of 5 points in space where gravitation fields of earth and moon balance each other so that object would tend to remain there rather than falling toward either body; initial station would be built using space shuttle and space tug systems presently under development; would take advantage of abundant bldg materials available on moon and 1 of 2 novel cargo-launching systems to export such materials from moon; Dr Gerard K O'Neill, Princeton physics prof, notes 'virtually unlimited' resources exist in space and that sunlight provides constant source of free energy with no nighttime interruption; notes asteroid belt contains chunks of pure nickel and iron that can be fabricated into steel with minimal processing; initial colony would require transport of 10,000 tons of material from earth and fabrication of cylinder 200 meters in diameter and 100 meters long, which would rotate once every 20 sees to simulate earth gravity; other features of colony described; diagram of proposed site of space colony (L)

headline.main: To the Moon, Alice! (Use Your Internet Connection, Dear)

stories.snippet: You don't have to wait for a spaceship or even the night sky to get a close-up view of the Moon.
stories.lead_paragraph: Imagine soaring over the surface of the Moon, dipping into a crater and seeing rock slides on its slopes and boulders piled up at the bottom. You don't have to wait for a spaceship or even the night sky to get such a close-up view of the Moon. You can visit it now with a PC and a broadband Internet connection, courtesy of a free public-access program developed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Ames Research Center in California.

headline.main: A Final Turn-On Lifts Timothy Leary Off

stories.snippet: Toward the end of his life, Timothy Leary talked of death as the final trip and of outer space as the great new frontier. Today, 10 months after ''de-animating,'' as he called it, he left this planet with a blast, on his next adventure.     In a new...
stories.lead_paragraph: Toward the end of his life, Timothy Leary talked of death as the final trip and of outer space as the great new frontier. Today, 10 months after ''de-animating,'' as he called it, he left this planet with a blast, on his next adventure. In a new episode in space travel, not to mention the funeral business, a rocket carrying capsules of his ashes and those of 23 others was launched from a plane after takeoff from Grand Canary Island off the Moroccan coast.

stories.abstract: Readings from seismographs left on moon during Apollo space flights get second look now that computer technology has improved and they can been interpreted; Dr Yosio Nakamura, University of Texas geophysicist who analyzed seismographs in 1970's and continues work on them today, asserts that reanalysis of 9,000 unidentified events shows that 5,885 of them were deep moonquakes; possible implications of moonquake findings discussed; analysis supports idea that moon was formed at different time than earth; map; photos (M)

headline.main: Scientists Find Deeper Meaning for Moon Rumblings

stories.snippet: The recent discovery of more than 100 quakes that occurred three decades ago may help scientists understand what the Moon is made of and why its inside trembles.
stories.lead_paragraph: In the category of ''good research takes time,'' scientists have just discovered more than 100 quakes that occurred on the Moon three decades ago. Seemingly combining archaeology and modern computer science, several groups of researchers have exhumed data from the Apollo landings and taken a closer look at them to improve their understanding of what the Moon is made of and why its inside trembles.

stories.abstract: 3-min firing of US Apollo 16 spacecraft's main rocket engine on Apr 24 boosts craft out of lunar orbit and back toward earth; Duke and Mattingly take pictures of receding moon and of earth rise from spacecraft windows; spacecraft is traveling at 2,300 mph; during final hrs of lunar orbit, astronauts release 85-lb satellite that is expected to remain in lunar orbit and return scientific data for about 1 yr; instruments are designed to measure moon's gravitational and magnetic fields and to study 'solar wind'; astronauts jettison lunar module, which begins tumbling out of control because of malfunction in small maneuvering rockets; flight controllers cancel plans to crash module on lunar surface so that resulting shock waves can be measured by seismometer left on moon by Young and Duke; such measurements help scientists learn more about moon's interior; flight dir P C Shaffer says Young and Duke apparently failed to close circuit-breaker in lunar module's control system when they were shutting down vehicle prior to jettison maneuver; holds module's guidance computer instructions were unable to reach maneuvering rockets because of open circuit-breaker; says 2 astronauts may have overlooked switch setting because they were working hurriedly, with heavily revised list of tasks; revisions were necessary because of many changes in flight plan after lunar landing was delayed for 6 hrs; Duke apologizes to Mission Control for oversight; Young holds moon may have stopped changing after its 1st 500-million yrs of existence; astronauts spend most of day stowing equipment, cleaning cabin and preparing for firing of main rocket engine; astronauts are forced to curtail some of scientific experiments; Mattingly repts he has completed nearly all of orbital photography

headline.main: Galactic Puzzle Solved? Threads Tie It Together

stories.snippet: Astronomers have a new explanation for why filaments emanating from galaxy NGC 1275 can persist for millions of years.
stories.lead_paragraph: A tangle of spidery filaments stretches outward from the giant elliptical galaxy NGC 1275 as if they were dendrites of an intergalactic nerve cell. NGC 1275, located 235 million light-years from Earth near the center of a clump of galaxies known as the Perseus cluster, has posed a puzzle: How have these filaments, which are made of gas much cooler than the surrounding intergalactic cloud, persisted for perhaps 100 million years? Why haven't they warmed, dissipated or collapsed to form stars?

headline.main: Hubble's Power Bolsters Count Of Galaxies

stories.snippet: Taking a census of the galaxies in the universe is like counting the grains of sand on a beach. Even with leaping extrapolations, the task is probably impossible, and the numbers become, well, astronomical.    Undaunted, astronomers studying new...
stories.lead_paragraph: Taking a census of the galaxies in the universe is like counting the grains of sand on a beach. Even with leaping extrapolations, the task is probably impossible, and the numbers become, well, astronomical. Undaunted, astronomers studying new pictures taken by the Hubble Space Telescope announced at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society here today an updated estimate of the number of galaxies in the observable universe: 125 billion. As recently as three years ago, the count was only 50 billion, which was subsequently raised to 80 billion.

stories.snippet: Wintry Uranus      Winters may be long and hard here, but consider the situation on Uranus, the seventh planet in the solar system. There, where the seasons last for more than two decades, old man winter is a very old man indeed.    But now, parts...
stories.lead_paragraph: Wintry Uranus Winters may be long and hard here, but consider the situation on Uranus, the seventh planet in the solar system. There, where the seasons last for more than two decades, old man winter is a very old man indeed. But now, parts of Uranus are coming out of a long wintertime slumber. And a new time-lapse movie of images taken by the Hubble Space Telescope shows for the first time the seasonal changes taking place. Uranus, long considered fairly featureless, is wracked by spring storms.

headline.main: Spacecraft Give 'Deeper' Picture of the Origin of Galaxies

stories.snippet: Astronomers unveiled the first results yesterday from what they said was the most searching look yet into the origin of galaxies and how they grew.     Staring at two patches of sky, one in the north and one in the south, NASA's Hubble Space...
stories.lead_paragraph: Astronomers unveiled the first results yesterday from what they said was the most searching look yet into the origin of galaxies and how they grew. Staring at two patches of sky, one in the north and one in the south, NASA's Hubble Space Telescope and Chandra X-ray Observatory assembled a snapshot of cosmic history, the astronomers said, that reaches back to less than a billion years after the Big Bang in which the universe was born.

headline.main: Mars Gets Its Close-Up

stories.snippet: WEATHERING THE STORMS -- Clouds of ice and swirling orange dust storms are visible above Mars in a picture taken by the Hubble Space Telescope on June 26, when the planet was about 43 million miles from Earth -- the closest it had been to Earth since...
stories.lead_paragraph: WEATHERING THE STORMS -- Clouds of ice and swirling orange dust storms are visible above Mars in a picture taken by the Hubble Space Telescope on June 26, when the planet was about 43 million miles from Earth -- the closest it had been to Earth since 1988. The large amount of seasonal dust storm activity captured on the image included a storm system churning above the planet's northern polar cap (top), with a smaller dust cloud nearby. Another large dust storm spilled out of the giant Hellas impact basin in the southern hemisphere (lower right).

stories.snippet: It may look like the gasp of a fireworks display, and it was formed by one very big bang. But what this picture really shows is how far from empty outer space is.     Taken by the Hubble Space Telescope, the picture is of a supernova remnant called...
stories.lead_paragraph: It may look like the gasp of a fireworks display, and it was formed by one very big bang. But what this picture really shows is how far from empty outer space is. Taken by the Hubble Space Telescope, the picture is of a supernova remnant called N49 in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a small galaxy about 160,000 light-years away. It was created when a massive star exploded in a blast whose light reached the Earth thousands of years ago.

stories.abstract: Photograph of distant exploding star or supernova, taken by Hubble Space Telescope in 1997, lends weight to Albert Einstein's theory of 'negative gravity' force that swept universe and still pervades it; scientists say intensity of light from star, which exploded 11 billion years ago and is most distant ever observed, confirms one of Einstein's conjectures about universe: that all of space is bubbling with invisible form of energy that creates mutual repulsion between objects normally attracted to each other by gravity (M)

headline.main: Photo Gives Weight To Einstein's Thesis Of Negative Gravity

stories.snippet: A photograph of a distant exploding star has given astronomers the first direct evidence that a mysterious ''negative gravity'' force swept through and still pervades the universe, scientists announced at a NASA news conference yesterday in...
stories.lead_paragraph: A photograph of a distant exploding star has given astronomers the first direct evidence that a mysterious ''negative gravity'' force swept through and still pervades the universe, scientists announced at a NASA news conference yesterday in Washington. The Hubble Space Telescope by chance photographed the exploding star, the most distant ever observed, in 1997. Scientists say subsequent detective work on the relative intensity of its light confirms one of Einstein's conjectures about the universe: that all of space is bubbling with an invisible form of energy that creates a mutual repulsion between objects normally attracted to each other by gravity.

(The gel serves as both their home and their food.) The Antquarium is three and a half inches wide and five inches tall and comes with a magnifying glass and an ant trap for those enterprising enough to catch their own colony; ants are also available by mail. Available for about $30 at stores including F. A. O. Schwarz in New York, (212) 644-9400; the gift shop at the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago, (773) 753-6297; and www.hearthsong.com. KATHERINE E. NELSON

headline.kicker: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE STUDENTS
headline.main: Hopes for Experiments Disappear as Disaster Unfolds

stories.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia had many things in its hold when it soared into the Florida sky last month, including basic examples of schoolyard curiosity. There were some marbles, some crayons, a few insects, a lot of plant seeds, and even Central Park...
stories.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia had many things in its hold when it soared into the Florida sky last month, including basic examples of schoolyard curiosity. There were some marbles, some crayons, a few insects, a lot of plant seeds, and even Central Park pond water -- all to answer one of childhood's most fundamental questions: What happens to stuff in space? In recent years NASA has developed an educational program designed to fire the imaginations of the young whenever flaming engines propel one of its spaceships skyward. That is why, besides dozens of technical experiments prepared by scientists and tucked away in the bays of Columbia, there were also projects from, among others, a preschool class in New Freedom, Pa., and a 4-H club in Sacramento.

headline.main: Our Best Spies Are In Space

stories.snippet: Though the two events seem unconnected, the tragic bombing of the American embassies in East Africa last week was in some ways related to the explosion a few days later of a Titan 4A rocket shortly after launching from Cape Canaveral, Fla. One was...
stories.lead_paragraph: Though the two events seem unconnected, the tragic bombing of the American embassies in East Africa last week was in some ways related to the explosion a few days later of a Titan 4A rocket shortly after launching from Cape Canaveral, Fla. One was caused by terrorists, and the other was a blow to a system intended to help ferret them out. The payload lost in the rocket explosion was a Mercury-class signals intelligence satellite, one of a series of spacecraft used by the supersecret National Security Agency to eavesdrop on everything from cellular telephone calls to global data transmissions (like faxes and computer transfers) to nuclear missile tests. The satellite was scheduled to have been placed in orbit above Africa, where it would also have eavesdropped on the Mideast. The loss may eventually hamper the Government's ability to track down those responsible for the embassy bombing as well as prevent similar acts in the future.

headline.main: Largest Telescope Sends First Image

stories.snippet: The new Chandra X-Ray Observatory, which a NASA shuttle placed in Earth orbit last month, has transmitted its first image, confirming that the telescope, larger and more sensitive than any before it, is in excellent health and performing up to...
stories.lead_paragraph: The new Chandra X-Ray Observatory, which a NASA shuttle placed in Earth orbit last month, has transmitted its first image, confirming that the telescope, larger and more sensitive than any before it, is in excellent health and performing up to expectations. Its first X-ray image shows in striking detail Cassiopeia A, the 320-year-old remnant of an exploding star. This gaseous shell is about 10 light-years in diameter. The Chandra is named for the late American physicist Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, a Nobel laureate who specialized in the evolution of massive stars.

stories.abstract: Editorial holds life of Hubble Space Telescope should be extended until more advanced replacement, now in planning stages, is placed in orbit

headline.main: The Fate of the Hubble Telescope

stories.snippet: The Hubble Space Telescope, an astonishingly productive but aging space-based observatory, is facing challenges that will determine how long it can keep performing first-rate science. In our view, the life of the telescope should be extended until a...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Hubble Space Telescope, an astonishingly productive but aging space-based observatory, is facing challenges that will determine how long it can keep performing first-rate science. In our view, the life of the telescope should be extended until a more advanced replacement, now in the planning stages, is placed in orbit. After some early technical modifications to repair flaws in its primary mirror, Hubble has been a resounding success. Floating well above the distorting effects of the atmosphere, the observatory has been able to detect extremely faint objects that cannot be found by earthbound telescopes. Hubble has provided the clearest and deepest views of the distant universe, calibrated the age and expansion rate of the universe, and detected supermassive black holes that seem to lie at the core of most galaxies, among myriad other achievements.

stories.abstract: Nearly every major element of Pres Ronald Reagan's original proposal to place weapons in space is back in center of Pentagon's plans for national missile shield; space-based defenses would be placed in orbit as permanent sentinels, waiting until enemy warhead rises above atmosphere before trying to obliterate warhead, missile carrying it or both; Pentagon's new plan calls for accelerated development of chemical lasers that would fly in space or high in atmosphere, fresh research on abandoned program to launch thousands of interceptors into space and expansion of project to place dozens of sensor-laden satellites into orbit; critics of new plan, like critics of Reagan's plan 20 years ago, fear it could transform space from placid zone into potential battlefield; diagrams (M)

headline.main: Cast of Star Wars Makes Comeback in Bush Plan

stories.snippet: Twenty years after President Ronald Reagan created an international furor by proposing to place weapons in space, the Pentagon has put nearly every major element of the original program back in the center of its plans as part of a national missile...
stories.lead_paragraph: Twenty years after President Ronald Reagan created an international furor by proposing to place weapons in space, the Pentagon has put nearly every major element of the original program back in the center of its plans as part of a national missile shield. Unlike the ground-launched interceptor that successfully pulverized a mock warhead above Earth's atmosphere a week ago, space-based defenses would be placed in orbit as permanent sentinels, waiting until an enemy warhead rose above the atmosphere before trying to obliterate the warhead, the missile carrying it or both.

byline.original: By Terry Pristin (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

stories.lead_paragraph: The Apollo Theater yesterday sued a company controlled by Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan borough president, accusing it of violating the Apollo trademark for the long-running amateur talent program, ''It's Showtime at the Apollo.'' After 15 years of producing the program, Mr. Sutton's company, Inner City Broadcasting, lost its contract with the Apollo to Heritage Networks in August. Inner City Broadcasting then began producing a program called ''Showtime in Harlem.'' In New York, both programs compete in the same early Sunday morning time slot, with ''Apollo'' on WNBC (Channel 4) and ''Harlem'' on WWOR (Channel 9). In the lawsuit, filed in federal court in Manhattan, the Apollo said the rival show has caused confusion among audiences and advertisers. Mr. Sutton could not be reached for comment. Terry Pristin (NYT)

stories.snippet: THE Apollo Theater is not nearly as big as its name. The world-famous landmark, on 125th Street in Harlem, seats 1,500 people, tops. Its old-fashioned opera-house design dates back to 1914, when it first opened its doors as a burlesque theater. It...
stories.lead_paragraph: THE Apollo Theater is not nearly as big as its name. The world-famous landmark, on 125th Street in Harlem, seats 1,500 people, tops. Its old-fashioned opera-house design dates back to 1914, when it first opened its doors as a burlesque theater. It was not until 1934 that the Apollo assumed its current identity, quickly becoming the most important stage for African-American entertainers, a title it has held ever since. ''The Apollo is to popular music what Carnegie Hall is to classical music,'' said the producer and director Don Mischer. ''When you performed there, you'd pretty much made it.''

stories.snippet: The Apollo Theater has rebuffed a multimillion-dollar bid to finance and distribute the weekly program ''It's Showtime at the Apollo'' and is expected to make a less lucrative deal with Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President, and his...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Apollo Theater has rebuffed a multimillion-dollar bid to finance and distribute the weekly program ''It's Showtime at the Apollo'' and is expected to make a less lucrative deal with Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President, and his financial backers, officials and lawyers involved in the negotiations said yesterday. BKS Entertainment, a television syndication company that distributes and markets programs aimed at minority viewers, bid on the ''Showtime'' contract on Aug. 6 after learning that Time Warner was to take control of the board of the Apollo Theater Foundation. The foundation is the nonprofit organization that runs the theater, a state-owned Harlem landmark where the popular variety program is taped. BKS said it was willing to retain Mr. Sutton's company, Inner City Theater Group, as the producer of ''Showtime.''

stories.abstract: BKS Entertainment, in positive sign for future of faltering Apollo Theater, makes multimillion-dollar bid for right to syndicate It's Showtime at the Apollo, popular weekly variety program taped at theater; Leonard Koch, chairman of BKS, company that distributes and markets television programs aimed at minority viewers, says he decided to seek Showtime contract after learning that Time Warner planned to take control of board of Apollo Theater Foundation (M)

headline.main: Company Bids On TV Show From Apollo

stories.snippet: In a positive sign for the future of the faltering Apollo Theater, a company that distributes and markets television programs aimed at minority viewers has made a multimillion-dollar bid for the right to syndicate ''It's Showtime at the Apollo,'' the...
stories.lead_paragraph: In a positive sign for the future of the faltering Apollo Theater, a company that distributes and markets television programs aimed at minority viewers has made a multimillion-dollar bid for the right to syndicate ''It's Showtime at the Apollo,'' the popular weekly variety program that is taped there, officials said yesterday. Leonard Koch, the chairman of the distribution company, BKS Entertainment, said yesterday that he decided to seek the ''Showtime'' contract after learning that Time Warner planned to take control of the board of the Apollo Theater Foundation, the nonprofit corporation that operates the state-owned Harlem landmark. BKS, he said, did not go after the syndication rights until Friday because the company believed it had no chance while the Apollo's board was run by United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, a powerful Harlem Democrat.

stories.lead_paragraph: The lawyer representing the Apollo Theater's management yesterday described contract demands by the theater's striking stage workers as ''reprehensible,'' leaving in doubt the scheduled taping tomorrow of 12 episodes of the popular television show ''It's Showtime at the Apollo.'' The labor dispute between the 34 stage workers and the theater had appeared to be on the verge of easing yesterday after representatives of the workers and management said they had agreed to meet tomorrow.

Giuliani are refusing to provide any more financial assistance to the Apollo Theater, the state-owned historic anchor of Harlem, until the private foundation that controls it answers questions about its financial affairs. Aides to the Governor and the Mayor said yesterday that those questions center on a series of state and Federal loans to the Apollo Theater Foundation, which is controlled by Representative Charles B. Rangel, and the foundation's contract with Inner City Broadcasting. Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President and a close friend of Mr. Rangel, is chairman of the broadcasting group.

stories.lead_paragraph: Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President, was granted his request yesterday to become a defendant in a lawsuit that accuses the directors of the Apollo Theater of mismanaging the Harlem landmark by failing to collect millions of dollars from Mr. Sutton. After the brief proceeding in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Mr. Sutton said that participating in the case would give him a chance to restore his reputation. ''This has been a continuing cloud,'' he said. ''For me and my family, this has been the most cruel thing that ever happened.''

stories.lead_paragraph: Inside the famous theater on 125th Street, Luz Claudio was doing a pretty convincing job of announcing, ''It's Showtime at the Apollo,'' the weekly television version of perhaps the world's oldest and most famous talent review, Apollo Amateur Night. But this was a recent weekday, and the band's space was vacant. A custodian swept the aisles, and the rows of red seats were empty, save for the first few where several dozen young women sat, some studying a brief paragraph on a piece of paper, some chatting nervously in Spanish or Engish.

stories.snippet: A company controlled by Percy Sutton, the former Manhattan borough president, has lost the right to produce ''It's Showtime at the Apollo,'' a weekly televised amateur talent show that was at the center of a legal battle over the management of the...
stories.lead_paragraph: A company controlled by Percy Sutton, the former Manhattan borough president, has lost the right to produce ''It's Showtime at the Apollo,'' a weekly televised amateur talent show that was at the center of a legal battle over the management of the landmark Harlem theater, Apollo officials said yesterday. The show, which is broadcast on 105 stations and is seen in New York after ''Saturday Night Live,'' will be produced in the coming season by Suzanne de Passe, an Emmy-award-winning television producer, said Derek Q. Johnson, the chief executive of the Apollo Theater Foundation, the nonprofit organization that runs the theater.

stories.snippet: Stepping up its investigation of the Apollo Theater's tangled finances, the State Attorney General's office issued a subpoena yesterday to Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President, whose business relationship with the foundation that...
stories.lead_paragraph: Stepping up its investigation of the Apollo Theater's tangled finances, the State Attorney General's office issued a subpoena yesterday to Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President, whose business relationship with the foundation that manages the theater is the focus of the inquiry. State prosecutors issued the subpoena a day after Mr. Sutton's company, Inner City Broadcasting, was accused by another company of striking an illicit deal to retain the syndication rights to a popular television show broadcast from the historic Harlem theater. The company, which was also seeking the contract, said that the Apollo Theater Foundation had secretly allowed Mr. Sutton to raise his bid at the last minute.

stories.snippet: From a helium balloon, Felix Baumgartner, no stranger to high jumps, intends to break the speed of sound in free fall.
stories.lead_paragraph: Ordinarily, Felix Baumgartner would not need a lot of practice in the science of falling. He has jumped off two of the tallest buildings in the world, as well as the statue of Christ in Rio de Janeiro (a 95-foot leap for which he claimed a low-altitude record for parachuting). He has sky-dived across the English Channel. He once plunged into the black void of a 623-foot-deep cave, which he formerly considered the most difficult jump of his career.

headline.main: NASA Jet Sets Record For Speed

stories.snippet: A tiny pilotless NASA jet soared above the Pacific Ocean on Tuesday at nearly 10 times the speed of sound, almost 7,000 miles an hour, thanks to a radical new engine technology.
stories.lead_paragraph: A small, pilotless NASA aircraft set a speed record for jet planes on Tuesday when it dashed out over the Pacific Ocean at almost 10 times the speed of sound, project officials announced. The craft, the X-43A, reached a speed of about 6,600 miles an hour during the short test flight of its experimental scramjet engine before executing a series of high-speed maneuvers on its way down to the sea.

headline.main: Jet Breaks Speed Record

stories.snippet: An experimental X-43 pilotless plane on Saturday broke the world speed record for an atmospheric engine, briefly flying 4,780 miles an hour, seven times the speed of sound, NASA said.    The hypersonic aircraft, a cross between a jet and a rocket,...
stories.lead_paragraph: An experimental X-43 pilotless plane on Saturday broke the world speed record for an atmospheric engine, briefly flying 4,780 miles an hour, seven times the speed of sound, NASA said. The hypersonic aircraft, a cross between a jet and a rocket, was dropped from the wing of a modified B-52 bomber and boosted by an auxiliary rocket to an altitude of nearly 100,000 feet . It then flew on its own for 10 seconds before plunging into the Pacific Ocean, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said.

stories.abstract: NASA plans to try to set world speed record for jets with flight of pilotless vehicle that culminates decades-long research program into hypersonic flight; craft, X-43A, is powered by rocket booster dropped from modified -52 bomber; it is expected to go almost 7,000 miles an hour, 10 times speed of sound (M)

headline.main: Pilotless Jet Will Attempt Speed Record

stories.snippet: NASA plans to try to set a world speed record for jets with the flight of a pilotless vehicle that culminates a decades-long research program into hypersonic flight.
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA plans to try to set a world speed record for jets on Monday with the flight of a pilotless vehicle that culminates a decades-long research program into hypersonic flight. The craft, the X-43A, is powered by a rocket booster dropped from a modified B-52 bomber. In a short dash above the Pacific, it is to use its experimental scramjet engine, which is expected to push the craft to almost 7,000 miles an hour, or 10 times the speed of sound.

stories.lead_paragraph: Gordon Cooper, the astronaut who flew the last of the pioneering Mercury space missions and stayed aloft in a Gemini capsule long enough to demonstrate that a trip to the moon was feasible, died Monday at his home in Ventura, Calif., NASA said. He was 77. He died of natural causes, Mitch Breese of the Ventura County medical examiner's office, was quoted by The Associated Press as saying.

headline.main: Seeking Water on Moon In New NASA Mission

stories.snippet: Twenty-five years after the last Apollo astronaut left the Moon, a small unmanned spacecraft is ready to embark on a return trip, the first mission since then designed expressly for lunar exploration. One of its priorities is to answer the question,...
stories.lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years after the last Apollo astronaut left the Moon, a small unmanned spacecraft is ready to embark on a return trip, the first mission since then designed expressly for lunar exploration. One of its priorities is to answer the question, Is there water on the Moon? The 660-pound cylindrical spacecraft, Lunar Prospector, is scheduled for launching at 8:31 P.M. on Monday at Cape Canaveral, Fla. After a journey of four and a half days, the craft should swing into a lunar orbit on Saturday and begin 18 months of gathering data on the Moon's structure, composition and potentially useful resources for future interplanetary exploration.

headline.main: NASA Seeking to Avoid Year 2000 Trouble on Shuttle Mission

stories.snippet: To avoid Year 2000 computer problems, NASA is taking steps to make sure the shuttle Discovery completes its mission to repair the Hubble Space Telescope before the new year, even if it means flying over the Christmas holiday, a space agency official...
stories.lead_paragraph: To avoid Year 2000 computer problems, NASA is taking steps to make sure the shuttle Discovery completes its mission to repair the Hubble Space Telescope before the new year, even if it means flying over the Christmas holiday, a space agency official said today. Ron Dittemore, NASA's shuttle program director, said the agency had tested and adjusted its computers and programming and did not anticipate any problems when the year changes to 2000. But NASA does not intend to take any chances by having a shuttle and crew in orbit on New Year's, Mr. Dittemore said.

stories.abstract: Editorial lauds NASA administrator Michael Griffin for approving shuttle mission to service and upgrade Hubble Space Telescope; says that mission to repair Hubble may be marginally riskier than typical mission to International Space Station, but that Hubble's scientific importance is far greater than that of space station

headline.main: The Amazing Hubble Telescope

stories.snippet: A Hubble mission may be marginally more risky than a flight to the space station, but that risk is surely worth taking for the scientific payoff.
stories.lead_paragraph: The space agency's finest scientific instrument escaped a death sentence yesterday when Michael Griffin, the NASA administrator, approved a shuttle mission to service and upgrade the Hubble Space Telescope. It was a brave call, since repairing the Hubble will put the shuttle at greater risk than a typical mission to the International Space Station. It was also a welcome sign that NASA is willing to go the extra orbital mile to support superb science, even while it squanders large sums on completing the space station to perform research that can't begin to compare with the Hubble's in importance. For a decade and a half, the Hubble has made discoveries that have helped revolutionize our understanding of the universe. Its typical role is to pick up a hint from ground-based telescopes and then use its unparalleled vantage point above the atmosphere to probe deeply into some puzzling phenomenon. The Hubble has peered farther into space and farther back in time than any other instrument. It has discovered more than 500 proto-galaxies that emitted light when the universe was in its formative stages, confirmed the jaw-dropping discovery that the expansion of the universe is accelerating, and helped establish the rate of expansion and the age of the universe.

headline.main: National News Briefs; 7 Astronauts Preparing Space Station Mission

stories.snippet: Seven astronauts have arrived at the Kennedy Space Center to begin final preparations for a quickly planned mission to the International Space Station, which is slowly losing its orbit as it awaits an overdue Russian module.     The space shuttle...
stories.lead_paragraph: Seven astronauts have arrived at the Kennedy Space Center to begin final preparations for a quickly planned mission to the International Space Station, which is slowly losing its orbit as it awaits an overdue Russian module. The space shuttle Atlantis is scheduled to lift off on Monday and return to Earth 10 days later. While docked to the space station, Atlantis will use its own engines to boost the complex by about 19 miles, which should put it safely beyond the Earth's atmosphere until the arrival of the Russian module, Zvezda, now scheduled for mid-July.

headline.main: Russian Space Station Has Navigation Flaws

stories.snippet: The navigation system of the Mir faltered today, creating a new problem for Russian space officials and astronauts as they prepared for a tricky mission to repair the stricken space station.    The navigation problem developed on Wednesday night when...
stories.lead_paragraph: The navigation system of the Mir faltered today, creating a new problem for Russian space officials and astronauts as they prepared for a tricky mission to repair the stricken space station. The navigation problem developed on Wednesday night when the space station's gyrodynes mysteriously failed. The gyroscope-like devices are used to stabilize the Mir and keep its electricity-producing solar arrays pointed at the sun.

headline.main: Money to Fix Space Telescope May Be Cut by White House

stories.snippet: A service mission to extend the life of the Hubble Space Telescope could be jeopardized by a White House plan to cut NASA's budget.
stories.lead_paragraph: A much-anticipated service mission to extend the life of the Hubble Space Telescope could be jeopardized by a White House plan to eliminate funding for it from NASA's 2006 budget request, government officials said. Officials in the Bush administration and in Congress, who asked not to be identified because the budget has not been officially sent to Congress, said NASA was one of the few agencies that would get a proposed budget increase next year. However, a mission to service Hubble, estimated to exceed $1 billion, will not be part of that package, they said.

stories.lead_paragraph: Thrust by the Columbia shuttle disaster into a new role as sole supplier of the International Space Station, Russia said today that its lucrative space tourism program had been suspended until the station's future was assured and seats in its Soyuz space capsules were again available. The decision deprives the badly underfinanced Russian Aviation and Space Agency, or Rosaviakosmos, of a sideline that had added as much as $20 million per tourist to a program whose entire budget totals only $266 million.

stories.snippet: The once-mighty Russian space program, out of money and buried in debt, is fighting to survive through imagination, guile and the forging of worldwide partnerships.    Time appears to be running out for Mir, Russia's pioneering space station. ...
stories.lead_paragraph: The once-mighty Russian space program, out of money and buried in debt, is fighting to survive through imagination, guile and the forging of worldwide partnerships. Time appears to be running out for Mir, Russia's pioneering space station. Russian space agency officials met last week to discuss Mir's fate, but did not issue public recommendations to the government on when to bring the station down.

headline.main: TV Notes; Glenn's Show, And Cronkite's

stories.snippet: John Glenn's return trip to space has the ring of nostalgia for a generation of Americans, and CNN will add to that flavor by bringing Walter Cronkite back as a co-anchor for its coverage of the event.    The cable network announced yesterday that...
stories.lead_paragraph: John Glenn's return trip to space has the ring of nostalgia for a generation of Americans, and CNN will add to that flavor by bringing Walter Cronkite back as a co-anchor for its coverage of the event. The cable network announced yesterday that Mr. Cronkite, who was closely associated with the American space program in his role as the CBS News anchor in the 1960's, would join John Holliman in presenting CNN's coverage of the launching of the space shuttle Discovery on Oct. 29 and the planned landing on Nov. 7.

headline.main: Space Pioneer Glenn Recalls Old Glory

stories.snippet: Forty years ago today, America held its breath and found its heart as John Herschel Glenn Jr. became the first American to orbit Earth.    Mr. Glenn, who went around the globe three times on Feb. 20, 1962, and put the United States back into the...
stories.lead_paragraph: Forty years ago today, America held its breath and found its heart as John Herschel Glenn Jr. became the first American to orbit Earth. Mr. Glenn, who went around the globe three times on Feb. 20, 1962, and put the United States back into the space race with the former Soviet Union, said today that he still vividly recalled the details.

stories.abstract: Ordinary mission for space shuttle Discovery assumes outsized importance because it will include John Glenn, who 36 years ago was first American to orbit Earth; Glenn, now 77, will be oldest person ever to fly in space; Glenn's encore flight is scheduled for launching on Oct 29; he will join crew of six other astronauts on nine-day mission during which they will conduct observations of solar physics, test new equipment for Hubble Space Telescope and conduct experiments in materials processing and biology; there has been some criticism of flight as blatant publicity ploy by National Aeronautics and Space Administration; deeper response has been awakening of submerged memories of Glenn's earlier flight, during cold war era, when Russians at first outpaced United States in space accomplishments; photos (L)

headline.main: For Glenn and the Nation, a Trip Back in Time

stories.snippet: The countdown is set to begin tomorrow morning for a space flight that will not make history or any new heroes but has everything to do with history and an aging hero, John Glenn.    Thirty-six years after he rode a cramped Mercury capsule to become...
stories.lead_paragraph: The countdown is set to begin tomorrow morning for a space flight that will not make history or any new heroes but has everything to do with history and an aging hero, John Glenn. Thirty-six years after he rode a cramped Mercury capsule to become the first American to orbit Earth, on Feb. 20, 1962, and 24 years after the trajectory of fame landed him in the United States Senate, Mr. Glenn will be suiting up again as an astronaut. At the age of 77, he will be the oldest person ever to fly in space, a hero of the cold war stepping forward this time as a role model for the geriatric generation -- and to satisfy an unending yearning.

stories.abstract: Sen John Glenn, who 36 years ago became first American to orbit Earth, wins his campaign to be rocketed back into space in October, at age 77, aboard space shuttle Discovery; NASA, Glenn and space-medicine experts will discuss plans at official announcement; nation's delight with Glenn's image of mid-American modesty and freckle-faced mastery during first historic mission recalled; photos; Glenn, ever ebullient, has lobbied for two years to make new flight (S)

headline.main: John Glenn to Go Back Into Orbit, at Age 77

stories.snippet: In a wonder of aeronautics and geriatrics, Senator John Glenn, the first American to orbit Earth, has won his campaign to be rocketed back into space at the age of 77, space officials and experts said today.    The news that the spry, ever ebullient...
stories.lead_paragraph: In a wonder of aeronautics and geriatrics, Senator John Glenn, the first American to orbit Earth, has won his campaign to be rocketed back into space at the age of 77, space officials and experts said today. The news that the spry, ever ebullient hero of the pioneer American space program will go back into orbit for about 10 days this fall -- after his 77th birthday in July -- was an instant source of coast-to-coast smiles of amazement today among Americans who cherish the memory of Mr. Glenn's three-orbit ride 36 years ago.

headline.main: At Cape Canaveral, Reliving the Grand Highs of '62

stories.snippet: If he could see the place this week, Juan Ponce de Leon might wish he had taken a closer look when he passed this way in 1513 in his quest for the Fountain of Youth. There must be something here invigorating the likes of John Glenn and T. J....
stories.lead_paragraph: If he could see the place this week, Juan Ponce de Leon might wish he had taken a closer look when he passed this way in 1513 in his quest for the Fountain of Youth. There must be something here invigorating the likes of John Glenn and T. J. O'Malley. Mr. Glenn, as everyone knows by now, is preparing to return to space on Thursday at an age -- 77 -- when many men are content to read Modern Maturity magazine after a gentle round of golf. Some of the spring in Mr. Glenn's step may be gone and his bones may be a little creaky, but here he is ready to board the space shuttle Discovery with other astronauts half his age to show the world, as he said in a recent interview, that the lives of older people need not be dictated by the calendar.

stories.abstract: "Astronaut Scott Carpenter, whose flight into space in 1962 as the second American to orbit the Earth was marred by technical problems and ended with the nation waiting anxiously to see if he had survived a landing far from the target site, dies at age 88;" he was one of the last two surviving astronauts of America's original space program, Project Mercury.

headline.main: John Glenn, Bozo the Clown And Me

stories.snippet: A lot has been written about something that happened 50 years ago Monday - the Friendship 7 spaceflight that made John Glenn the first American to orbit the earth. This is about something that happened 50 years ago Sunday - my television debut.    ...
stories.lead_paragraph: A lot has been written about something that happened 50 years ago Monday - the Friendship 7 spaceflight that made John Glenn the first American to orbit the earth. This is about something that happened 50 years ago Sunday - my television debut. In my mind, the two events will always be tied together. If my 10 or 15 seconds on camera hadn't happened on Feb. 19, who knows when I might have gotten on? The way I remember it, the show I was on was pre-empted the rest of that week for news coverage about Mr. Glenn. And it was canceled later that year.

stories.abstract: John Glenn, former senator who was first American to orbit Earth, says he opposes cutting money from International Space Station and basic scientific research to pay for Pres Bush's goal of sending astronauts to Moon and Mars (S)

headline.main: Former Senator-Astronaut Criticizes Space Plan

stories.snippet: John Glenn, the former senator who was the first American to orbit the Earth, said Thursday that he opposed cutting money from the International Space Station and basic scientific research to pay for President Bush's goal of sending astronauts to the...
stories.lead_paragraph: John Glenn, the former senator who was the first American to orbit the Earth, said Thursday that he opposed cutting money from the International Space Station and basic scientific research to pay for President Bush's goal of sending astronauts to the Moon and Mars. Testifying at a hearing of the new presidential commission on space exploration at the Air Force Museum in Dayton, Ohio, Mr. Glenn said it would be wrong to redirect space station research to make it applicable to human spaceflight to the Moon and Mars and to abandon the more expansive studies previously planned.

stories.abstract: Seven space shuttle Discovery astronauts, including Sen John Glenn, fly from Houston to Cape Canaveral for final preparations for nine-day mission that will be launched on October 29; Glenn expresses surprise at outpouring of interest in mission, which he hopes will lead to renewal of widespread public support for space exploration; he is returning to space, at age 77, for first time since historic flight in 1962, when he became first American to orbit Earth; photo (M)

headline.main: Countdown Begun, Glenn and Shuttle Crew Arrive

stories.snippet: With the countdown clock running and all preparations on schedule here, the seven astronauts of the space shuttle Discovery, including Senator John Glenn, flew in today from Houston to get ready for their nine-day mission, set to begin at 2 P.M. on...
stories.lead_paragraph: With the countdown clock running and all preparations on schedule here, the seven astronauts of the space shuttle Discovery, including Senator John Glenn, flew in today from Houston to get ready for their nine-day mission, set to begin at 2 P.M. on Thursday. At a brief welcoming ceremony at the Kennedy Space Center landing strip, Mr. Glenn stepped down from a T-38 jet and told reporters, ''I have been pleasantly surprised at the outpouring of interest in this flight.'' He said he hoped it would lead to a renewal of widespread public support for space exploration.

headline.main: Many Scrambling for a Spot To Watch Venus Cross the Sun

stories.snippet: On Tuesday, people worldwide will look to witness a subtle celestial event noted more for its rarity than its spectacle: For the first time in 122 years, Venus will be seen passing between Earth and the Sun.    For six hours in the best viewing...
stories.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, people worldwide will look to witness a subtle celestial event noted more for its rarity than its spectacle: For the first time in 122 years, Venus will be seen passing between Earth and the Sun. For six hours in the best viewing areas, Venus will be seen as a small black dot crossing the Southern Hemisphere of the Sun from left to right. The event, called a transit of Venus, once caused nations to mount competitive expeditions to view it from optimum locations.

stories.abstract: Pioneer 10 spacecraft passes within 81,000 mi of Jupiter on Dec 3, sailing safely past planet's hazardous radiation belts and transmitting color photographs and mass of scientific data; extreme pull of Jupiter's gravity accelerates spacecraft and swings it past planet on new trajectory, which should make it 1st man-made object ever to leave solar system; Pres Nixon lauds mission as 'impressive technical scientific achievement,' which demonstrates 'man's ability to explore the heavens is on the threshold of the infinite'; spacecraft transmits photographs, reptdly clearer than any previous pictures of Jupiter, which reveal planet's Great Red Spot as well as its cloud-covering of cold ammonia flowing in bands of many colors; radioed data include measurements of Jupiter's radiation belts, magnetic field, temperatures and atmospheric composition; scientists rept 1st confirmation of helium existing on Jupiter, discovery considered important to cosmologists attempting to explain chem of solar system and universe; rept spacecraft apparently survived Jupiter's heavy radiation doses without degradation, and that radiation levels reached peak 15 mins before Pioneer's closest approach; spacecraft passed within 277,000 mi of Ganymede, largest of Jupiter's 12 moons, and transmitted information, which indicates Ganymede's surface is coated with water ice and has temperature of -235 degrees Fahrenheit; encountered steadily increasing amount of radiation after passing Europa, closest of Jupiter's satellites; temporary malfunction of spacecraft's imaging system results in loss of nearly 1 hr of data, including photograph of Io, another of Jupiter's moons; flight controllers are unsure whether problem was random malfunction or somehow related to radiation bombardment; Dr J A Van Allen, project scientist, says Jupiter's magnetic field seems to be slightly offset at a slight degree from those most commonly predicted and that it apparently is shaped like a broad, thick disc as opposed to spherical and symmetrical shape of earth's magnetic field; estimates disc is spun out out several million miles, but is only 176,000 mi thick--4 times as thick as planet's radius; spacecraft traveled further and faster than any previous manmade object during journey to Jupiter--1 of most important scientific moments in 16-yr US space program; chart compares mean distance from sun, diameter, mass, surface gravity, rotation period and number of moons of Jupiter, Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune and Pluto; diagram of Pioneer's trajectory to Jupiter and its solar system trajectory depicts assumed shape of planet's magnetic field and assumed limit of its disturbance in interplanetary medium; shows direction of Jupiter's orbit around sun and direction away from Jupiter toward earth and sun

headline.main: Watching Venus Make a Rare Journey

stories.snippet: Earthlings will have a rare chance to witness a Transit of Venus when, on June 8, the planet makes its passage between the Earth and the Sun. Then, for about six hours in its 120-year cycle, Venus will appear as a small black dot crossing the Sun's...
stories.lead_paragraph: Earthlings will have a rare chance to witness a Transit of Venus when, on June 8, the planet makes its passage between the Earth and the Sun. Then, for about six hours in its 120-year cycle, Venus will appear as a small black dot crossing the Sun's glowing disk. Johannes Kepler was the first to predict that Venus would transit the Sun, and to predict the cycle; he died before his projected date, in December 1631, and because it happened after sunset in most of Europe, no other Western scientist observed it either. Jeremiah Horrocks, a young clergyman and astronomer, was the first to document Venus's transit on Nov. 24, 1639. Since then, transits have occurred in 1761, 1769, 1874 and 1882.

headline.main: Next-Generation Space Telescope Chosen to Peer Into Past

stories.snippet: NASA chose a successor to the Hubble Space Telescope today, announcing that it would launch a next-generation space observatory in 2010 that would study light produced in the earliest days of the universe.    The space agency selected TRW Inc., of...
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA chose a successor to the Hubble Space Telescope today, announcing that it would launch a next-generation space observatory in 2010 that would study light produced in the earliest days of the universe. The space agency selected TRW Inc., of Redondo Beach, Calif., to lead a team that will build the observatory, which will be called the James Webb Space Telescope in honor of a pioneering NASA administrator. The TRW design won out over a proposal by a group led by Lockheed Martin Space Systems.

headline.main: Pictures Give Hints Of Universe At Its Dawn

stories.snippet: Peering farther back in space and time than ever before, the Hubble Space Telescope has taken infrared pictures of what may be the most distant objects ever detected, early light from the galactic dawn of the universe.    Astronomers are not sure,...
stories.lead_paragraph: Peering farther back in space and time than ever before, the Hubble Space Telescope has taken infrared pictures of what may be the most distant objects ever detected, early light from the galactic dawn of the universe. Astronomers are not sure, but they think some of the faint objects could be galaxies formed in the first billion years of cosmic history, or more than 12 billion years ago. If so, they are crossing a new frontier of the cosmos, where they hope to find the very first galaxies and solve the mystery of when and how such congregations of stars emerged out of the formless dark.

headline.main: What 'Astronomical' Means; Getting Ready to Show the Universe as It Is

stories.snippet: Elephant to mouse: Gee, you're small.  Mouse to elephant: I know. I've been sick lately.      Astronomers have always had trouble conveying the excesses of the universe to the small human beings who inhabit it: its huge celestial bodies, its vast...
stories.lead_paragraph: Elephant to mouse: Gee, you're small. Mouse to elephant: I know. I've been sick lately. Astronomers have always had trouble conveying the excesses of the universe to the small human beings who inhabit it: its huge celestial bodies, its vast lonely spaces, its unthinkably long spans of time. As Neil de Grasse Tyson, the director of the American Museum of Natural History's spanking new Hayden Planetarium, puts it, astronomers are constantly comparing BB's to beach balls to get across the bigness of the universe.

headline.main: What Did Poe Know About Cosmology? Nothing. But He Was Right.

stories.snippet: In 1848, by then a nationally celebrated poet, Edgar Allan Poe published ''Eureka,'' a 150-page prose poem on the nature and origin of the universe. The work, an overheated grab bag of metaphysics and cosmology, was a flop. A reviewer for Literary...
stories.lead_paragraph: In 1848, by then a nationally celebrated poet, Edgar Allan Poe published ''Eureka,'' a 150-page prose poem on the nature and origin of the universe. The work, an overheated grab bag of metaphysics and cosmology, was a flop. A reviewer for Literary World likened it to ''arrant fudge.'' A hundred years later T. S. Eliot summed up the critical consensus. ''Eureka,'' he wrote, ''makes no deep impression . . . because we are aware of Poe's lack of qualification in philosophy, theology or natural science.'' Of course, Eliot had a point: ''Eureka'' was the work of an amateur, a backyard stargazer who read astronomy books in his spare time.

stories.abstract: Astronomers, using array of radio telescopes stretching more than 5,000 miles from Hawaii to Virgin Islands, make most precise measurement ever of distance to galaxy way beyond Milky Way in constellation Ursa Major, 23.5 million light-years from Earth; say measurement raises serious questions about precision of recent estimates of expansion rate and age of universe, including those recently reported by astronomers using data from Hubble Space Telescope; new findings appear to expose possible shortcomings in basic galactic distances used in previous calculations of rate at which space and time are expanding from explosive moment of cosmic creation in theoretical Big Bang; universe is about 15 percent smaller than calculated on basis of Hubble data if most recent galaxy measurement is correct; previous estimate put age of universe at 12 billion to 14 billion years old (M)

headline.main: New Measurement Suggests Universe Is Younger Than Believed

stories.snippet: Using an array of radio telescopes stretching more than 5,000 miles from Hawaii to the Virgin Islands, astronomers have made what they say is the most accurate measurement ever of the distance to a galaxy far beyond the Milky Way -- 23.5 million...
stories.lead_paragraph: Using an array of radio telescopes stretching more than 5,000 miles from Hawaii to the Virgin Islands, astronomers have made what they say is the most accurate measurement ever of the distance to a galaxy far beyond the Milky Way -- 23.5 million light-years from here to a prominent galaxy in the constellation Ursa Major, the Great Bear. Scientists said the measurement, announced here today at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society, raised serious questions about the precision of recent estimates of the expansion rate and age of the universe, including those reported last week by astronomers using data from the Hubble Space Telescope.

headline.main: What Happened Before the Big Bang?

stories.snippet: Like baseball, in which three strikes make an out, three outs on a side make an inning, nine innings make a regular game, the universe makes its own time. There is no outside timekeeper. Space and time are part of the universe, not the other way...
stories.lead_paragraph: Like baseball, in which three strikes make an out, three outs on a side make an inning, nine innings make a regular game, the universe makes its own time. There is no outside timekeeper. Space and time are part of the universe, not the other way around, thinkers since Augustine have said, and that is one of the central and haunting lessons of Einstein's general theory of relativity. In explaining gravity as the ''bending'' of space-time geometry, Einstein's theory predicted the expansion of the universe, the primal fact of 20th-century astronomy. By imagining the expansion going backward, like a film in reverse, cosmologists have traced the history of the universe credibly back to a millionth of a second after the Big Bang that began it all.

stories.abstract: Dr John Schwarz and Dr Michael Green celebrate twentieth anniversary of their public announcement of string theory; over past twenty years string theory has become major force in physics and although it has not been definitively proven it is first equation ever developed that explains all laws of physics and may provide insight into origin of space and time in Big Bang theory; various characteristics of strings and general theory described; string theory provides basis for Einstein's quantum gravity and lends valuable insight into study of black holes; many scientific instruments, such as Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory, could, at least in part, validate string theory; photos; drawings (L)

By prearrangement men in white suits swooped in and carried away Dr. Schwarz, then a little-known researcher at the California Institute of Technology.

Hawking of Cambridge University in England -- the brilliant theorist regarded as one of Albert Einstein's intellectual successors -- has conceded defeat in a famous bet he made six years ago on a matter of cosmic significance. The bet he made with two professors at the California Institute of Technology was that naked singularities could not exist, and now, it seems, they could -- maybe.

headline.main: Did This Man Just Rewrite Science?

stories.snippet: You can try this at home.    Take a sheet of graph paper that has been divided into grids. Color a square in the middle of the top row black. Drop down to the next row. Now invent a rule that will decide if a square should be black or white, based on...
stories.lead_paragraph: You can try this at home. Take a sheet of graph paper that has been divided into grids. Color a square in the middle of the top row black. Drop down to the next row. Now invent a rule that will decide if a square should be black or white, based on the square above it and that square's neighbors -- for example, that a square should be the same color as the one above it unless that square has a black neighbor. Go across the second row filling in squares accordingly, then repeat the process, following the same rule, for the third row, the fourth row, and so on.

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Satellite Venture Talks

stories.snippet: The French electronics group Alcatel said it had been approached by Europe's biggest aerospace company, the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, or EADS, with a proposal to merge satellite businesses. The satellite industry is pressed to...
stories.lead_paragraph: The French electronics group Alcatel said it had been approached by Europe's biggest aerospace company, the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, or EADS, with a proposal to merge satellite businesses. The satellite industry is pressed to consolidate as telecommunications companies, seeking to cut costs, order fewer broadcast satellites. Alcatel said contacts, which were reported in The Wall Street Journal, are in a preliminary stage. Alcatel builds satellites for commercial, military, and scientific use. EADS owns Europe's biggest satellite manufacturer, Astrium, and a stake in Arianespace, the rocket launching group. John Tagliabue (NYT)

headline.main: Fighting Inflation: Higher Rates and Tough Talk

keywords.value: EUROPEAN AERONAUTIC DEFENSE AND SPACE CO

stories.snippet: Can the Federal Reserve continue raising rates without choking off economic growth?
stories.lead_paragraph: FORGET the question of whether the Federal Reserve is finished raising interest rates. It is not. The question now is, Can it continue raising rates without choking off economic growth? Investors and others were wrestling with that question this week amid signs that prices are rising too fast even as economic growth appears to be slowing. 'UNWELCOME,' NOT UNEXPECTED -- Consumer prices rose 0.4 percent last month, and 0.3 percent after stripping out volatile food and energy costs. That pushed the annual rate to 2.4 percent this year. While economists had anticipated just that kind of increase, it still is in a range that the Federal Reserve chairman recently described as ''unwelcome.'' Investors and others assume that means the Fed will continue raising interest rates, reducing the amount of cash and credit available. Fed board members have also been on the stump, talking tough about keeping prices in check. If effective, such efforts could ease pressure for even higher rates just as the economy appears to be flagging.

stories.snippet: There was an eerie echo of the siren song of the 1990’s economic boom on Wall Street this week.
stories.lead_paragraph: STOCKS shattered records. Corporate profits soared. Economists waxed about a so-called Goldilocks economy -- not too hot, not too cold. Sound familiar? That was the siren song of the 1990's economic boom, and there was an eerie echo on Wall Street this week. The only thing missing this time was the mirth. A wary sense of relief greeted a record for blue-chip stocks. Robust profit reports came with warnings of weak numbers to come. A fingers-crossed optimism underpinned economic forecasts.

byline.original: By JUDY DEMPSEY; Kevin O'Brien contributed reporting from Berlin

stories.lead_paragraph: The European Commission is abandoning plans to build a satellite navigation system in partnership with private industry after the consortium chosen for the project became mired in disputes about financing, jobs and management structure, officials said on Wednesday. The commission, which is expected to announce its decision on Thursday, is most likely to propose instead that the 7 billion euro ($9.5 billion) project, known as Galileo, be wholly financed by the public sector.

stories.lead_paragraph: No matter where it goes, the Airbus A380, a double-decker superjumbo jet so big that it has been called the Whale, turns heads. As the world's leaders in aviation gather at the Farnborough International Airshow, which opens Monday about 30 miles southwest of here, the A380 will be on center stage as it makes its Farnborough debut. But the plane is also an outsize reminder of the problems facing Airbus and its parent company, the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company.

headline.main: A Little Spacecraft That Could

stories.snippet: Voyager 1, a spacecraft launched by NASA more than a quarter-century ago, has reached or at least approached the very edge of our solar system, a violent frontier where high-speed solar winds propelled by the Sun slow to a celestial crawl as they...
stories.lead_paragraph: Voyager 1, a spacecraft launched by NASA more than a quarter-century ago, has reached or at least approached the very edge of our solar system, a violent frontier where high-speed solar winds propelled by the Sun slow to a celestial crawl as they collide with the thin gases of interstellar space. It is another important milestone for an amazingly durable spacecraft, which has already explored Jupiter and Saturn and may well keep returning data until its power runs out in about 2020. Scientists are not yet sure whether Voyager 1 has really entered the boundary region known as termination shock, where the electrically charged particles of the solar wind slow abruptly. This is largely because the instrument that measures solar wind speed has conked out. From indirect measurements, one group of scientists believes that the spacecraft has indeed reached this boundary, while another team believes that it is not quite there yet. Either way, Voyager 1, now more than eight billion miles from Earth, has traveled farther than any other human-made object. It is trailed by Voyager 2, an identical spacecraft launched on a different path in the same year, 1977.
