stories.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 28 -- President Kennedy asked Congress today for a $125,670,000 increase in the space agency's budget to permit the accelerated development of huge launching vehicles that would match or excel the weight-lifting capacity of Soviet...

byline.original: By JOHN W. FINNEY Special to The New York Times

stories.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 28 -- President Kennedy asked Congress today for a $125,670,000 increase in the space agency's budget to permit the accelerated development of huge launching vehicles that would match or excel the weight-lifting capacity of Soviet rockets.

stories.abstract: Computer on Russian space station Mir fails for third time since mid-July, forcing crew to shut down most of equipment; Russian and American space officials play down seriousness of computer crash; station is able to maintain its orientation toward Sun, and its power supplies are in much better shape than during previous breakdowns (M)

headline.main: Computer on Mir Fails, Forcing Crew to Shut Down Equipment

stories.snippet: The Mir's computer broke down again today and forced the crew to shut down most of the space station's equipment.    Russian and American space officials played down the seriousness of the computer crash, the third aboard Mir since mid-July. The...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Mir's computer broke down again today and forced the crew to shut down most of the space station's equipment. Russian and American space officials played down the seriousness of the computer crash, the third aboard Mir since mid-July. The station was able to maintain its orientation toward the Sun, and its power supplies were in much better shape than during the previous breakdowns.

stories.abstract: Photo of Russian and American astronauts bidding farewell to each other before space shuttle Atlantis un-docked from Mir space station

headline.main: Farewells in Space

stories.snippet: Photo of Russian and American astronauts bidding farewell to each other before space shuttle Atlantis un-docked from Mir space station

stories.abstract: NASA is seeking to spend over $660 million over five years to bail out Russian partner in building international space station; argues that Russian and American programs are so intimately linked that Russian effort must be preserved lest American space program suffer greatly; key members of Congress immediately fault new proposal as too expensive; orbital construction on station, which is expected to cost $40 billion, will begin in two months, but even if new bailout goes through and keeps Russians afloat, project faces new round of construction delays in 1999 because of Russia's problems in building crucial part; lag in work will also have costly repercussions for fleet of space shuttles, which are to carry station elements into orbit (M)

headline.main: NASA Wants Money to Save Russia Partner

stories.snippet: Worried that trouble in Moscow is threatening its own dreams, NASA wants to spend up to $660 million over five years to bail out its Russian partner in building a planned international space station, agency officials said yesterday.     Key members...
stories.lead_paragraph: Worried that trouble in Moscow is threatening its own dreams, NASA wants to spend up to $660 million over five years to bail out its Russian partner in building a planned international space station, agency officials said yesterday. Key members of Congress immediately faulted the proposal as too expensive, clouding the fate of the biggest science project of all time. But NASA officials argued that the American and Russian programs were now linked so intimately that the Russian effort must be preserved lest the American space program suffer greatly.

stories.abstract: Dennis A Tito, first paying space tourist, emerges from Russian Soyuz space capsule after it lands in Kazakhstan; he is shaky on his feet but buoyed by his adventure; end of his eight-day mission, which took him to International Space Station, does not end public dispute between Russian and American space agencies over space tourism; NASA administrator Daniel S Goldin promises to present Russian space agency with bill for hours of work required by extra precautions and 'incredible stress' placed on NASA employees as they tried to ensure that Tito would not break anything or otherwise endanger space station; photo (M)

headline.main: Space Tourist, Back From 'Paradise,' Lands on Steppes

stories.snippet: Shaky on his feet but buoyed by his adventure in space, Dennis A. Tito, the first paying space tourist, plunked down on the rolling steppe of Kazakhstan this morning, bounced and skidded a bit in a Russian Soyuz space capsule and then emerged into...
stories.lead_paragraph: Shaky on his feet but buoyed by his adventure in space, Dennis A. Tito, the first paying space tourist, plunked down on the rolling steppe of Kazakhstan this morning, bounced and skidded a bit in a Russian Soyuz space capsule and then emerged into the sunlight to get reacquainted with gravity. ''It was great, best, best, best of all,'' Mr. Tito, 60, a financial adviser from Los Angeles, shouted as he and two Russian astronauts were pulled from their capsule. ''It was paradise. I just came back from paradise.''

stories.abstract: Russian and American astronauts prepare to blast off from Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan to dock with new orbiting International Space Station on four-month shakedown mission to make it habitable; US astronaut Capt William M Shepherd will enter craft as first commander; Russian cosmonaut Yuri P Gidzenko will command Soyuz spacecraft on two-day trip to station; will control rendezvous and docking; Sergei K Krikalev will serve as flight engineer; $60 billion space station being constructed by 16 nations led by US and Russia is currently 143-foot-long structure of linked modules weighing 162,000 pounds; will be expanded to mass of 1 million pounds over next five years, covering area larger than football field and will include at least four major scientific modules (M)

headline.main: Russian and U.S. Crew Ready To Blast Off to Space Station

stories.snippet: A patient crew of astronauts is ready to blast off to the International Space Station to begin what could be more than 15 years when humans will continually occupy the orbiting outpost.    The three-man crew of astronauts from Russia and the United...
stories.lead_paragraph: A patient crew of astronauts is ready to blast off to the International Space Station to begin what could be more than 15 years when humans will continually occupy the orbiting outpost. The three-man crew of astronauts from Russia and the United States is scheduled to lift off aboard a Russian Soyuz rocket from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan at 2:53 a.m., Eastern time, on Tuesday. If all goes well, this Expedition One crew will dock with the new space station early Thursday to begin a four-month shakedown mission to make the spacecraft habitable.

stories.abstract: Bryan Burrough Op-Ed article laments that launching of two Russian and American astronauts as first inhabitants of International Space Station was greeted with 'giant yawn', even though it represents dawn of historic new era in space exploration; says romantic age of space exploration died moment Neil Armstrong stepped onto moon; photo (M)

headline.main: Giant Leap, Tiny Footprint

stories.snippet: A historic era in space exploration dawned yesterday, with an American astronaut and two Russian cosmonauts -- the first permanent crew to inhabit the new International Space Station -- blasting into orbit atop a Soyuz rocket launched from the...
stories.lead_paragraph: A historic era in space exploration dawned yesterday, with an American astronaut and two Russian cosmonauts -- the first permanent crew to inhabit the new International Space Station -- blasting into orbit atop a Soyuz rocket launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Central Asia. Other than their families, science teachers and CNN watchers, no one on Earth seemed to notice.

stories.abstract: Russian and American crew of space station Mir bring all systems back on line, replacing main computer after third breakdown in three months (S)

headline.main: Mir's Systems Said to Be Working Again

stories.snippet: The Russian and American crew of the Mir brought all systems back on line today, replacing the space station's main computer after it had broken down for a third time in three months.    The new computer allowed the crew on the accident-prone station...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Russian and American crew of the Mir brought all systems back on line today, replacing the space station's main computer after it had broken down for a third time in three months. The new computer allowed the crew on the accident-prone station to restore the gyroscopes, which keep the Mir pointed toward the sun, its source of power. Russian space officials said they had known it was only a matter of time before the computer would simply give out. The cash-strapped Russian space program prefers to continue to use the equipment until it dies.

stories.abstract: Mir space station experiences fourth computer breakdown in two months; Russian and American crew manages to make some repairs (S)

headline.main: World News Briefs; Mir Crew Handles 4th Computer Fault

stories.snippet: The Mir space station had its fourth computer breakdown in two months over the weekend, but the Russian and American crew managed to make some repairs today.    The crew kept essential functions operating and was in no danger, officials said. But the...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Mir space station had its fourth computer breakdown in two months over the weekend, but the Russian and American crew managed to make some repairs today. The crew kept essential functions operating and was in no danger, officials said. But the shutdown provided new fodder for critics who fear the Russian station is unsafe after 11 years in space.

stories.abstract: Plans for more Russian help to maintain International Space Station while US space shuttles are grounded are limited by US law barring direct financial support for Russian program, unless lives of astronauts are at stake or president certifies that Russia is no longer helping Iran build ballistic missiles; Russian and American astronauts now on space station say they are willing to extend four-month stay to help project; photo (M)

headline.kicker: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE SPACE STATION
headline.main: Law Limits Aid to Russia to Maintain Space Station

stories.snippet: Plans for more Russian help in maintaining the International Space Station while American space shuttles are grounded are limited by a law that bars direct financial support for the Russian program, NASA officials said today.    While negotiations...
stories.lead_paragraph: Plans for more Russian help in maintaining the International Space Station while American space shuttles are grounded are limited by a law that bars direct financial support for the Russian program, NASA officials said today. While negotiations are under way with the Russians, and other partners in the international project, to keep the station functioning and staffed until shuttle flights resume, options are limited because of a law from 2000 that was intended to keep the Russians from helping Iran with rocket technology.

stories.abstract: technicians at Cape Kennedy on July 25 begin countdown for launching of 2d Skylab mission on July 29; crew members--Capt Alan L Bean, Maj Jack R Lousma and Dr Owen K Garriott--conclude training by practicing key maneuvers in flight simulators; Skylab program dir William C Schneider says 3d Skylab mission may be launched later Nov '73 to allow crew best opportunity to view recently-discovered Kohoutek comet as it circles close to sun

stories.abstract: crew members aboard 2d Skylab mission on Aug 1 appear to have recovered from motion sickness that had affected them during 1st 4 days of planned 59-day mission; Capt Alan L Bean, Maj Jack R Lousma and Dr Owen K Garriott begin series of med tests and check cameras and sensors, which will be used during earth resources survey; physicians at Houston Space Center advise crew to eat smaller meals 6 times per day to better cope with motion sickness should problem recur; astronauts attempt to repair leak in system that controls oxygen-nitrogen atmosphere within space station; take turns in rotating chair to test their susceptibility to motion sickness

stories.abstract: countdown for launching of 2d Skylab mission with US astronauts Capt Alan L Bean, Maj Jack R Lousma and Dr Owen K Garriott enters final hours on July 27; Walter J Kapryan, dir of launch operations at Kennedy Space Center, says technicians encountered fewer problems preparing Apollo spacecraft and Saturn 1-B rocket than during previous launchings; project officials say thorough med study of crew will be conducted after 1st 28 days in orbit and that decision will be made, and re-evaluated wkly, on whether to continue mission for full 59 days; high on priority list of assignments for astronauts will be observations of sun through 8 telescopes, observations of earth through remote-sensing instruments designed to survey planet's resources and observations of themselves to see how well they can function in weightless environment; crew will be launched with menagerie of small creatures for variety of experiments; Skylab program dir William C Schneider says space station's internal temperature has stabilized at 79 degrees Fahrenheit; says astronauts will make 'space walk' to extend new sunshade over space station, and will install new set of gyroscopes; diagram depicts sequence of events from launching of Apollo spacecraft at Cape Kennedy to docking with Skylab space station; listing of key highlights of mission

Six Rocket Maneuvers

headline.main: Astronauts Feeling Weak But A re Adapting Quickly

stories.abstract: Maj Jack R Lousma and Dr Owen K Garriott, crew members on 2d Skylab mission, on Aug 6 set endurance record for 'space walk' after spending 6 hrs and 31 mins outside Skylab space station erecting new sunshade, replacing film in solar telescopes and performing other chores in vacuum of space; extravehicular activity described; mission controllers at Houston Space Center rept, contrary to earlier indications, that only 1 of Skylab's cooling systems is malfunctioning; say secondary cooling system is sound and presumably capable of operating for remainder of mission and for entire duration of 3d and final Skylab mission, and that primary system should last for 18 or 25 days; project dir William C Schneider says study is being made to determine whether it would be possible for 3d Skylab crew to replenish regrigerant fluid in primary system; drawing of Skylab space station showing new sunshade erected by astronauts

stories.lead_paragraph: Two of the Skylab 2 astronauts set endurance records in space "walking" today as they erected a new sunshade over their orbiting laboratory, changed film in the telescopes and performed other odd jobs in the vacuum of space.

stories.abstract: US Skylab 2 astronauts Capt Bean, Maj Lousma and Dr O K Garriott on Sept 24 make final preparations for splashdown; NASA drs say they expect astronauts to be very unsteady when they reach USS New Orleans, recovery ship, and try to flex muscles that have deteriorated somewhat from weightlessness; flight controllers express confidence that astronauts will have no trouble steering Apollo spacecraft, disabled by 2 leaks in maneuvering rockets, to accurate and safe return to earth; modified steering procedures were simulated successfully during ground tests last wk; P C Shaffer, who directed simulations and will be flight dir during return maneuvers, comments; Apollo mgr G S Lunney holds 2 leaks were found to be unrelated; 1st one was traced to stuck valve, probably caused by contamination in fuel line; 2d leak was caused by lose fittings in engine; Dr W R Hawkins, Johnson Space Center life sciences deputy dir, holds crew is in good condition; says astronauts have lost 7 to 8 lbs each; repts their physical condition seemed to stabilize after 39th day of mission; says he does not know why; map shows splashdown target

stories.abstract: House and Senate leaders, working behind closed doors, struggle to resolve differences on $388 billion spending bill that would squeeze dozens of domestic programs and favor a few; White House officials, under pressure to show progress in reducing budget deficit, threaten that Pres Bush would veto any measure that exceeded spending limits set earlier this year (M)

headline.main: Congressional Leaders Work On Compatible Spending Bill

stories.snippet: House and Senate leaders struggled to resolve differences on a $388 billion bill that would squeeze dozens of domestic programs.
stories.lead_paragraph: Working behind closed doors, House and Senate leaders struggled Thursday to resolve differences on a $388 billion spending bill that would squeeze dozens of domestic programs and favor a few. Under pressure to show progress in reducing the budget deficit, White House officials threatened that President Bush would veto any measure that exceeded the spending limits set earlier this year. But they also warned lawmakers not to shortchange some of Mr. Bush's priorities, like his plan for preliminary work on a mission to Mars.

stories.abstract: Congress passes Republican budget, driving toward a big tax cut and a showdown with Clinton Adm over nation's priorities in an emerging era of fiscal plenty; both House and Senate pass measure on largely party-line votes, uniting Republicans in two chambers as they prepare for months of budget battles with White House and set an agenda they hope to carry into 2000 elections; vote in House is 221 to 208; Senate vote is 55 to 44; Republican budget calls for tax cut of nearly $800 billion over next 10 years, increase in Pentagon spending and more money for education; plan would require deep cuts in most other programs (M)

headline.main: Congress Passes G.O.P.'s Budget, Voting Largely Along Party Lines

stories.snippet: Congress passed the Republican budget tonight, driving toward a big tax cut and a showdown with the Clinton Administration over the nation's priorities in an emerging era of fiscal plenty.    Both the House and the Senate passed the measure on...
stories.lead_paragraph: Congress passed the Republican budget tonight, driving toward a big tax cut and a showdown with the Clinton Administration over the nation's priorities in an emerging era of fiscal plenty. Both the House and the Senate passed the measure on largely party-line votes, uniting Republicans in the two chambers as they prepare for months of budget battles with the White House and set an agenda they hope to carry into the 2000 elections.

stories.abstract: Influential lawmakers say they would move quickly to secure money for long-delayed safety improvements to space shuttle, even as Congress prepares to examine whether spending constraints have put astronauts at risk; Sen Bill Nelson says he will try to add 'few tens of millions' to $390 billion spending bill that House and Senate negotiators are considering, and Sen Ted Stevens says he supports extra funding but doubts any money could be added to current budget; they and others hold private meeting with NASA's administrator Sean O'Keefe, who reportedly tells Senators he is satisfied with current levels and promises to consider idea of expanding membership of external board investigating loss of space shuttle Columbia; some lawmakers have complained that board has too many military experts and could use more scientists and academics; photo (M)

headline.kicker: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: OVERSEEING NASA
headline.main: Several Chief Lawmakers Vow a Rapid Push for Money to Improve the Shuttle's Safety

stories.snippet: After a private meeting with the administrator of NASA, several influential lawmakers said tonight that they would move quickly to secure money for long-delayed safety improvements to the space shuttle, even as Congress prepared to examine whether...

byline.original: By CARL HULSE and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

stories.lead_paragraph: After a private meeting with the administrator of NASA, several influential lawmakers said tonight that they would move quickly to secure money for long-delayed safety improvements to the space shuttle, even as Congress prepared to examine whether spending constraints had put astronauts at risk. ''You can't have a space budget that stays flat for the last 12 years,'' Senator Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida, who flew aboard the Columbia in 1986, said after tonight's session. He said he would try to add ''a few tens of millions'' to a $390 billion spending bill that House and Senate negotiators are considering.

stories.abstract: House and Senate approve stopgap spending measures to finance government through December 3 as lawmakers leave Washington eight days early to focus on midterm elections (M)

headline.main: Congress Wraps Up Session Early as Midterm Races Loom

stories.snippet: WASHINGTON -- Congress on Thursday adopted a stopgap spending measure to finance the government through Dec. 3 as lawmakers dashed  for an earlier-than-expected exodus from Washington and headed home to focus on the midterm elections.     ''We may...
stories.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Congress on Thursday adopted a stopgap spending measure to finance the government through Dec. 3 as lawmakers dashed for an earlier-than-expected exodus from Washington and headed home to focus on the midterm elections. ''We may not agree on much, but I think with rare exception all 100 senators want to get out of here and back to their states,'' the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Wednesday afternoon. And by 8:30 p.m., most of them were on their way. A half-dozen senators left before the final vote on a motion to adjourn.

stories.abstract: Democratic lawmakers introduce measures in House and Senate proposing that independent commission investigate oil spill in Gulf of Mexico; experts say that however honest or well-intentioned each internal investigator may be, no agency can effectively judge its own role in contributing to accident; map (M)

headline.main: Independent Inquiry Into Oil Spill Is Urged

stories.snippet: WASHINGTON -- As the Obama administration moves to end a conflict-of-interest problem in the operation of the Minerals Management Service, a rising chorus of experts is demanding that it rectify a similar conflict and appoint an independent...

byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD; Campbell Robertson contributed reporting from Kenner, La

stories.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- As the Obama administration moves to end a conflict-of-interest problem in the operation of the Minerals Management Service, a rising chorus of experts is demanding that it rectify a similar conflict and appoint an independent blue-ribbon commission to investigate the gulf spill. The government's main effort to get at the root causes of the April 20 oil rig explosion and spill is led by a six-member Board of Inquiry that has been holding hearings this week in Kenner, La.

stories.abstract: $9 billion spending bill to help Colombia combat drug traffickers and to pay for US military operations in Kosovo is imperiled because of opposition from Sen Trent Lott and fiscal conservatives in House and Senate (M)

headline.main: Senate Fight Snags Aid Bill For Kosovo And Colombia

stories.snippet: A $9 billion spending bill to help Colombia combat drug traffickers and to pay for American military operations in Kosovo is imperiled because of stiff opposition from Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, the majority leader, and fiscal...
stories.lead_paragraph: A $9 billion spending bill to help Colombia combat drug traffickers and to pay for American military operations in Kosovo is imperiled because of stiff opposition from Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, the majority leader, and fiscal conservatives in the House and Senate. Mr. Lott said today that he did not oppose the Kosovo and Colombia aid, but rather just the legislative vehicle for it. He said the so-called emergency measure, which is $3.8 billion larger than President Clinton had requested, had become a magnet for pork-barrel spending.

stories.abstract: House and Senate negotiators agree to shift control over exporting American satellites back to State Department from Commerce Department; some space experts have said controls on such exports to China have been loosened since Clinton Administration transferred licensing authority to les-restrictive Commerce Department in 1996, possibly compromising national security; several Congressional committees are investigating possible release of technology that may have helped China improve its missiles; Commerce Under Sec William A Reinsch charges latest action will hurt American companies, and warns of possible veto, but licensing provision is contained in Pentagon budget bill, and White House seems to pull back from veto threat (M);

headline.main: CHANGE IN CONTROL OF SATELLITE SALES GAINS IN CONGRESS

stories.snippet: In a major challenge to President Clinton's export policy, House and Senate negotiators agreed today to shift the control over exporting American satellites back to the State Department from the Commerce Department.    Some space experts and a senior...
stories.lead_paragraph: In a major challenge to President Clinton's export policy, House and Senate negotiators agreed today to shift the control over exporting American satellites back to the State Department from the Commerce Department. Some space experts and a senior Government auditor have said controls on exports of satellites to China have been loosened since the Administration transferred licensing authority to the less restrictive Commerce Department in 1996, possibly compromising national security. The Commerce Department denied this.

stories.abstract: House and Senate negotiators reach agreement on significant revamping of Department of Energy, establishing new agency within department to oversee nuclear weapons programs in response to accusations of Chinese espionage; Clinton Administration officials say proposal constrains Energy Secretary's authority, and indicates Sec Bill Richardson would recommend that Pres Clinton veto Pentagon's $289 billion budget bill unless lawmakers modify this aspect; Energy Dept's budget is included in bill because of nuclear weapons program (M)

headline.main: Congressional Pact Alters Energy Dept. to Protect Nuclear Secrets

stories.snippet: House and Senate negotiators reached agreement today on a significant revamping of the Department of Energy, establishing a new agency within the department to oversee nuclear weapons programs in response to accusations of Chinese espionage.     But...
stories.lead_paragraph: House and Senate negotiators reached agreement today on a significant revamping of the Department of Energy, establishing a new agency within the department to oversee nuclear weapons programs in response to accusations of Chinese espionage. But Administration officials said the proposal constrained the Energy Secretary's authority, and indicated that Secretary Bill Richardson would recommend that President Clinton veto the Pentagon's $289 billion budget bill unless lawmakers modified this aspect of it. Much of the Energy Department's budget is included in the bill because of the nuclear weapons programs.

headline.main: New Horizons Beckon, Inspiring Vision if Not Certainty

stories.snippet: Moon or Mars, or both? Economic incentives or political? And who will lead the way?
stories.lead_paragraph: Fifty years of spaceflight have taken people to the Moon and have sent unmanned vehicles zipping to the fringes of the solar system. What could the next 50 years bring? Much more, or potentially not much more. Government-financed space travel could stall in the face of America's growing aversion to risk and a kind of orbital ennui. NASA has, after all, already tried for more than a decade to develop follow-on vehicles to the flawed space shuttle and is in the process of trying again.

stories.abstract: Jack Hitt article on Centennial Challenges, design contests by which NASA is enlisting backyard inventors to brainstorm new technologies for possible return to moon; prize money in seven contests ranges from $200,000 for space glove, won by Peter K Homer, out-of-work director of local community center in Maine, to $2 million for creation of new lunar lander; part of impetus for challenges is fact that Americans, perhaps more so than people of other nations, have great faith in idea of outsider inventor; photos (L)

headline.main: The Amateur Future of Space Travel

stories.snippet: How NASA turned to America’s basement brainstormers, workbench concocters and garage tinkerers to revive the space program.
stories.lead_paragraph: When Peter K. Homer, an out-of-work director of a local community center in Maine, first heard that NASA was turning to America's backyard inventors to brainstorm new technologies for a possible return to the moon, he had an idea. With NASA sponsoring seven design contests for everything from a new lunar lander to a new space glove, anybody with a home-brewed invention could enter. Homer's previous jobs included some gigs in the aerospace industry as well as work sewing boat sails. So, Homer told me not long ago, he ruled out building a flying spacecraft but decided that ''the glove contest represented something of the scale I could achieve working out of my home by myself.'' He'd always been a garage tinkerer, he said, and being unemployed, he also wanted to prove to his 14-year-old son ''that you can do anything if you put your mind to it.'' Oh, he added offhandedly, ''the money is a motivator, too.'' At stake was a prize -- presented with one of those giant cardboard checks -- for $200,000.

headline.main: NASA Plans Permanent Base For Exploration on the Moon

stories.snippet: The agency envisions a base at one of the lunar poles, to take advantage of the near-constant sunlight.

stories.lead_paragraph: NASA announced plans on Monday for a permanent base on the Moon, to be started soon after astronauts return there around 2020. The agency's deputy administrator, Shana Dale, said the United States would develop rockets and spacecraft to get people to the Moon and establish a rudimentary base. There, other countries and commercial enterprises could expand the outpost to develop scientific and other interests, Ms. Dale said.

stories.abstract: Editorial supports efforts by Pres Obama to win over critics of his new approach to human space flight as shown chiefly through budget cuts; praises his realization that Bush administration plan to emphasize manned space flights and return to moon by 2020 lacked detailed rationale; holds that whether or not Obama wins over opponents, he has clearly learned lessons in past year about how to get involved with, and defend, plans that upend entrenched interests

headline.main: Now It's the President's Plan

stories.snippet: It isn’t clear whether Mr. Obama will win over critics of his space program, but his personal involvement in laying out his proposals is a good sign.
stories.lead_paragraph: in budget documents -- in February, we thought President Obama's new approach to human space flight made good sense. But it drew immediate, fierce opposition from states that feared they would lose jobs and from Congressional boosters of the traditional space program. It called for scrapping the Bush administration's program to return to the Moon by 2020, which had fallen hopelessly behind schedule and relied on outdated technology. It substituted a big investment in developing new technologies to make travel farther into the solar system cheaper and faster. In the meantime, NASA would rely on commercial companies to carry astronauts and cargo to the International Space Station after the aging shuttle fleet is retired.

headline.main: Talk of Space Turns to Ways To Develop Commercially

stories.snippet: Reports that President Bush wants to plant permanent human settlements on the moon and to send a manned mission to Mars are reinvigorating business dreams inspired by the Apollo program of the 1960's and 1970's.    The most obviously enthusiastic...
stories.lead_paragraph: Reports that President Bush wants to plant permanent human settlements on the moon and to send a manned mission to Mars are reinvigorating business dreams inspired by the Apollo program of the 1960's and 1970's. The most obviously enthusiastic companies about human space flight are the rocket-launching businesses: the Lockheed Martin Corporation and the Boeing Company. Lockheed Martin, manager of the space shuttle program, has a vested interest in seeing manned space flight continue. Boeing, which has been involved in the space program since its roots, was the lead contractor for the International Space Station and played a significant role in the Apollo moon program.

headline.main: A Google Competition, With a Robotic Moon Landing as a Goal

stories.snippet: Ten teams from five countries plan to compete for $30 million in prizes in the Google-sponsored race to the moon.
stories.lead_paragraph: More than three decades after the last Apollo astronauts roamed the lunar surface, disparate universities, open-source engineers and quixotic aerospace start-ups are planning to start their own robotic missions to the Earth's barren cousin. The return to the moon is part of the Google Lunar X Prize, a competition sponsored by Google with $30 million in prizes for the first two teams to land a robotic rover on the moon and send images and other data back home.

stories.abstract: Editorial notes that NASA has announced plans to establish permanent base on Moon by 2024; expresses concern that political proponents of Pres Bush's Moon-Mars adventure will not provide money commensurate with task; holds that NASA's crowning scientific achievements have come from its unmanned probes to distant worlds and its orbiting observatories; contends that it would be shame if underfinanced program to return to Moon on permanent basis and then venture on to Mars forced reductions in research programs of higher scientific value

headline.main: Back to the Moon, Permanently

stories.snippet: It would be a shame if an underfinanced program to return to the Moon on a permanent basis and then venture on to Mars forced reductions in research programs of higher scientific value.
stories.lead_paragraph: Three years after President Bush announced an ambitious long-term goal to return astronauts to the Moon and then send them on to Mars, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has finally put some flesh on his nebulous aspirations. This week, the agency announced plans to establish a permanent base on the Moon by 2024, explained why we should want to send astronauts back to a world they visited repeatedly more than three decades ago, and described what they might do when they get there. It was belated justification for a decision that the Bush administration and Congress have already made. But the payoff is distant and the likely future costs very high, leaving it unclear how realistic these aspirations will prove to be. The agency has done a commendably thorough job by consulting some 1,000 experts and 13 other space agencies in fashioning its plans. Such a costly and difficult venture should ideally be pursued cooperatively with other nations, to share the costs and the risks. It would be especially desirable to have multiple ways of reaching the Moon in case the American program runs into problems like those that grounded the shuttles.

stories.snippet: A new study in the Amazon rain forest shows that trees are worse off in the rainy season, when many leaves die but relatively few new ones are produced.
stories.lead_paragraph: Urban Ants Take the Heat There may be some remaining pockets of resistance to the idea that the planet is heating up, but no one can deny that cities have been growing warmer. Urban areas can be as much as 20 degrees hotter than nearby rural ones, a result, among other factors, of all that concrete and asphalt pumping out heat as sunlight hits it. Sweltering temperatures affect humans, of course, but are there other biological consequences of what are known as urban heat islands? A study by Michael J. Angilletta Jr. of Indiana State University and colleagues shows that there is. Urban ants, they report in PLoS Biology, can stand the heat better than those from out of town.

The liftoff had been scrubbed four times. The Aura's six-year mission seeks to improve understanding of how pollutants spread; to determine whether the ozone layer, which blocks harmful ultraviolet radiation, is recovering from depletion by chemicals; and to study how Earth's climate is changing as its atmosphere is altered.

headline.main: Going in Style: The Loved One Gets a New Age Send-off

stories.snippet: A Taurus rocket launched earlier this month from Vandenberg Air Force Base in Lompoc, Calif., carried a standard payload of three communications satellites. But also along for the ride were the cremated remains of 30 individuals who had paid $4,800...
stories.lead_paragraph: A Taurus rocket launched earlier this month from Vandenberg Air Force Base in Lompoc, Calif., carried a standard payload of three communications satellites. But also along for the ride were the cremated remains of 30 individuals who had paid $4,800 each to become one with the universe. They were packed by Celestis, a Houston-based commercial venture, in a canister with lipstick-sized vials containing about seven grams each of human remains. The launch drew attention to the increasingly creative possibilities for disposing of cremated remains -- or ''cremains'' as they are known in industry -- and to the growing popularity of cremation itself.

headline.main: Rust on the Moon

stories.snippet: A new element of excitement has been injected into the study of the moon by Apollo 17. The orange or reddish dust -- apparently resembling the rust on a piece of iron -- found by astronauts Cernan and Schmitt has astonished the scientific world....
stories.lead_paragraph: A new element of excitement has been injected into the study of the moon by Apollo 17. The orange or reddish dust -- apparently resembling the rust on a piece of iron -- found by astronauts Cernan and Schmitt has astonished the scientific world. Nothing similar had been previously seen on the moon. It is premature, though tempting, to conclude that this is evidence -- in geological terms -- of relatively recent volcanic activity.

stories.abstract: Julie Lew article on visiting new $76 million Chabot Space and Science Center, Oakland, Calif, premier astronomy and space museum; photos (M)

headline.main: Opening a Window on the Universe

stories.snippet: AT 45 degrees, it was a chilly November evening in the hills above Oakland, Calif., yet I waited in line patiently with 300 others for nearly an hour to peer at a bunch of sparkly dots that resembled a tiny pile of granulated sugar. One by one, we ...
stories.lead_paragraph: AT 45 degrees, it was a chilly November evening in the hills above Oakland, Calif., yet I waited in line patiently with 300 others for nearly an hour to peer at a bunch of sparkly dots that resembled a tiny pile of granulated sugar. One by one, we filed into a silver-domed observatory and climbed a ladder to look into the lens of a 20-inch telescope named Rachel, one of the largest refractors in the western United States open to the public. Tonight's target was M-15, a group of about 250,000 stars almost 40,000 light-years away. To put it into mind-boggling perspective, one light-minute is equal to a little more than 11 million miles, and despite this almost unfathomable distance, M-15 is still within the Milky Way. This age-old human fascination with our place in an infinite universe is the foundation upon which the new $76 million, 86,000-square-foot Chabot Space and Science Center was built. It is one of the premier astronomy and space museums in the country, with exhibits, equipment and science programs that have earned it an affiliation with the Smithsonian Institution. The center opened in August and is still a work in progress, but what is currently available will satisfy the most ardent stargazer.

stories.abstract: Dragon Skies: Astronomy of Imperial China, some of world's oldest stargazing tools and timepieces, are on display for first time time in US at Chabot Space and Science Center in Oakland, Calif; photo (M)

headline.main: Tools for Ancient Eyes To View the Heavens

stories.snippet: Some of the world's oldest stargazing tools, used by the royal astronomers of ancient China, are on display in Oakland, Calif., in their first appearance in the United States, at the Chabot Space and Science Center. Through Jan. 2, the hilltop...
stories.lead_paragraph: Some of the world's oldest stargazing tools, used by the royal astronomers of ancient China, are on display in Oakland, Calif., in their first appearance in the United States, at the Chabot Space and Science Center. Through Jan. 2, the hilltop observatory will showcase 32 artifacts, many of them original, and 13 interactive displays that make up ''Dragon Skies: Astronomy of Imperial China.'' China's royal astronomers were among the first to chart constellations and record the passing of comets, eclipses and supernovas, creating some of the earliest known continuous written logs of celestial events, dating at least as far back as 1500 B.C.

headline.main: Star-Gazing at a Higher and Sharper Level

stories.snippet: Amateur astronomers and other sky watchers will have a new West Coast spot to stargaze from when the Chabot Space and Science Center, an 86,000-square-foot facility in the hills of Oakland, Calif., opens Aug. 19.    While the center covers a broad...
stories.lead_paragraph: Amateur astronomers and other sky watchers will have a new West Coast spot to stargaze from when the Chabot Space and Science Center, an 86,000-square-foot facility in the hills of Oakland, Calif., opens Aug. 19. While the center covers a broad range of sciences, the focus is on astronomy and space exploration. An observatory complex houses 8- and 20-inch refractor telescopes (the bigger the telescope, the clearer the view) that were relocated from the center's former facility. A new 36-inch reflector, one of the largest public telescopes in the country, will be installed sometime next year.

headline.main: This Is the Mission: Fill Gap for Schools, Lift Students to Skies

stories.snippet: As more schools struggle to keep pace with grueling new federal and state standards, science centers are playing a bigger role than ever in science education.
stories.lead_paragraph: THE year is 2061. The mission, which is accepted with a mixture of trepidation and giddiness, is to launch a probe into the tail of Halley's comet. Twenty-seven astronauts and mission specialists will carry out the work of Challenger, 75 years after its namesake exploded upon liftoff. The isolation team uses robotic arms to test hazardous materials. The life support team quashes an oxygen depletion emergency. And the navigation team successfully triangulates the comet using a computerized grid on a star field. When the mission is done, these fifth graders slap high-fives, clear the air lock and bolt outside for lunch.

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: 3rd Day Of Delay In Shuttle Landing

stories.snippet: Thick low clouds and rain forced NASA to postpone the landing of the space shuttle Endeavour at the Kennedy Space Center for the third time in three days, the first time in almost 22 years of shuttle flights that poor weather prevented a landing for...
stories.lead_paragraph: Thick low clouds and rain forced NASA to postpone the landing of the space shuttle Endeavour at the Kennedy Space Center for the third time in three days, the first time in almost 22 years of shuttle flights that poor weather prevented a landing for three days in a row. Forecasters predict that the weather will improve in time for a landing in Florida today. If they are wrong, NASA can send the shuttle to land at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., or reschedule the landing for Sunday at an Air Force landing strip at White Sands, N.M. The space agency wants to avoid a California landing not only because it would cost $1 million to transport the shuttle back to Florida, but also because it could delay the ship's next mission. Stefano S. Coledan (NYT)

headline.main: Q & A

stories.snippet: Ring Around the Sun    Q.  How does a coronagraph work? How could I build one?    A.  A coronagraph is an optical device that blocks the light from the sun's disk, making it possible to observe the corona, the very thin and hot upper level of the...
stories.lead_paragraph: Ring Around the Sun Q. How does a coronagraph work? How could I build one? A. A coronagraph is an optical device that blocks the light from the sun's disk, making it possible to observe the corona, the very thin and hot upper level of the solar atmosphere, at the edge of the disk. A lens focuses an image of the sun onto a masking or occulting disk that prevents the light from proceeding farther into the telescope.

stories.lead_paragraph: Q. Why does the space shuttle roll after launching? How does it catch up to the space station without bumping into it? A. ''Shortly after the shuttle clears the launching tower, the software of its automated guidance, navigation and control system initiates a roll command to line it up on the desired course and heading,'' said Kyle Herring, a NASA spokesman at the Johnson Space Center in Houston.

stories.lead_paragraph: Q. How do scientists determine that a rock on Earth came from Mars rather than someplace else? A. The best idea scientists have of the geochemistry of Mars comes from the two Viking robots that landed on Mars in 1976. Findings from the robots' weeks of readings of things like the Martian atmosphere are compared with the chemical signatures of meteorites found on Earth.

headline.main: In a Rare View, Rings on Uranus Show Their Changes

stories.snippet: It’s that time of year on the distant planet  when its ring system appears edge-on to observers on Earth.
stories.lead_paragraph: It's that time of year on Uranus -- time for the semiannual ring-plane crossing, when the planet's ring system appears edge-on to observers on Earth. (Unlike the other planets, Uranus spins on its side, making for extreme changes in viewing angles.) The crossing allows telescopes to take pictures of the rings from the unlighted side, free from the glare that can obscure faint parts of them. Of course, a year on Uranus is equivalent to 84 Earth years, so this semiannual event is happening for the first time since the planet's rings were discovered, in 1977. And it's causing some rethinking about the rings and their stability.

headline.main: Hubble Mission Is Moved Back

stories.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration set Oct. 8 as the date for the final mission to the Hubble Space Telescope. A crew of seven aboard the space shuttle Atlantis was to repair and upgrade the 18-year-old telescope at the end of August,...
stories.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration set Oct. 8 as the date for the final mission to the Hubble Space Telescope. A crew of seven aboard the space shuttle Atlantis was to repair and upgrade the 18-year-old telescope at the end of August, but the mission was delayed because more time was needed to build fuel tanks for the shuttle flight and a potential rescue mission. The agency also rescheduled a supply mission to the International Space Station to Nov. 10 from Oct. 16. The shuttle Discovery is scheduled for launching on May 31 to deliver and install the Japanese laboratory Kibo at the space station.

stories.abstract: Thomas Wright letter holds that bureaucratic fear of shuttle program failure is main factor in NASA's reluctance to support mission to Hubble Space Telescope

headline.main: A Space Agency for the Faint of Heart

stories.snippet: To the Editor:    Pioneering is never safe, because it is never routine.    Sean O'Keefe, the NASA administrator, is concerned that ''schedule pressure'' to launch a space shuttle to repair the Hubble would compromise safety (Op-Ed, March 14). A...
stories.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Pioneering is never safe, because it is never routine. Sean O'Keefe, the NASA administrator, is concerned that ''schedule pressure'' to launch a space shuttle to repair the Hubble would compromise safety (Op-Ed, March 14). A Hubble mission would not be a case of discounting safety in favor of commercial pressure, but a race to save the most productive effort of the entire space program.

stories.abstract: Editorial assails NASA for canceling planned servicing mission to Hubble Space Telescope that would have upgraded its instruments and extended its life past end of decade; notes that decision makes it likely that telescope will run out of battery power by about 2007; urges Congress to prevent premature loss of Hubble; contends that it is being sacrificed to make way for Pres Bush's grand new plans to send astronauts to Moon and Mars in future years; maintains that once shuttles are deemed safe enough to resume flying, flight to Hubble will be no more risky than flights to space station; asserts that science still to be done on Hubble is far more important than anything likely to be accomplished on space station

headline.main: Premature Death for the Hubble

stories.snippet: By all accounts the Hubble Space Telescope is one of the most productive scientific instruments in history. Orbiting high above the distorting effects of Earth's atmosphere, it has peered far out into space and back toward the beginnings of time,...
stories.lead_paragraph: By all accounts the Hubble Space Telescope is one of the most productive scientific instruments in history. Orbiting high above the distorting effects of Earth's atmosphere, it has peered far out into space and back toward the beginnings of time, producing images of startling clarity. It has detected extremely faint objects that can't be seen from the Earth, calibrated the age and expansion rate of the universe, detected supermassive black holes in the cores of galaxies and generally helped revolutionize our understanding of the universe. A distinguished panel of astronomers judged that Hubble ''has arguably had a greater impact on astronomy than any instrument since the original astronomical telescope of Galileo.'' Yet now, just as Hubble was scheduled for a major rejuvenation, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has consigned it to slow death. The agency has canceled a planned servicing mission that would have upgraded Hubble's instruments and extended its life past the end of the decade, making it likely that the telescope will run out of battery power and functioning gyroscopes by about 2007. Congress needs to prevent the premature loss of this valuable instrument.

stories.abstract: Editorial contends that NASA administrator Sean O'Keefe seems to be digging in his heels against any effort to overturn his cancellation of next shuttle servicing mission to Hubble Space Telescope; maintains that his reluctance makes it imperative that Congress insist on full-scale analysis of risks and benefits of servicing Hubble, and that National Academy of Sciences refuse to undertake anything less

headline.main: Astronomical Exaggerations

stories.snippet: Sean O'Keefe, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, seems to be digging in his heels against any effort to overturn his cancellation of the next shuttle servicing mission to the Hubble Space Telescope, thereby sentencing...
stories.lead_paragraph: Sean O'Keefe, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, seems to be digging in his heels against any effort to overturn his cancellation of the next shuttle servicing mission to the Hubble Space Telescope, thereby sentencing this extraordinary scientific instrument to a probable death in 2007. Under pressure this week, Mr. O'Keefe agreed to solicit advice from the National Academy of Sciences, but made it clear that there is little chance he will reverse course. He wants the academy to focus on ways to extend Hubble's usefulness that do not require a visit by astronauts. The administrator's reluctance makes it imperative that Congress insist on a full-scale analysis of the risks and benefits of servicing the Hubble, and that the academy refuse to undertake anything less. The premature termination of such a valuable scientific instrument is too important a decision to be left solely to an administrator who announced the cancellation without warning in January and has yet to justify the decision adequately.

headline.main: The View From/New Rochelle; What the Wise Men Saw: A Star? Maybe

stories.snippet: THE Star of Bethlehem, said to have guided the Three Wise Men to the birthplace of Jesus, may not have been a star at all. In fact, in all probability the bright object in the sky was actually three objects, a conjunction of the planets Mars, Jupiter...
stories.lead_paragraph: THE Star of Bethlehem, said to have guided the Three Wise Men to the birthplace of Jesus, may not have been a star at all. In fact, in all probability the bright object in the sky was actually three objects, a conjunction of the planets Mars, Jupiter and Saturn, Dr. Martin Steinbaum said. Dr. Steinbaum is an astronomer, professor of astronomy and science education at Iona College here, and the recently retired director of space science for the New Rochelle school system. He is also the author of ''The Star of Bethlehem,'' a planetarium show, which marks its 28th season this month. The show, which runs about an hour and a half, is a melange of star projections (the pinpoints of light that represent stars, planets and other heavenly bodies in planetariums), slides, music and narration. It will be presented at New Rochelle High School, free of charge, on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday this week and Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday next week, all at 8 P.M. (The number to call for information is 576-4589.)

headline.main: OBSERVATORY

stories.snippet: Bees Buzzing With Data      When a honeybee finds a good source of food, it quickly alerts its hive mates as to what it is and where to find it. With the honeybee's cousin the bumblebee, however, foraging has been considered an every-bee-for-itself...
stories.lead_paragraph: Bees Buzzing With Data When a honeybee finds a good source of food, it quickly alerts its hive mates as to what it is and where to find it. With the honeybee's cousin the bumblebee, however, foraging has been considered an every-bee-for-itself affair. Bumblebees were thought to guard information about food sources, like a New Yorker who has discovered a great hole-in-the-wall restaurant and doesn't want it to get overrun. But new research by scientists from the University of Wurzburg in Germany shows that bumblebees aren't that tight-lipped. By carefully controlling which insects in a nest were able to search for food and what they were able to find, the researchers discovered that a returning bumblebee tells its mates about the type of flower it found. It just doesn't reveal the location.

stories.abstract: Article on mission of discovery, which has also brought glimpses of natures' breathtaking beauty, embarked upon by twin Voyager spacecraft in late summer of 1977; both spacecraft visited Jupiter and Saturn, Voyager 2 continued on to Uranus and Neptune and both are still transmitting data far beyond Sun's outermost planets; Voyager 1 is now 7.9 billion miles from Earth, more than twice as far away as Pluto, and Voyager 2 is 6.3 billion miles away; NASA Jet Propulsion Lab flight controllers say spacecraft appear able to function long enough to reach heliopause, where solar system ends and rest of space begins; photos; diagrams (L)

headline.main: Voyagers Reap a Bounty of Beauty and Discovery

stories.snippet: Twenty-five years ago, in the late summer of 1977, two identical spacecraft took off on missions of exploration deep into the outer solar system. No drum rolls accompanied their launchings, no bloated language of cold war victories to be won or...
stories.lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years ago, in the late summer of 1977, two identical spacecraft took off on missions of exploration deep into the outer solar system. No drum rolls accompanied their launchings, no bloated language of cold war victories to be won or Odysseyan adventures ahead. In a departure from an earlier practice, the spacecraft were not given fanciful names from mythology, like Mercury or Gemini or Apollo. They were called simply the Voyagers. Their grandeur had to be earned. And so it was, through their own unexpected durability, the ingenuity of engineers and scientists on the ground and -- in no small measure -- nature's unending capacity for surprise, diversity and breathtaking beauty.

stories.snippet: WHEN Jeffrey K. Harris was head of the National Reconnaissance Office in the mid-1990's, his agency's satellites routinely peered down on the world's hot spots from outer space and photographed them for federal intelligence agencies. It was all...
stories.lead_paragraph: WHEN Jeffrey K. Harris was head of the National Reconnaissance Office in the mid-1990's, his agency's satellites routinely peered down on the world's hot spots from outer space and photographed them for federal intelligence agencies. It was all supersecret and all dedicated to national security. Now Mr. Harris has a new job and a new agenda. As president of Space Imaging Inc., a private company in Thornton, Colo., he wants to get rich by selling photographs taken by his company's satellite camera -- the first in the world to rival military reconnaissance in accuracy and sharpness.

headline.main: Abstraction in a Celestial Palette, Courtesy of Robots and Outer Space

stories.snippet: While images of Mars, Jupiter and Saturn filled a giant screen in the background, speakers ruminated on the topic of interplanetary photography. It resolves specks of distant light into places of astonishing form and beauty, it opens the eyes of...
stories.lead_paragraph: While images of Mars, Jupiter and Saturn filled a giant screen in the background, speakers ruminated on the topic of interplanetary photography. It resolves specks of distant light into places of astonishing form and beauty, it opens the eyes of science to discovery, but is it art? Specifically, can pictures taken by spacecraft millions of miles away from their human masters truly be deemed art?

stories.snippet: 'I Can Sing Anything . . .'      In many bird species, a song duel is just that -- a pitched battle (so to speak) between two males that warble it out for control of territory. But an avian battle of the bands does not occur in a vacuum. As...
stories.lead_paragraph: 'I Can Sing Anything . . .' In many bird species, a song duel is just that -- a pitched battle (so to speak) between two males that warble it out for control of territory. But an avian battle of the bands does not occur in a vacuum. As researchers from Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario, demonstrate in the current issue of Science, females may be listening -- and making choices based on what they hear.

headline.main: Studies of 2 Alien Planets Show No Evidence of Water

stories.snippet: And now the alien planet weather report: scorching, dry, dark and windy.     Astronomers said yesterday that the most extensive examinations yet of the atmospheres of planets orbiting other stars was most noteworthy for what they did not see: namely...
stories.lead_paragraph: And now the alien planet weather report: scorching, dry, dark and windy. Astronomers said yesterday that the most extensive examinations yet of the atmospheres of planets orbiting other stars was most noteworthy for what they did not see: namely water, a substance predicted by virtually all theories of planet formation, not to mention the essential ingredient for life as we know it.

headline.main: OBSERVATORY

stories.snippet: New Cosmic Titleholder      A recount of sorts has been undertaken in California, and the results appear to have overturned a previously certified outcome.    This has nothing to do with Al or George (or Chad, for that matter). No, the recount in...
stories.lead_paragraph: New Cosmic Titleholder A recount of sorts has been undertaken in California, and the results appear to have overturned a previously certified outcome. This has nothing to do with Al or George (or Chad, for that matter). No, the recount in question -- reobservation might be a more accurate term -- involves a galaxy with the prosaic name STIS 123627+621755. Since last year this object had held the title of Most Distant Thing Ever Seen in the Universe.

headline.main: OBSERVATORY

stories.snippet: Twisted Strips of Crystal      You remember the Möbius strip, don't you? It's that oddity of topology you may have played around with as a schoolchild: a two-sided strip of paper that becomes one-sided when one end is given a half-twist as it is...
stories.lead_paragraph: Twisted Strips of Crystal You remember the Möbius strip, don't you? It's that oddity of topology you may have played around with as a schoolchild: a two-sided strip of paper that becomes one-sided when one end is given a half-twist as it is joined to the other to form a loop. Researchers at Hokkaido University in Japan remember the Möbius strip, and have created one in their lab. It's not made of paper, however, but rather of a single ribbonlike crystal -- about 50 microns in diameter.

stories.snippet: To someone stepping off a stifling hot 125th Street, the Apollo Theater - cool, dark and empty, as it was on a recent afternoon - felt like hallowed space. A tap-dancing man in a fedora beat out rhythms onstage, while a few musicians stood together...
stories.lead_paragraph: To someone stepping off a stifling hot 125th Street, the Apollo Theater - cool, dark and empty, as it was on a recent afternoon - felt like hallowed space. A tap-dancing man in a fedora beat out rhythms onstage, while a few musicians stood together collectively improvising a new song. But things snapped to order when a slim man in a black tuxedo strode across the stage, glanced at his watch and told the musicians, ''Time to do it.''

stories.abstract: Eight teachers, college counselor and school aide from Celia Cruz Bronx High School of Music, members of rock band Suspensions, will be among 17 acts performing in first Teachers' Night at the Apollo on June 2; band members comment; photos (M)

headline.main: A Night at the Apollo, Starring Teachers

stories.snippet: On Wednesday, 17 acts will perform in the first Teachers’ Night at the Apollo, an eclectic roster including a hula hooper, comedians, poets and musicians of all stripes.
stories.lead_paragraph: JOHN MORO, a walkie-talkie-wielding dean, was patrolling the halls of the Celia Cruz Bronx High School of Music one recent afternoon, droning, ''Let's go! Ladies, walk and talk please.'' Lisa Gwasda was leading her choir class in lilting 16th-century madrigals, Paula Kadanoff was teaching a health class on safe sex, and Matthew Daley was coaxing ideas from his senior English class about the use of hubris in ''Beowulf,'' ''Macbeth,'' ''Oedipus Rex'' and Percy Bysshe Shelley's ''Ozymandias.'' Then the bell rang, and the four descended into the school's basement. They plugged in amplifiers, broke out microphones, unpacked instruments and turned into the Suspensions, a soul-infused rock band composed of eight teachers plus a college counselor and a school aide singing backup.

stories.lead_paragraph: The National Association of Orchestra Leaders has filed papers supporting the management of the Apollo Theater in a labor dispute with musicians who work on the program ''Amateur Night at the Apollo,'' officials said yesterday. In a letter to Grace Blake, the executive director of the Apollo Foundation, Charles Peterson, the treasurer of the orchestra leaders association, called the attempts by band members to organize a union ''illegal and unlawful practices.''

headline.main: Just Another 17-Year-Old Who Has Her Own Label

stories.snippet: Gabrielle Ross may be dedicated to her music, but she’s not exactly a slick self-promoter.
stories.lead_paragraph: GABRIELLE ROSS may be dedicated to her music, but she's not exactly a slick self-promoter. She was discovered, after all, on karaoke night at Broccoli Garden, a Chinese restaurant in Levittown. ''I'm very into my career, but I'm also a down-to-earth girl from Long Island,'' Ms. Ross, 17, who lives in Bellmore, explained before performing at a Patti LaBelle tribute in Harlem last month. ''I don't have psycho stage parents or anything like that.''

stories.abstract: Growing controversy over NASA's award of space shuttle engine contract to N Amer Rockwell Corp's Rocketdyne Div discussed; Repr Cotter and 9 Sens, who have forced 3-mo delay in signing of contract, are pressing NASA for more complete explanation of decision; Gen Acctg Office is probing matter; Cotter charges Nixon Adm influenced NASA's choice; Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Div of United Aircraft Corp, which was competing for contract, has filed complaint charging selection was 'illegal, arbitrary and capricious'; charges Rocketdyne was allowed exclusive use of tech garnered from another NASA contract, practice that may be illegal, and that some of reasoning used by NASA against Pratt & Whitney proposal should also have been applied to Rocketdyne concept; Rocketdyne officials regard protest as 'fit of pique' by 'losing competitor'; N Amer Rockwell pres Anderson expresses confidence that NASA decision will be upheld by Gen Acctg Office; rendering of space shuttle orbiter craft designed by N Amer Rockwell

stories.lead_paragraph: A multimillionaire's newest rocket is poised to blast off Friday from Cape Canaveral in a trial run of what the pioneering company hopes to do for NASA once the shuttles stop flying. Space Exploration Technologies' Falcon 9 rocket will try to carry a mock-up of its Dragon capsule into orbit on Friday. NASA wants to use the combo to haul cargo to the International Space Station. Elon Musk, chief executive of SpaceX and a co-founder of PayPal, said astronauts could follow within three years of his company's getting a contract.

headline.main: Engineers Plug Leaks on Rocket to Saturn

stories.snippet: NASA's multibillion-dollar Cassini mission to Saturn was back on track today after its Air Force Titan rocket was found to be free of leaks in a launching pad test.    Leaks in the upper stage of the 20-story Titan 4B rocket were detected on Aug. 5...
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA's multibillion-dollar Cassini mission to Saturn was back on track today after its Air Force Titan rocket was found to be free of leaks in a launching pad test. Leaks in the upper stage of the 20-story Titan 4B rocket were detected on Aug. 5 in a fueling test, raising fears that the powerful booster would not be ready to dispatch the probe in its narrow launching window. But engineers were able to plug the leaks.

stories.abstract: Highly successful Cassini mission to Saturn is prime example of orbital mechanics, science of moving craft in space using gravity for propulsion to reduce need for fuel; Cassini arrived at Saturn in 2004 for four-year mission, but has since had mission extended to 2017; John C Smith, mission planning engineer with Jet Propulsion Laboratory, and colleague Brent Buffington designed mission; photos; drawings; graphs (L)

headline.main: A Saturn Spectacular, With Gravity's Help

stories.snippet: Scientists have a plan to extend the life, on relatively little fuel, of NASA’s Cassini spacecraft, now in its sixth year of studying Saturn.
stories.lead_paragraph: When it comes to voyages of discovery, NASA's venerable Cassini mission is about as good as it gets. In six years of cruising around the planet Saturn and its neighborhood, the Cassini spacecraft has discovered two new Saturn rings, a bunch of new moons and a whole new class of moonlets. It encountered liquid lakes on the moon Titan, water ice and a particle plume on the moon Enceladus, ridges and ripples on the rings, and cyclones at Saturn's poles. Cassini also released a European space probe that landed on Titan. And Cassini has sent back enough data to produce more than 1,400 scientific papers -- at last count.

stories.abstract: Cassini spacecraft cruises to within 745 miles of Titan, Saturn's planet-sized moon, and sends back video images to NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif; Dr Carolyn Porco, leader of imaging team, says images are better than best they have seen before; first detailed exploration of Titan is perhaps most eagerly anticipated objective of $3.2 billion Cassini mission to Saturn (M)

headline.main: First Saturn Moon Close-Ups Arrive After Spacecraft Flyby

stories.snippet: The moon, long an enigma wrapped in smog, has been described by one scientist as the "largest unexplored surface in the solar system."
stories.lead_paragraph: The Cassini spacecraft cruised on Tuesday to within 745 miles of Titan, Saturn's planet-size moon, for the first close encounter with it. The moon, long an enigma wrapped in smog, has been described by one scientist as the ''largest unexplored surface in the solar system.'' Scientists and flight controllers here at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory cheered when radio signals arrived at 9:25 p.m., Eastern time, announcing the successful flyby. Twenty minutes later, the first pictures of Titan appeared on video monitors in the control room.

stories.snippet: Far-ranging barn swallows, induction cooktops, vitamin-infused grapes and light pollution.
stories.lead_paragraph: It's Heating Up Inside If you want to wow your friends in the kitchen (and you have cash to spare), replace your old stove with an induction cooktop. The appliance works as if by magic: pots and pans heat up, but the surface of the cooktop stays cool. It's not magic at work, of course, but magnetic induction. A coil below the cooktop surface creates a rapidly alternating magnetic field, which induces currents in the iron or steel of the cookware. Resistance to the current causes the pot or pan to heat up.

stories.snippet: Supernavigator's Secret      Honeybees can go home again, and again, and again. Their ability to return directly to the hive after a rambling flight in pursuit of food is remarkable, although exactly how they accomplish this has been unclear.    The...
stories.lead_paragraph: Supernavigator's Secret Honeybees can go home again, and again, and again. Their ability to return directly to the hive after a rambling flight in pursuit of food is remarkable, although exactly how they accomplish this has been unclear. The most reasonable explanation is that, like some other insects, they use vector navigation, constantly calculating the required direction of homeward travel from their movements during foraging.

headline.main: Columbia Is Helping to Bring Royal Shakespeare to Apollo

stories.snippet: Columbia University and the University of Michigan are teaming up to sponsor the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of Salman Rushdie's allegorical novel, ''Midnight's Children,'' and to bring it to the United States in the spring.    The...
stories.lead_paragraph: Columbia University and the University of Michigan are teaming up to sponsor the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of Salman Rushdie's allegorical novel, ''Midnight's Children,'' and to bring it to the United States in the spring. The production will be presented in January and February in London and in March in Michigan and New York, where it will play at the Apollo Theater on 125th Street. It builds upon scripts that Mr. Rushdie wrote for a five-part serialization of the 1981 novel for the BBC; the project was canceled shortly before it was to be filmed in Sri Lanka because of political upheaval there.

headline.main: A Compliment Sharansky Can't Refuse

stories.snippet: Natan Sharansky's ideas seem to have found a place in the affections of President Bush, who has embraced his new book.
stories.lead_paragraph: Natan Sharansky, the Soviet dissident turned Israeli politician, admits that his ideas have not much altered his new country. Government after government, from the left or right, have heard him out politely but then dismissed his arguments as irrelevant. They seem to have found a place, however, in the affections of the American president, George W. Bush, who has embraced Mr. Sharansky and his new book, ''The Case for Democracy: The Power of Freedom to Overcome Tyranny & Terror,'' which depicts a clear moral universe divided into ''free societies,'' which promote peace, and ''fear societies,'' which foster war.

stories.snippet: A number of people who assisted or survive the victims of the Arizona shootings will join Michelle Obama in her gallery box in the House chamber on Tuesday night to watch President Obama deliver the annual State of the Union address.     Robert...
stories.lead_paragraph: A number of people who assisted or survive the victims of the Arizona shootings will join Michelle Obama in her gallery box in the House chamber on Tuesday night to watch President Obama deliver the annual State of the Union address. Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, said on Monday that seated near the first lady for the joint session of Congress would be Daniel Hernandez, an intern to Representative Gabrielle Giffords whose immediate attention to her brain wound is credited with helping to save her life; members of the family of the youngest victim who died, 9-year-old Christina Taylor Green; and Dr. Peter Rhee, the director of the trauma center at the University of Arizona Medical Center in Tucson, where the casualties were treated.

stories.abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column imagines a conversation between Alexander Hamilton and Edmund Burke in which they discuss their reactions to Pres Obama's State of the Union address (M)

headline.main: Mr. Hamilton and Mr. Burke

stories.snippet: Two of the greats debate the president’s State of the Union address.
stories.lead_paragraph: Every Thursday my gurus, Mr. Burke and Mr. Hamilton, get together at the Heavenly Rest to drink and talk politics. Mr. Burke prefers a whiskey and water, while Mr. Hamilton likes a good strong Sex on the Beach. This week, they ended up talking about President Obama. Burke: I congratulate you. Your president is most prudent and wise. He has decided to focus on three things: education reform, infrastructure investment and scientific innovation. He's not wasting money on desperate schemes to pump up the employment rate before the next elections. He's thinking about the long-term prosperity of the nation.

stories.abstract: Pres Obama will outline an agenda for 'winning the future' in his State of the Union address, striking a theme of national unity and renewal as he stresses the need for government spending in key areas, particularly job creation, balanced with cutting the budget deficit; message will be geared more broadly toward the political center, toward independent voters who may have been alienated during his first two years in office (M)

headline.main: OBAMA TO PRESS CENTRIST AGENDA IN HIS ADDRESS

stories.snippet: President Obama will strike a theme of national unity and renewal in his State of the Union address Tuesday as he stresses the need for both government spending in key areas and an attack on the budget deficit.

byline.original: By JACKIE CALMES and JEFF ZELENY; Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Helene Cooper contributed reporting

stories.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- President Obama will outline an agenda for ''winning the future'' in his State of the Union address on Tuesday night, striking a theme of national unity and renewal as he stresses the need for government spending in key areas and an attack on the budget deficit. Mr. Obama previewed the themes in a video e-mailed Saturday evening to supporters who had helped in his election campaign. But the video made plain that his speech would be geared more broadly toward the political center, to independent voters and business owners and executives alienated by the expansion of government and the partisan legislative fights of the past two years.

headline.main: On Edge in Outer Space? It Has Happened Before

stories.snippet: American space experts say they believe that Vasily Tsibliyev, the commander of the Mir space station, has been badly shaken by a series of space failures in recent months and is intent on avoiding a risky repair mission.    If so, they say, he joins...
stories.lead_paragraph: American space experts say they believe that Vasily Tsibliyev, the commander of the Mir space station, has been badly shaken by a series of space failures in recent months and is intent on avoiding a risky repair mission. If so, they say, he joins a little-known roster of astronauts who have rebelled against Mission Control when faced with heightened risks or tensions in exploring space.

stories.abstract: American and Russian astronaut get some belated Christmas turkey and vital supplies when pilotless cargo ship docks at international space station, ending shortage that had alarmed officials at home and forced two men to ration supplies (M)

headline.main: Cargo Ship Brings Space Station Crew Belated Christmas Dinner

stories.snippet: An American and a Russian astronaut got vital supplies when a pilotless cargo ship docked at the International Space Station.
stories.lead_paragraph: An American and a Russian astronaut got some belated Christmas turkey and vital supplies on Sunday when a pilotless cargo ship docked at the international space station, ending a shortage that had alarmed officials at home and forced the two men to ration supplies. The Progress M-51 docked at the orbiting station without problems. Workers at Russian Mission Control in Korolyov, near Moscow, applauded when the hookup, seen on television screens, was completed.

stories.abstract: Two astronauts aboard International Space Station install antennas and release baby Sputnik on spacewalk, completing work just before station drifts and rolls slightly because of overloaded gyroscopes; NASA says slow roll was not unexpected; astronauts are American and Russian; photo (M)

headline.main: Spacewalking Men, Cartwheeling Craft

stories.snippet: For reasons that are not entirely clear to NASA, the space station has tended to drift during spacewalks over the past year or so.
stories.lead_paragraph: The two astronauts aboard the International Space Station installed antennas and released a baby Sputnik on a spacewalk Monday, completing the work just before the station drifted and rolled slightly because of overloaded gyroscopes. The astronauts were in no danger, and the slow roll, which lasted 17 minutes, was not unexpected. In fact, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said the station held steady longer than expected.
